description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner (CASP) certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and a brief amount of details about the exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. The CASP covers the technical knowledge and skills required to conceptualize, design, and engineer secure solutions across complex enterprise environments. The certification is designed for advanced security professionals that have knowledge of Security+, have a few years of experience in the field, and will go on to learn more advanced skills and need to understand things like risk management and incident response and is also approved by U.S. Dept. of Defense to meet IA technical and management certification requirements.

00:30:42.796 --> 00:30:46.351
that is essentially as a service model,
SASS, PASS,

645
00:30:46.351 --> 00:30:51.222
or IASS with a third party vendor,
we use SLAs to essentially negotiate and

646
00:30:51.222 --> 00:30:56.360
to manage the expectations for hosting
between me and the third party vendor.

647
00:30:56.360 --> 00:31:00.900
Whether it's Microsoft, Google,
Amazon, VMWare, whoever that may be.

648
00:31:00.900 --> 00:31:02.960
We have a combination of
these when we do outsourcing.

649
00:31:02.960 --> 00:31:06.329
It's very important for
us to think about very often in the cloud,

650
00:31:06.329 --> 00:31:10.118
in the cloud models, we have to worry
about SLAs and MLAs both cuz as I said,

651
00:31:10.118 --> 00:31:12.850
we may be hosting on prem,
we may be hosting off prem.

652
00:31:12.850 --> 00:31:15.918
We may have what's known as a hybrid
cloud where we have both public and

653
00:31:15.918 --> 00:31:19.299
private cloud capabilities, and so
we're gonna be thinking about all these

654
00:31:19.299 --> 00:31:22.050
different models and
how we're gonna deal with that.

655
00:31:22.050 --> 00:31:24.826
Mergers and
acquisitions are very big in this space.

656
00:31:24.826 --> 00:31:28.670
We have to be thinking about mergers
to organizations agree they're gonna

657
00:31:28.670 --> 00:31:30.693
essentially get together in partner.

658
00:31:30.693 --> 00:31:34.978
One organization buys essentially the
other, so Dell acquiring EMC and VMware,

659
00:31:34.978 --> 00:31:39.030
right recently at the end of 2000 or
2015, I was gonna say 2015.

660
00:31:39.030 --> 00:31:40.400
I would have been.

661
00:31:40.400 --> 00:31:44.283
Right, the AV versus BC conversation,
right?

662
00:31:44.283 --> 00:31:48.175
So Dell acquiring EMC and
ultimately as a result acquiring VMware,

663
00:31:48.175 --> 00:31:50.890
is an example of a merger and acquisition.

664
00:31:50.890 --> 00:31:53.196
They went out and
essentially bought those companies and

665
00:31:53.196 --> 00:31:55.270
are becoming much bigger
in that space as a result.

666
00:31:55.270 --> 00:31:58.450
So mergers are very important for
us as well.

667
00:31:58.450 --> 00:32:00.834
Demergers are what
are called divestitures,

668
00:32:00.834 --> 00:32:03.593
where a company essentially
sells off a whole areas.

669
00:32:03.593 --> 00:32:07.971
So Verizon acquired a Terremark over the
last several years back in probably about

670
00:32:07.971 --> 00:32:10.900
2011, 2012, 2013 somewhere in there.

671
00:32:10.900 --> 00:32:14.940
They bought the data hosting and
data center business.

672
00:32:14.940 --> 00:32:17.510
Very very big business
globally called Terremark.

673
00:32:17.510 --> 00:32:21.832
They're now at the end of 2015-
2016 they are divesting essentially

674
00:32:21.832 --> 00:32:26.255
selling off Terremark and all the data
centers, the maps etc that they bought.

675
00:32:26.255 --> 00:32:27.260
Theyre getting out of that business.

676
00:32:27.260 --> 00:32:31.054
So a company buys somebody and
then a couple years later they divest and

677
00:32:31.054 --> 00:32:32.671
essentially get rid of them.

678
00:32:32.671 --> 00:32:35.733
So either demerger or divestiture are the
terms that you often hear where companies

679
00:32:35.733 --> 00:32:38.550
will essentially devolve and
get rid of some of those acquisitions.

680
00:32:38.550 --> 00:32:40.730
This happens all the time in our industry,
in our business.

681
00:32:40.730 --> 00:32:44.702
And we have to think about the regulatory
concerns, the risk concerns the data

682
00:32:44.702 --> 00:32:48.799
management and information management
concerns associated with acquiring and

683
00:32:48.799 --> 00:32:51.026
merging, but also about breaking apart and

684
00:32:51.026 --> 00:32:54.843
figuring out who's gonna own my data and
how we're gonna manage all that.

685
00:32:54.843 --> 00:32:59.867
These are very important things and for
for you, for me, for Mike, for all of us,

686
00:32:59.867 --> 00:33:04.169
critical concerns that we really have to
be focused on again from a due care and

687
00:33:04.169 --> 00:33:05.913
a due diligence perspective.

688
00:33:05.913 --> 00:33:07.850
Very, very important to consider.

689
00:33:07.850 --> 00:33:10.640
All right Adam, again, a lot of great
information there on risk management.

690
00:33:10.640 --> 00:33:12.980
Some eye opening facts as well.

691
00:33:12.980 --> 00:33:15.410
A good look at some of the resources
again that we have available.

692
00:33:15.410 --> 00:33:20.117
A look at some of those publications that
are available out there for us online to

693
00:33:20.117 --> 00:33:24.770
help us develop our risk management
framework and our understanding of that.

694
00:33:24.770 --> 00:33:27.446
So thanks again for that Adam.

695
00:33:27.446 --> 00:33:28.406
Appreciate it.

696
00:33:28.406 --> 00:33:29.566
Hope everyone out there enjoyed watching.

697
00:33:29.566 --> 00:33:32.320
Remember, if you wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live,

698
00:33:32.320 --> 00:33:34.486
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

699
00:33:34.486 --> 00:33:36.406
Sounding off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

700
00:33:36.406 --> 00:33:37.966
>> I'm not Mike.

701
00:33:37.966 --> 00:33:39.286
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

702
00:33:39.286 --> 00:33:40.286
>> Take care everybody.

703
00:33:40.286 --> 00:33:41.926
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Risk Management Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.086 --> 00:00:10.086
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.359 --> 00:00:15.621
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.621 --> 00:00:17.106
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.106 --> 00:00:20.763
Today we're doing our CompTIA Advanced
Security Practitioner content.

5
00:00:20.763 --> 00:00:26.236
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be focusing in on risk management,

6
00:00:26.236 --> 00:00:30.280
as well as tossing in a little
security and privacy policies.

7
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:35.240
And to borrow one of
Adam Gordon's SAT vocabulary words,

8
00:00:35.240 --> 00:00:38.230
the plethora of acronyms
that go along with them.

9
00:00:38.230 --> 00:00:41.030
So here to help us with all that is,
of course, Mr. Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:41.030 --> 00:00:42.270
How's it going, Adam?

11
00:00:42.270 --> 00:00:44.190
>> Plethora, I like that.

12
00:00:44.190 --> 00:00:45.080
That's good.
>> I'm learning.

13
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:48.790
>> The real challenge for Mike is, can he
spell that and actually define plethora?

14
00:00:48.790 --> 00:00:50.085
Can you use that in a sentence?

15
00:00:50.085 --> 00:00:54.350
He's just simply aspiring,
right, to that word.

16
00:00:54.350 --> 00:00:56.920
All right, so
we're gonna continue our conversations.

17
00:00:56.920 --> 00:01:00.520
And we are gonna pick up where we
left off, talking about risks,

18
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:03.660
surprising though that may be,
shocking as that may be.

19
00:01:03.660 --> 00:01:05.770
We're gonna continue talking about risk.

20
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:08.150
The thing with risk is
that it never goes away.

21
00:01:08.150 --> 00:01:10.920
And as a result,
we gotta keep our minds focused.

22
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:15.163
We've really gotta be thinking logically,
physically, all the time about where risk

23
00:01:15.163 --> 00:01:19.010
is, where it's lurking, what we can
do to potentially fetter it out.

24
00:01:19.010 --> 00:01:22.010
We've been talking right at the end
of the last episode about mergers,

25
00:01:22.010 --> 00:01:26.855
about acquisitions, about divestitures,
about how we can bring in companies

26
00:01:26.855 --> 00:01:31.710
and/or get rid of them, and add or remove
risk to our overall business as a result.

27
00:01:31.710 --> 00:01:34.950
We have to think about the fact that
third party providers, our vendors,

28
00:01:34.950 --> 00:01:39.300
our suppliers also bring risk in or
invite risk into our organization.

29
00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:43.588
Ask Target whether or not they think that
partnering with a third party provider

30
00:01:43.588 --> 00:01:47.248
is such a good idea and is not gonna
have any risk associated with it.

31
00:01:47.248 --> 00:01:50.791
And you'll probably get a very different
answer than you would from somebody who

32
00:01:50.791 --> 00:01:54.281
has not recently had one of the largest
data breaches in InfoSec history occur to

33
00:01:54.281 --> 00:01:55.450
their company.

34
00:01:55.450 --> 00:01:59.580
And as a result, I mentioned this in
one of our prior episodes as well,

35
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:02.860
you have misguidance on managing
risk in the supply chain.

36
00:02:02.860 --> 00:02:03.930
It's very, very critical here.

37
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:07.730
For instance, as one example,
this is another area where as a CASP,

38
00:02:07.730 --> 00:02:10.100
you can exercise due care and
due diligence.

39
00:02:10.100 --> 00:02:13.330
But ultimately,
you could exercise common sense, right?

40
00:02:13.330 --> 00:02:16.610
And you could say to yourself,
if I'm gonna partner,

41
00:02:16.610 --> 00:02:21.750
if I'm gonna use a third party supplier to
essentially give me a good or a service,

42
00:02:21.750 --> 00:02:25.340
it's not what I'm getting from them
exclusively that I have to worry about.

43
00:02:25.340 --> 00:02:29.080
It's where they get it from and
who is essentially supplying them.

44
00:02:29.080 --> 00:02:33.700
Because I promise you, if you go look at
that outsourced third party relationship,

45
00:02:33.700 --> 00:02:36.200
they, the vendor,
let's call them Company ABC.

46
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:41.610
ABC Company is probably purveying
getting that information, that good,

47
00:02:41.610 --> 00:02:45.660
that service through another vendor,
and you're not seeing three, four,

48
00:02:45.660 --> 00:02:47.510
five levels down the supply chain.

49
00:02:47.510 --> 00:02:49.340
You're only seeing what's in front of you.

50
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:54.077
As most security professionals will tell
you, you inherit the risk of your vendors.

51
00:02:54.077 --> 00:02:58.382
And this is really critical for
you to understand as well, because this

52
00:02:58.382 --> 00:03:03.263
is what separates ultimately good
security policy, good security procedure,

53
00:03:03.263 --> 00:03:07.980
good practitioners from people that
just don't really see it coming.

54
00:03:07.980 --> 00:03:11.940
We've talked a lot about you managing
risk versus risk managing you

55
00:03:11.940 --> 00:03:13.400
in the organization.

56
00:03:13.400 --> 00:03:16.670
In order for you to manage risk, you have
to understand how to deal with third party

57
00:03:16.670 --> 00:03:21.040
providers and understand what third party
supply chain risk may or may not be.

58
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:26.524
Is it okay, for instance,
just to give you a hypothetical,

59
00:03:26.524 --> 00:03:31.200
is it okay for you, as a CASP
exercising due care and due diligence,

60
00:03:31.200 --> 00:03:34.808
is it okay for you to say in your RFP,
your request for

61
00:03:34.808 --> 00:03:38.850
information, RFI, or
your request for proposal, RFP.

62
00:03:38.850 --> 00:03:41.323
We use different terms,
depending what industry you're in and

63
00:03:41.323 --> 00:03:42.810
what you're looking to do.

64
00:03:42.810 --> 00:03:47.420
Is it okay in your RFP or
RFI with a vendor to stipulate that

65
00:03:47.420 --> 00:03:52.010
you expect them to uphold and to agree
to certain risk management standards and

66
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:55.240
best practices as part of
doing business with you?

67
00:03:55.240 --> 00:03:57.730
The answer is absolutely,
it is 100% acceptable.

68
00:03:57.730 --> 00:04:00.220
It is fully aligned with
best practices today.

69
00:04:00.220 --> 00:04:03.080
And more and
more companies are doing exactly this.

70
00:04:03.080 --> 00:04:06.480
Yet as a CASP, you would have
to know that it's acceptable,

71
00:04:06.480 --> 00:04:11.510
it's indeed required in some cases to be
regulatory compliant that you do this, and

72
00:04:11.510 --> 00:04:13.180
it's just good common sense.

73
00:04:13.180 --> 00:04:18.300
Why wouldn't you say to people that you're
gonna give information, good services,

74
00:04:18.300 --> 00:04:22.040
access to, that you want them to
uphold the same security standards

75
00:04:22.040 --> 00:04:25.580
that you essentially are asking the rest
of your organization to abide by?

76
00:04:25.580 --> 00:04:27.420
That just makes good sense
at the end of the day,

77
00:04:27.420 --> 00:04:29.670
if you think about the logic of that,
right?

78
00:04:29.670 --> 00:04:31.040
So, it's very, very important for us.

79
00:04:31.040 --> 00:04:35.110
So internal and external influences
really have to be thought about,

80
00:04:35.110 --> 00:04:37.190
how are we dealing with
compliance internally?

81
00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:40.150
Do we have an audit function internally,
are we managing that?

82
00:04:40.150 --> 00:04:43.160
Do we have a chief risk officer,
as I mentioned to you?

83
00:04:43.160 --> 00:04:45.600
Do we have external
compliance considerations?

84
00:04:45.600 --> 00:04:51.420
Do we have a third party relationship
with a company that can come in and

85
00:04:51.420 --> 00:04:53.130
can do a compliance audit for us?

86
00:04:53.130 --> 00:04:56.210
I do a lot of audit work,
with and for customers.

87
00:04:56.210 --> 00:04:58.460
Can you come in and
do that kind of work externally?

88
00:04:58.460 --> 00:05:02.160
Absolutely, get out your checkbook,
I'll tell you exactly how it works,

89
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:05.680
is the question and the answer you
often go through with a vendor.

90
00:05:05.680 --> 00:05:08.830
We hire external experts all the time
to come in and do this stuff.

91
00:05:08.830 --> 00:05:12.040
If you're in a regulated industry, if
you're in the bio-pharmaceutical industry,

92
00:05:12.040 --> 00:05:15.270
if you're in the financial services
industry, if you're in the defense

93
00:05:15.270 --> 00:05:18.380
contracting industry,
if you're in the communications industry,

94
00:05:18.380 --> 00:05:22.850
if you're a publicly traded company in the
United States or in the EU, you have to

95
00:05:22.850 --> 00:05:27.250
have external, third party risk compliance
as part of your corporate profile.

96
00:05:27.250 --> 00:05:29.270
And you have to have external
audits taking place.

97
00:05:29.270 --> 00:05:31.540
This is accepted behavior today.

98
00:05:31.540 --> 00:05:34.473
Security practitioner, the CASP,
needs to understand this and

99
00:05:34.473 --> 00:05:36.490
needs to be aligned with this.

100
00:05:36.490 --> 00:05:40.100
Question really is how well do you
understand what an audit goes,

101
00:05:40.100 --> 00:05:42.050
looks like, is executed as, etc.

102
00:05:42.050 --> 00:05:44.490
In other words,
do you have any background with this?

103
00:05:44.490 --> 00:05:47.810
And for many of the security professionals
today, the answer is not really.

104
00:05:47.810 --> 00:05:49.270
We just don't know much about audits.

105
00:05:49.270 --> 00:05:50.760
We're not engaged in them, at them.

106
00:05:50.760 --> 00:05:52.280
We don't take part in them, right?

107
00:05:52.280 --> 00:05:53.230
I've never seen one before.

108
00:05:53.230 --> 00:05:54.360
I've heard about them.

109
00:05:54.360 --> 00:05:56.940
I know people that do them, but
I've never actually taken part in one.

110
00:05:56.940 --> 00:05:59.855
I hear that all the time from students
as they come through classes.

111
00:05:59.855 --> 00:06:01.180
And that's not a bad thing.

112
00:06:01.180 --> 00:06:04.840
There is nothing wrong with never
having participated in an audit before.

113
00:06:04.840 --> 00:06:07.960
The only thing that's wrong with that
statement is you not willing to go out and

114
00:06:07.960 --> 00:06:11.290
find out about how to become good at
doing that in order to offset that

115
00:06:11.290 --> 00:06:12.320
lack of knowledge.

116
00:06:12.320 --> 00:06:13.410
Then we have a problem.

117
00:06:13.410 --> 00:06:14.520
Then we have an issue.

118
00:06:14.520 --> 00:06:16.700
But if you're pursuing knowledge,
if you're trying to figure it out,

119
00:06:16.700 --> 00:06:19.680
there's absolutely nothing wrong with
saying I haven't done something before.

120
00:06:19.680 --> 00:06:22.720
Just go out and learn how to do it
over time and become better at it.

121
00:06:22.720 --> 00:06:25.350
That's one of the reasons
you subscribe to ITProTV,

122
00:06:25.350 --> 00:06:28.120
because we can help you become
better at all these things.

123
00:06:28.120 --> 00:06:29.770
Mike's got a laundry
list of stuff in his back

124
00:06:29.770 --> 00:06:31.020
pocket he wants to get better at, right.

125
00:06:31.020 --> 00:06:33.330
And every day, he checks a box off.

126
00:06:33.330 --> 00:06:36.068
We add four or
five typically to his list every day.

127
00:06:36.068 --> 00:06:37.458
So he's never quite getting
ahead of himself, right,

128
00:06:37.458 --> 00:06:38.203
cuz we wanna keep him humble.

129
00:06:38.203 --> 00:06:41.490
That's one of the things that
makes him a great host, right.

130
00:06:41.490 --> 00:06:44.810
So think about all those things and
make sure we understand

131
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:48.860
that as a security professional, you've
gotta be willing and you've gotta be able,

132
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:52.030
most importantly, to admit you're
not capable of doing everything.

133
00:06:52.030 --> 00:06:54.130
This is the secret to being
successful in what we do.

134
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:56.920
You have to understand there
are limitations to your knowledge,

135
00:06:56.920 --> 00:06:58.100
you have to be willing to go out and

136
00:06:58.100 --> 00:07:01.210
partner with people that are experts
in those areas that you are not.

137
00:07:01.210 --> 00:07:04.895
Because you can't be good at everything,
the concept of the Renaissance person

138
00:07:04.895 --> 00:07:08.615
is a great ideal to uphold, but
it's very difficult to achieve, all right?

139
00:07:08.615 --> 00:07:12.345
Last time it was done successfully,
it was about the 15, 1600s.

140
00:07:12.345 --> 00:07:15.435
Leonardo da Vinci, and people of that
nature were at the top of that list.

141
00:07:15.435 --> 00:07:18.255
I haven't seen too many of those people
floating around recently, right?

142
00:07:18.255 --> 00:07:22.175
As a result of that, you've gotta
understand that while we can claim to be

143
00:07:22.175 --> 00:07:26.750
good at a lot of stuff, it's very hard
to actually show that in practice and

144
00:07:26.750 --> 00:07:29.760
with the complicated
ecosystems we manage today.

145
00:07:29.760 --> 00:07:34.630
Cloud services, virtualized environments,
clusters, high availability,

146
00:07:34.630 --> 00:07:39.786
VDI, virtual desktop infrastructure,
PKI, right, public key infrastructure,

147
00:07:39.786 --> 00:07:43.940
CA, certificate authorities,
and certificate infrastructure,

148
00:07:43.940 --> 00:07:49.045
risk management across the enterprise in
multiple formats with multiple systems.

149
00:07:49.045 --> 00:07:52.940
Baseline configuration management,
continuous monitoring, I mean,

150
00:07:52.940 --> 00:07:54.329
I could go on and on and on.

151
00:07:54.329 --> 00:07:58.507
IDS, intrusion detection,
IPS, intrusion prevention.

152
00:07:58.507 --> 00:08:02.055
Thinking about all those kinds of systems,
Firewalls, SIEM systems or

153
00:08:02.055 --> 00:08:04.620
Security Information Event Management.

154
00:08:04.620 --> 00:08:07.600
All these things you may be experts
at one or more of them, but

155
00:08:07.600 --> 00:08:10.170
you're not going to be
an expert at everything.

156
00:08:10.170 --> 00:08:12.910
I do this for a living,
I've done it for over 30 years and

157
00:08:12.910 --> 00:08:14.710
I'm not an expert at all that stuff.

158
00:08:14.710 --> 00:08:18.460
And I probably know a lot more about
some of it than some of you, but

159
00:08:18.460 --> 00:08:22.210
I don't know as much about it as some of
you because that's what you specialize in.

160
00:08:22.210 --> 00:08:26.050
One or more of those areas, right, and you
could teach me a lot of stuff, I'm sure.

161
00:08:26.050 --> 00:08:29.290
And the reality is that we've
gotta understand our limitations

162
00:08:29.290 --> 00:08:32.270
as a risk manager cuz we've gotta
be willing to ask for help.

163
00:08:32.270 --> 00:08:35.550
This is how we get better at
creating an overall risk profile

164

762
00:35:34.250 --> 00:35:36.702
We talked about them having
a very formalized relationship.

763
00:35:36.702 --> 00:35:39.969
They may have a BPA, and we would then
have to pick up on that subtlety and

764
00:35:39.969 --> 00:35:43.630
understand the difference between
the two as part of our conversation.

765
00:35:43.630 --> 00:35:47.500
So all those guidelines for integrating
documentation into risk management, or

766
00:35:47.500 --> 00:35:48.720
you could think of it the other way,

767
00:35:48.720 --> 00:35:51.440
integrating risk management
into our documentation.

768
00:35:51.440 --> 00:35:54.691
Either way, both are essentially the same
thing, are very important right?

769
00:35:54.691 --> 00:35:57.522
We gotta make sure we have
those policies we talked about.

770
00:35:57.522 --> 00:36:01.850
We've got to clearly identify all the
mission, the purpose, the objective, and

771
00:36:01.850 --> 00:36:03.760
value statements in the organization.

772
00:36:03.760 --> 00:36:06.330
We have to know what the business
objectives are in other words.

773
00:36:06.330 --> 00:36:08.510
We have to get our
stakeholders to buy in and

774
00:36:08.510 --> 00:36:10.820
tell us what's strategically is important.

775
00:36:10.820 --> 00:36:14.830
We then have to create policies to
reinforce those things, and clearly and

776
00:36:14.830 --> 00:36:18.070
formally communicate them to
everybody in the organization.

777
00:36:18.070 --> 00:36:20.910
We have to train on those policies,
create broad awareness.

778
00:36:20.910 --> 00:36:25.320
We have to create procedure and we have
to create process that will essentially

779
00:36:25.320 --> 00:36:30.080
drill down and implement through tactical
and operational formats the policies and

780
00:36:30.080 --> 00:36:31.580
the objectives of the policies.

781
00:36:31.580 --> 00:36:33.890
We have to train on those,
clearly document and

782
00:36:33.890 --> 00:36:35.820
communicate broadly around what those are.

783
00:36:35.820 --> 00:36:38.260
And we have to reinforce that over time.

784
00:36:38.260 --> 00:36:40.610
What about when somebody new gets
hired and comes on board, right?

785
00:36:40.610 --> 00:36:43.660
We have to have documentation for that,
and make sure we have all those things.

786
00:36:43.660 --> 00:36:44.860
So we have to broadly communicate,

787
00:36:44.860 --> 00:36:47.100
widely communicate,
train down on all these things and

788
00:36:47.100 --> 00:36:53.030
make sure that ultimately we understand
what it is that we're being asked to do.

789
00:36:53.030 --> 00:36:55.719
What we as CAFs are being
asked to do ultimately,

790
00:36:55.719 --> 00:36:59.602
is to act with both due care and
due diligence that I keep referring to.

791
00:36:59.602 --> 00:37:03.170
And the idea ultimately is that we have
to be the responsible party, right?

792
00:37:03.170 --> 00:37:06.140
Often the voice in the wilderness
that stands out there and says,

793
00:37:06.140 --> 00:37:07.800
hey, we forgot about this.

794
00:37:07.800 --> 00:37:08.750
We gotta remember this.

795
00:37:08.750 --> 00:37:09.730
We gotta document this.

796
00:37:09.730 --> 00:37:10.450
We gotta do this.

797
00:37:10.450 --> 00:37:13.030
This is important, and this is why.

798
00:37:13.030 --> 00:37:16.853
If we can answer the question, the why
question, we ultimately can understand

799
00:37:16.853 --> 00:37:20.687
how to align the organization, the
business objectives of the organization.

800
00:37:20.687 --> 00:37:23.980
We could understand how to align risk
management with those objectives.

801
00:37:23.980 --> 00:37:27.542
And we can clearly articulate and
formally detail a path forward,

802
00:37:27.542 --> 00:37:31.230
that although it may be fraught with risk,
we can trot ultimately and

803
00:37:31.230 --> 00:37:35.530
manage successfully because we're
gonna understand where the risks are.

804
00:37:35.530 --> 00:37:37.550
We've documented them and we're on watch.

805
00:37:37.550 --> 00:37:38.520
We're on guard for them.

806
00:37:38.520 --> 00:37:42.365
And we have steps, we have policies,
we have procedures, we have techniques and

807
00:37:42.365 --> 00:37:45.172
tools to implement to deal with
them as we go down that road.

808
00:37:45.172 --> 00:37:48.030
All right, this is really ultimately
what we're asked to do with regards to

809
00:37:48.030 --> 00:37:50.040
risk management security profession.

810
00:37:50.040 --> 00:37:53.945
>> Fantastic Adam, again as always a lot
of great information there, again looking

811
00:37:53.945 --> 00:37:57.720
at risk management and really diving
into the documentation side of things,

812
00:37:57.720 --> 00:38:02.538
looking at policies and great resources,
Sans will give you the ability.

813
00:38:02.538 --> 00:38:05.810
If you are called upon to create
these policies from scratch,

814
00:38:05.810 --> 00:38:08.680
it's a good resource to get you started,
to get you off on the right foot.

815
00:38:08.680 --> 00:38:10.170
So thanks again for that Adam.

816
00:38:10.170 --> 00:38:10.860
We enjoyed it.

817
00:38:10.860 --> 00:38:13.150
I hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

818
00:38:13.150 --> 00:38:15.410
Remember, if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

819
00:38:15.410 --> 00:38:18.760
shoot us an email here
at seeadam@itpro.tv.

820
00:38:18.760 --> 00:38:20.730
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

821
00:38:20.730 --> 00:38:21.600
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

822
00:38:21.600 --> 00:38:22.750
>> And we'll see you next time.

823
00:38:22.750 --> 00:38:24.002
>> Take care, everybody.

824
00:38:24.002 --> 00:38:31.698
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Incident Response
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:02.739
[SOUND]

2
00:00:02.739 --> 00:00:12.558
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:12.558 --> 00:00:15.826
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:15.826 --> 00:00:17.340
I'm your host Mike Roderick,

5
00:00:17.340 --> 00:00:20.606
today we're doing our
CompTIA Advanced Security practitioner.

6
00:00:20.606 --> 00:00:25.110
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at incident response.

7
00:00:25.110 --> 00:00:29.120
We've been talking a lot about risk and
risk management.

8
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:31.650
And we know,
Adam has explained to us several times,

9
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:33.530
that you can't get rid of all of it.

10
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:37.160
There's always gonna be some, and
we need to know what's gonna happen, or

11
00:00:37.160 --> 00:00:41.990
what we need to do, In the event that some
of those risks actually come to fruition.

12
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:45.040
So here to help us with that,
of course, is Mr. Adam Gordon.

13
00:00:45.040 --> 00:00:46.080
How's it going, Adam?

14
00:00:46.080 --> 00:00:48.900
>> Good. Good. How's everybody doing
out there this fine morning slash

15
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:49.945
afternoon almost?

16
00:00:49.945 --> 00:00:51.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hope everybody is well.

17
00:00:51.630 --> 00:00:55.060
So we're gonna start talking a little
bit more about incident response,

18
00:00:55.060 --> 00:00:57.500
or talk about it, we've talked
about it a little bit already.

19
00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:01.040
But as Mike alluded to,
we have talked a lot about risk, right?

20
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:05.810
And the idea with risk is that we never
really know when it's gonna pop up.

21
00:01:05.810 --> 00:01:08.660
We never really know where
risk will come from.

22
00:01:08.660 --> 00:01:12.900
We never really know what activities may
ultimately lead to behavior that is going

23
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:16.160
to pose a threat to the organization,
have some sort of negative impact.

24
00:01:16.160 --> 00:01:17.200
And as a result,

25
00:01:17.200 --> 00:01:21.300
we want to make sure we do,
is like the boy scouts say be prepared.

26
00:01:21.300 --> 00:01:24.130
Always be prepared is
a good motto in general.

27
00:01:24.130 --> 00:01:27.030
It is something that we as security
professionals, security practitioners,

28
00:01:27.030 --> 00:01:29.240
have to really work hard at doing.

29
00:01:29.240 --> 00:01:31.970
You know, the security professional,
security practitioner,

30
00:01:31.970 --> 00:01:37.070
the CASP, that makes it look easy,
is the person that puts in the time,

31
00:01:37.070 --> 00:01:40.570
spends the hours,
understands the value of planning,

32
00:01:40.570 --> 00:01:44.340
in order to make sure that when something
happens, they're prepared to respond.

33
00:01:44.340 --> 00:01:48.940
It's not about anticipating everything,
we often say it's about anticipating what

34
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:52.530
you know, maybe an issue,
control what you can, in other words, and

35
00:01:52.530 --> 00:01:57.520
then be prepared to respond and to react
to things that you can't anticipate.

36
00:01:57.520 --> 00:01:59.280
That you're not able to prepare for.

37
00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:03.790
Nobody says, or at least anybody that you
talk to that is knowledgeable [LAUGH]

38
00:02:03.790 --> 00:02:04.660
>> About these things,

39
00:02:04.660 --> 00:02:07.120
will tell you you can prepare for
everything, cuz it's a fallacy.

40
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:09.560
There are things that are gonna happen
you're just never gonna see coming.

41
00:02:09.560 --> 00:02:15.000
So what instant response is really all
about is planning to ensure, right?

42
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:16.190
Planning to be successful.

43
00:02:16.190 --> 00:02:20.360
Planning to ensure that we can
respond when something happens.

44
00:02:20.360 --> 00:02:23.000
If we know that something,
if we've identified it, great.

45
00:02:23.000 --> 00:02:24.850
If we don't, we still have to respond.

46
00:02:24.850 --> 00:02:27.590
We can't just sit around and
say, woe is me and

47
00:02:27.590 --> 00:02:29.960
be the ostrich that sticks
our head in the sand.

48
00:02:29.960 --> 00:02:30.660
It doesn't work.

49
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:32.690
I mean, it does but
it doesn't really work well for

50
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:37.060
us because what happens to those people is
that hackers come in and eat their lunch.

51
00:02:37.060 --> 00:02:41.140
And ultimately, they take away
their networks and they essentially

52
00:02:41.140 --> 00:02:45.270
own what is no longer gonna be
the property of the organization but

53
00:02:45.270 --> 00:02:46.970
now becomes a property of a bad actor.

54
00:02:46.970 --> 00:02:48.430
Because somebody takes it over.

55
00:02:48.430 --> 00:02:50.780
Well we want to do is to make sure
we prevent that from happening.

56
00:02:50.780 --> 00:02:53.550
So as we start thinking about
as incident response, right,

57
00:02:53.550 --> 00:02:56.800
we have to really think about both
internal and external violations.

58
00:02:56.800 --> 00:02:59.210
The idea is where is
the threat coming from.

59
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:01.450
Where is the vulnerability emerging from.

60
00:03:01.450 --> 00:03:03.070
Where is the bad actor?

61
00:03:03.070 --> 00:03:06.150
What is the activity that
is causing the concern?

62
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:09.560
We could have people internally
attempting to do us harm, right?

63
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:12.310
There are people, we're tied up before
we get started this morning Mike and

64
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:14.221
I, Mike's Doppelganger, right?

65
00:03:14.221 --> 00:03:15.231
>> [LAUGH]
>> His evil twin.

66
00:03:15.231 --> 00:03:16.442
That's out there somewhere.

67
00:03:16.442 --> 00:03:19.396
That pretends to be him when
nobody's around, comes in at night,

68
00:03:19.396 --> 00:03:22.640
does some ITProTV work, messes around
with the camera angles, right?

69
00:03:22.640 --> 00:03:23.895
Puts everything back when we're done.

70
00:03:23.895 --> 00:03:24.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

71
00:03:24.800 --> 00:03:28.090
mysteriously in the morning, everything's
exactly where it's supposed to be.

72
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:31.840
But we all have this idea in our head
of what a bad actor will be, right?

73
00:03:31.840 --> 00:03:33.940
And we often think, it's a hacker.

74
00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:36.150
It's somebody who's looking to do us harm,
and

75
00:03:36.150 --> 00:03:38.800
it's always somebody who's
outside the organization.

76
00:03:38.800 --> 00:03:42.610
When in fact, more studies show that, more
often than not, it's somebody we know,

77
00:03:42.610 --> 00:03:46.340
somebody we work with,
someone inside of our organization.

78
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:49.220
Somebody like Mike for instance,
can we go to Mike for a second?

79
00:03:49.220 --> 00:03:50.440
This evil person right here.

80
00:03:50.440 --> 00:03:51.078
He could be
>> [NOISE]

81
00:03:51.078 --> 00:03:52.590
>> A bad actor right?

82
00:03:52.590 --> 00:03:56.690
And so, the reality is that it
could be somebody that we work with

83
00:03:56.690 --> 00:04:00.870
who may just have a grudge against the
organization, somebody who ultimately may

84
00:04:00.870 --> 00:04:04.900
have a problem with what we're doing and
how we're doing it and as a result of that

85
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:09.120
may be looking to get us back,
not us per say but the organization.

86
00:04:09.120 --> 00:04:10.900
Right?
So we have to look internally and

87
00:04:10.900 --> 00:04:11.790
externally.

88
00:04:11.790 --> 00:04:15.180
External actors are sometimes
easier to identify, believe it or

89
00:04:15.180 --> 00:04:16.610
not then internal ones.

90
00:04:16.610 --> 00:04:19.030
Because we only know that there are so

91
00:04:19.030 --> 00:04:21.545
many ways that they can
come into the organization.

92
00:04:21.545 --> 00:04:25.955
There's only so many places they can
essentially enter our systems from.

93
00:04:25.955 --> 00:04:29.295
And if we're vigilant, if we're standing
guard, if we're watching those entry

94
00:04:29.295 --> 00:04:35.225
points, it's usually easier to find those
external actors attempting to probe,

95
00:04:35.225 --> 00:04:40.020
nibble around the edges of our perimeter,
through some sort of examination of logs.

96
00:04:40.020 --> 00:04:44.880
Looking at traffic flows,
examining inbound requests for services.

97
00:04:44.880 --> 00:04:47.900
We can begin to paint a picture of
what's going on from the outside in.

98
00:04:47.900 --> 00:04:53.200
But the internal actors, people behind the
firewall, inside that essentially have,

99
00:04:53.200 --> 00:04:56.930
in theory, some level of restricted
access, but more often than not have

100
00:04:56.930 --> 00:05:01.320
unrestricted access to many of the same
systems, that external actors would love

101
00:05:01.320 --> 00:05:05.390
to get their hands on, it's a lot
tougher to identify that behavior.

102
00:05:05.390 --> 00:05:07.350
Because when Mike legitimately, right?

103
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:11.390
Goes to access the ITPro TV library,
it may be tough for

104
00:05:11.390 --> 00:05:15.490
me to discern the fact that he's up to no
good because he has rights to be there and

105
00:05:15.490 --> 00:05:17.380
his log ons are legitimate.

106
00:05:17.380 --> 00:05:19.820
And they're happening during
normal business hours and

107
00:05:19.820 --> 00:05:24.610
the normal traffic we would see
that may indicate a possible

108
00:05:24.610 --> 00:05:28.710
violation occurring from outside the
organization is 100% percent legitimate,

109
00:05:28.710 --> 00:05:31.730
when Mike engages in that behavior
from behind the firewall.

110
00:05:31.730 --> 00:05:35.180
So, it's very hard sometimes to
identify those internal actors, right?

111
00:05:35.180 --> 00:05:38.185
We may have contractors Factors,
remember third parties, vendors,

112
00:05:38.185 --> 00:05:43.025
federated partners that may be acting
legitimately inside our systems.

113
00:05:43.025 --> 00:05:44.395
If they're compromised,

114
00:05:44.395 --> 00:05:48.985
if their credentials are taken, if they're
impersonated or masqueraded against,

115
00:05:48.985 --> 00:05:53.475
we may have a problem differentiating
between the real Mike and the fake Mike,

116
00:05:53.475 --> 00:05:57.010
the bad actor Mike who's looking to
do us harm, who pretends to be Mike.

117
00:05:57.010 --> 00:05:59.960
And we may not realize that
that really isn't Mike.

118
00:05:59.960 --> 00:06:01.420
It's Mike 2.0, right?

119
00:06:01.420 --> 00:06:03.050
Version B for bad, right?

120
00:06:03.050 --> 00:06:07.450
So we may not realize that it's the Mike
that is pretending to be Mike but

121
00:06:07.450 --> 00:06:09.480
is really the bad actor that
we're up against, right?

122
00:06:09.480 --> 00:06:12.760
And that's a real big issue and
so you know, co-workers,

123
00:06:12.760 --> 00:06:16.071
as we're seeing in the chat right,
a lot of the times, absolutely David.

124
00:06:16.071 --> 00:06:19.440
Co-workers as well as personal
vendettas as you point out.

125
00:06:19.440 --> 00:06:22.710
Absolutely correct,
there's a lot of things that go on.

126
00:06:22.710 --> 00:06:25.120
Right.
People's feelings get hurt,

127
00:06:25.120 --> 00:06:28.160
they feel passed over because of
a promotion going to somebody else.

128
00:06:28.160 --> 00:06:28.930
Who knows what it worked.

129
00:06:28.930 --> 00:06:32.380
There's all sorts of activity that
may lead somebody to feel that they

130
00:06:32.380 --> 00:06:36.170
legitimately have an axe to grind, kind of
what David was saying in the chat window.

131
00:06:36.170 --> 00:06:37.970
Right?
And as a result of that,

132
00:06:37.970 --> 00:06:40.780
we may see that that behavior
becomes very problematic.

133
00:06:40.780 --> 00:06:44.800
So we have to be looking internally
as often as we do externally, and

134
00:06:44.800 --> 00:06:47.350
really have to stand on the border,
theoretically,

135
00:06:47.350 --> 00:06:51.120
of our network,
with the two headed thought process.

136
00:06:51.120 --> 00:06:53.450
Looking internally and externally,
it looks like Cerberus,

137
00:06:53.450 --> 00:06:59.020
the three headed dog from Myths and
Legends, the Greek and the Roman pantheon.

138
00:06:59.020 --> 00:07:02.560
We think about that and we kind of think
of one head always looking forward,

139
00:07:02.560 --> 00:07:04.888
one looking internally,
one looking externally.

140
00:07:04.888 --> 00:07:07.180
Kind of having that multi part type view,

141
00:07:07.180 --> 00:07:09.340
trying to envision the world is really
what we have to think about here.

142
00:07:09.340 --> 00:07:14.790
You know when we think about DOS,
distributed denial of service, DDOS.

143
00:07:14.790 --> 00:07:17.360
We think about, as I said, masquerading.

144
00:07:17.360 --> 00:07:18.820
We think about spoofing attacks.

145
00:07:18.820 --> 00:07:23.088
All these kinds of things we really just
have to make sure that we're considering

146
00:07:23.088 --> 00:07:27.065
and being concerned with the ideas behind
where these attacks are coming from

147
00:07:27.065 --> 00:07:30.585
first and foremost with regards to
incident management and, of course,

148
00:07:30.585 --> 00:07:31.635
incident response.

149
00:07:31.635 --> 00:07:35.135
We have to think about the fact that
clearly we have insider threats

150
00:07:35.135 --> 00:07:37.552
with external threats,
but what about policies.

151
00:07:37.552 --> 00:07:39.392
What about somebody violating a policy?

152
00:07:39.392 --> 00:07:44.252
Not meaning to do that, right, but
maybe we have a usage policy for email.

153
00:07:44.252 --> 00:07:46.532
Maybe we have one for mobile devices.

154
00:07:46.532 --> 00:07:51.080
And it says that you're not supposed to
go out and search non-business sites.

155
00:07:51.080 --> 00:07:57.248
And or send non business email when you
are using company proprietary systems.

156
00:07:57.248 --> 00:08:00.462
So you're using a mobile platform
with a laptop or a cell phone or

157
00:08:00.462 --> 00:08:04.108
you're surfing the web or sending
an email using the corporate system.

158
00:08:04.108 --> 00:08:05.848
We don't want you emailing your friends.

159
00:08:05.848 --> 00:08:07.469
We don't want you on Facebook.

160
00:08:07.469 --> 00:08:10.300
We don't want you on LinkedIn or
whatever it may be.

161
00:08:10.300 --> 00:08:12.520
But if somebody goes out and
does that, and

162
00:08:12.520 --> 00:08:16.790
then downloads malware inadvertently or
gets spam email, a phishing email, and

163
00:08:16.790 --> 00:08:20.360
then essentially responds and
opens that system up, it's compromised.

164
00:08:20.360 --> 00:08:22.510
They've essentially violated the policy,
right?

00:31:30.260 --> 00:31:34.510
the copy does not get modified and
cannot be changed without our knowledge.

613
00:31:34.510 --> 00:31:38.610
We then use that copy,
essentially, to comply

614
00:31:38.610 --> 00:31:42.320
with the legal hold order because
the data's frozen at that moment in time.

615
00:31:42.320 --> 00:31:45.094
That allows us to forensically
to examine the data,

616
00:31:45.094 --> 00:31:49.508
allows us to provide it to whatever party
may be requesting it under e-discovery,

617
00:31:49.508 --> 00:31:53.418
but also allows the user under
investigation to continue working without

618
00:31:53.418 --> 00:31:57.538
any knowledge that they essentially,
potentially have a problem, right?

619
00:31:57.538 --> 00:32:01.962
So, as a result of this, we essentially
complied in two very specific,

620
00:32:01.962 --> 00:32:03.348
very important ways.

621
00:32:03.348 --> 00:32:07.385
We've provided the e-discovery
order with the full capability or

622
00:32:07.385 --> 00:32:09.380
the full control that they need.

623
00:32:09.380 --> 00:32:12.820
And we've complied to the full
capabilities of our ability to do so

624
00:32:12.820 --> 00:32:14.140
to provide that data.

625
00:32:14.140 --> 00:32:17.740
We also have not tipped off the person
that potentially is under investigation by

626
00:32:17.740 --> 00:32:18.500
doing this.

627
00:32:18.500 --> 00:32:20.938
So, this is what legal holds
allow us to essentially do.

628
00:32:20.938 --> 00:32:23.682
And the attorney has essentially said,
hey, by the way,

629
00:32:23.682 --> 00:32:27.170
I want access to the data, or
the court has said that, or whatever.

630
00:32:27.170 --> 00:32:28.700
And we need it, and

631
00:32:28.700 --> 00:32:31.400
you have to essentially give us
that data in the current form,

632
00:32:31.400 --> 00:32:34.690
cuz we thing there's something in there,
we want to figure out what it is.

633
00:32:34.690 --> 00:32:37.570
And so we put legal holds in
place all the time on data.

634
00:32:37.570 --> 00:32:40.837
Again, I could do this from my
tenant administrative console,

635
00:32:40.837 --> 00:32:42.477
my dashboard in Office 365.

636
00:32:42.477 --> 00:32:43.980
It's relatively straightforward to do.

637
00:32:43.980 --> 00:32:45.770
It's not hard to do at all.

638
00:32:45.770 --> 00:32:48.490
Little bit beyond the conversation
here with regards to

639
00:32:48.490 --> 00:32:50.280
the specific steps of how to do it.

640
00:32:50.280 --> 00:32:52.660
It's not required knowledge for
you to become a CASP,

641
00:32:52.660 --> 00:32:56.230
to take the exam that you no how to do it
in one vendor's platform or the other.

642
00:32:56.230 --> 00:33:00.064
What's required, what's important is the
sense that you understand what the concept

643
00:33:00.064 --> 00:33:03.449
of a legal hold is and why it would be
important with regards to e-discovery.

644
00:33:03.449 --> 00:33:06.910
These kinds of things in other
words become very important.

645
00:33:06.910 --> 00:33:10.070
The other thing that we want to think
about with regards to e-discovery,

646
00:33:10.070 --> 00:33:11.920
with regards to incident response,

647
00:33:11.920 --> 00:33:16.280
is ultimately there's a lot of things that
drive, as we've said, incident response.

648
00:33:16.280 --> 00:33:19.100
It's not just about,
hey, somebody hacked in.

649
00:33:19.100 --> 00:33:21.560
It's not just about, hey,
somebody made a mistake and

650
00:33:21.560 --> 00:33:22.750
did this and they shouldn't have.

651
00:33:22.750 --> 00:33:24.990
It's not just about, hey,
somebody's asking for

652
00:33:24.990 --> 00:33:28.950
our information from outside
the organization, we have to comply.

653
00:33:28.950 --> 00:33:31.340
It's any or all these things
all at the same time, right?

654
00:33:31.340 --> 00:33:32.590
So it could be a data breach.

655
00:33:32.590 --> 00:33:36.292
And a data breach, obviously, clearly,
is a major security incident,

656
00:33:36.292 --> 00:33:40.175
where somebody or a group of somebodies,
either internally or externally,

657
00:33:40.175 --> 00:33:42.049
has broken into one or more systems.

658
00:33:42.049 --> 00:33:45.267
Has essentially acquired
data using malfeasance or

659
00:33:45.267 --> 00:33:47.360
bad actions in order to do so.

660
00:33:47.360 --> 00:33:50.210
They've essentially, in other words,
broken in without rights or permission and

661
00:33:50.210 --> 00:33:54.590
have stolen or acquired data or system
access in order to gain some advantage.

662
00:33:54.590 --> 00:33:56.560
This is what a data breach essentially is,

663
00:33:56.560 --> 00:33:59.500
unauthorized access to one or
more secure systems.

664
00:33:59.500 --> 00:34:02.280
As a cast, we have to obviously
be constantly vigilant.

665
00:34:02.280 --> 00:34:04.890
And we have to worry about responding
to a variety of incidents.

666
00:34:04.890 --> 00:34:07.980
Data breaches obviously are going
to be near the top of that list.

667
00:34:07.980 --> 00:34:11.205
Again, think about all the companies that
you've heard about that have had data

668
00:34:11.205 --> 00:34:13.389
breaches in the last number of days,
weeks, months,

669
00:34:13.389 --> 00:34:14.969
as you're listening to this content.

670
00:34:14.969 --> 00:34:18.499
The others, probably 10, 20,
30 that you could think of or

671
00:34:18.499 --> 00:34:22.420
point to that in the last year have
probably had these concerns come up.

672
00:34:22.420 --> 00:34:26.240
You can think of in prior years
certainly Target, the Heartland breach.

673
00:34:27.250 --> 00:34:32.050
You can think of the VA, the Veterans
Administration has had several stellar

674
00:34:32.050 --> 00:34:34.070
breaches over the last several years.

675
00:34:34.070 --> 00:34:37.228
JP Morgan Chase had a big
issue back in 2015.

676
00:34:37.228 --> 00:34:41.590
The iCloud scandal in 2015 with
pictures being compromised from

677
00:34:41.590 --> 00:34:43.300
all sorts of accounts.

678
00:34:43.300 --> 00:34:45.970
LinkedIn was hacked several
years ago had a big break

679
00:34:45.970 --> 00:34:47.340
with all the usernames and passwords.

680
00:34:47.340 --> 00:34:51.539
I've talked about it, prior episodes and
some of our other shows in other areas.

681
00:34:51.539 --> 00:34:53.138
These are just off the top of my head.

682
00:34:53.138 --> 00:34:54.107
If I really sat down and

683
00:34:54.107 --> 00:34:57.740
thought about a list I could probably come
up with a huge number of them, right?

684
00:34:57.740 --> 00:35:00.190
But the idea is that these things happen,
they happen on a rolling and

685
00:35:00.190 --> 00:35:00.960
regular basis.

686
00:35:00.960 --> 00:35:04.000
And so data breaches are really
something we also have to think about.

687
00:35:04.000 --> 00:35:05.670
We have to think about detection and

688
00:35:05.670 --> 00:35:09.590
collection with regards to
thinking about a data breach.

689
00:35:09.590 --> 00:35:11.190
We have to know the breach occurred,
in other words.

690
00:35:11.190 --> 00:35:13.470
We have to start thinking about
the fact that when it does occur,

691
00:35:13.470 --> 00:35:15.990
we may have to start collecting
information with regards to.

692
00:35:15.990 --> 00:35:17.130
We have to mitigate the breach.

693
00:35:17.130 --> 00:35:21.440
We have to essentially figure out how to
minimize the impact, stop the bleeding,

694
00:35:21.440 --> 00:35:25.170
prevent access, and
then go about our search for answers.

695
00:35:25.170 --> 00:35:29.550
We have to do recovery and/or
reconstitution, essentially reconstruct

696
00:35:29.550 --> 00:35:33.900
what took place, recover the system,
rebuild it, figure out how they broke in.

697
00:35:33.900 --> 00:35:34.950
Figure out what happens, so

698
00:35:34.950 --> 00:35:38.020
we know how essentially to be able
to deal with it going forward.

699
00:35:38.020 --> 00:35:40.100
So these are all steps that
we have to consider and

700
00:35:40.100 --> 00:35:41.500
think about in regards to a data breach.

701
00:35:41.500 --> 00:35:43.090
What about disclosure right?

702
00:35:43.090 --> 00:35:45.550
Disclosure might be a step that
we have to engage in as well.

703
00:35:45.550 --> 00:35:47.590
We may have to tell the system owner or

704
00:35:47.590 --> 00:35:50.600
users that were involved in
the breach that the breach occurred.

705
00:35:50.600 --> 00:35:53.080
And it's not always
required to tell users.

706
00:35:53.080 --> 00:35:57.570
Not always required that we disclose, it's
optional, but it is usually recommended.

707
00:35:57.570 --> 00:35:59.190
Now that may be put on hold for

708
00:35:59.190 --> 00:36:03.250
a while based on senior level management,
based on law enforcement coming in,

709
00:36:03.250 --> 00:36:06.140
depending on the severity of the breach
saying hey we have to investigate.

710
00:36:06.140 --> 00:36:10.010
We don't want you to tell anybody for 30
days or whatever while we're doing that,

711
00:36:10.010 --> 00:36:13.420
we don't want to tip off the bad actors so
we know they're broken in.

712
00:36:13.420 --> 00:36:15.716
But at some once we're done
with our investigation,

713
00:36:15.716 --> 00:36:18.939
yeah we're gonna expect you to go
ahead and essentially alert everybody.

714
00:36:18.939 --> 00:36:21.824
These things are gonna be the kinda
things we have to think about and

715
00:36:21.824 --> 00:36:24.320
be aware of as well with
regards to a data breach.

716
00:36:24.320 --> 00:36:25.490
>> Very good.
All right, Adam again,

717
00:36:25.490 --> 00:36:28.010
a lot of information there
on risk management and

718
00:36:28.010 --> 00:36:32.490
specifically incident response, and
some great demos there as well.

719
00:36:32.490 --> 00:36:34.090
And I think we got more coming up?

720
00:36:34.090 --> 00:36:34.877
>> We do, we do.
>> We do.

721
00:36:34.877 --> 00:36:37.179
>> So we still gotta talk
about chain of custody,

722
00:36:37.179 --> 00:36:39.960
we still gotta talk about
forensic examination.

723
00:36:39.960 --> 00:36:43.410
We still have to talk about how to do
some vulnerability assessment work.

724
00:36:43.410 --> 00:36:46.170
Make sure we understand how to
essentially identify risks.

725
00:36:46.170 --> 00:36:48.140
So, got a lot more coming up.

726
00:36:48.140 --> 00:36:49.170
So stay tuned as they say.

727
00:36:49.170 --> 00:36:50.100
>> Very good, that's right.

728
00:36:50.100 --> 00:36:51.790
Yes, so we have to cut it short here.

729
00:36:51.790 --> 00:36:52.870
Come back for a part two.

730
00:36:52.870 --> 00:36:53.947
So make sure to tune back in.

731
00:36:53.947 --> 00:36:57.487
And remember, if you guys want to
attend one of Adam's classes live,

732
00:36:57.487 --> 00:36:59.889
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

733
00:36:59.889 --> 00:37:01.709
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

734
00:37:01.709 --> 00:37:07.109
>> I am a security assessment professional
who's looking for some e-discovery.

735
00:37:07.109 --> 00:37:08.529
>> [LAUGH] We'll see you next time.

736
00:37:08.529 --> 00:37:10.569
>> Take care everybody.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.040 --> 00:00:10.040
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.444 --> 00:00:15.151
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.151 --> 00:00:16.648
I'm your host Mike Roddick.

4
00:00:16.648 --> 00:00:20.571
Today we are doing our
CompTIA Advance Security Practitioner.

5
00:00:20.571 --> 00:00:24.803
And, specifically, in this episode we
are gonna be focusing in again risk

6
00:00:24.803 --> 00:00:28.040
management, more specifically,
incident response.

7
00:00:28.040 --> 00:00:29.380
Now this is a Part 2, so

8
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:31.730
we've already started the conversation
on incident response.

9
00:00:31.730 --> 00:00:34.500
If you missed that one,
make sure you go back and check it out.

10
00:00:34.500 --> 00:00:37.220
But we'll continue right on and
we'll just jump right back in.

11
00:00:37.220 --> 00:00:40.010
And with me of course is Mr Adam Gordon.

12
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:41.190
How's it going Adam?

13
00:00:41.190 --> 00:00:41.850
>> Good, good.

14
00:00:41.850 --> 00:00:42.593
Very, very good.

15
00:00:42.593 --> 00:00:43.916
So we're gonna pick up where we left off,
all right?

16
00:00:43.916 --> 00:00:48.235
We're gonna talk more about incident
response, chain of custody,

17
00:00:48.235 --> 00:00:49.940
things of that nature.

18
00:00:49.940 --> 00:00:52.636
And what we're gonna do is,
essentially, as Mike said,

19
00:00:52.636 --> 00:00:54.470
go right back to where we left off.

20
00:00:54.470 --> 00:00:57.630
We had been talking at
the last episode about

21
00:00:57.630 --> 00:01:01.270
kind of the overarching thought process
with regards to incident response.

22
00:01:01.270 --> 00:01:04.320
We identified some of the key
things that go on there.

23
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:06.810
We talked about e-discovery
as being very important.

24
00:01:06.810 --> 00:01:10.147
We talked about polices that help
to drive that thought process, and

25
00:01:10.147 --> 00:01:13.090
the kind of things we would have
to do as a cast to be prepared.

26
00:01:13.090 --> 00:01:15.420
We've talked about retention policies.

27
00:01:15.420 --> 00:01:17.210
We talked about data storage.

28
00:01:17.210 --> 00:01:18.820
We talked about data ownership.

29
00:01:18.820 --> 00:01:22.790
We identified all these key criteria
that would have to be in the mind

30
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:25.440
of the cast in order to,
potentially, plan for and

31
00:01:25.440 --> 00:01:27.625
ultimately deal with
the discovery when it occurs.

32
00:01:27.625 --> 00:01:29.015
We also talked about data breaches.

33
00:01:29.015 --> 00:01:31.915
And how data breaches really
become kind of the focal point for

34
00:01:31.915 --> 00:01:33.355
a lot of what we need to contend with.

35
00:01:33.355 --> 00:01:35.615
And how we have to identify
the breach has occurred.

36
00:01:35.615 --> 00:01:38.545
We have to analyze what's
going on with those systems.

37
00:01:38.545 --> 00:01:41.897
And, essentially, understand how
the compromise took place, and

38
00:01:41.897 --> 00:01:46.055
then we have to, essentially, go through
and reconstruct, right, the system, so

39
00:01:46.055 --> 00:01:50.136
we can, essentially, then understand how
to prevent that breach going forward.

40
00:01:50.136 --> 00:01:53.402
We're gonna turn our attention now to
something known as chain of custody.

41
00:01:53.402 --> 00:01:57.153
When we have discovered evidence
of a breach, and we, essentially,

42
00:01:57.153 --> 00:02:00.968
have identified through analysis and
interrogation that there is data

43
00:02:00.968 --> 00:02:04.520
in a system or multiple systems
that may be of interest to us.

44
00:02:04.520 --> 00:02:09.310
What we have to then do, essentially,
is go in and grab that information

45
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:13.220
in a forensically sound way, and
then keep track of that evidence.

46
00:02:13.220 --> 00:02:14.820
So that we can not only present it,

47
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:18.880
potentially, to an investigative
body in a court of law.

48
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:21.310
If we're asked to testify about it,
things of that nature.

49
00:02:21.310 --> 00:02:23.710
We never know for
sure what may or may not happen.

50
00:02:23.710 --> 00:02:26.020
But we also have to have
a record of that evidence.

51
00:02:26.020 --> 00:02:29.250
So that way even if we never show up in
court, even if this never gets beyond

52
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:32.550
the conversation stage
between investigators and

53
00:02:32.550 --> 00:02:35.930
maybe senior management,
we still can validate the evidence and

54
00:02:35.930 --> 00:02:39.360
know beyond any reasonable doubt
that there has been no compromise.

55
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:42.020
Integrity, in other words,
has always been maintained.

56
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:46.368
We've also maintained confidentiality,
if that is an important criteria as well.

57
00:02:46.368 --> 00:02:51.130
And we wanna, obviously, strictly monitor
and control, but allow for availability to

58
00:02:51.130 --> 00:02:54.400
evidence that it's been gathered, but
only under the proper conditions.

59
00:02:54.400 --> 00:02:57.330
And following not just the chain
of custody of evidence, but

60
00:02:57.330 --> 00:02:59.110
the rules of evidence
with regards to handling.

61
00:02:59.110 --> 00:03:01.450
And these are very important things.

62
00:03:01.450 --> 00:03:04.770
Rules of evidence are a little bit
different than chain of custody.

63
00:03:04.770 --> 00:03:08.980
And the chain of custody of evidence is
about making sure that the evidence has

64
00:03:08.980 --> 00:03:14.260
been handled in such a way that we have
authoritative ownership established,

65
00:03:14.260 --> 00:03:17.250
and authoritative access control
being maintained at all times to

66
00:03:17.250 --> 00:03:18.450
validate integrity.

67
00:03:18.450 --> 00:03:22.130
The rules of evidence are the rules that
we follow in order to forensically gather

68
00:03:22.130 --> 00:03:23.910
and ultimately to be
able to examine evidence.

69
00:03:23.910 --> 00:03:26.136
So I want to make sure we
differentiate between the two.

70
00:03:26.136 --> 00:03:29.072
But the chain of custody is, essentially,
the record of evidence handling from

71
00:03:29.072 --> 00:03:31.768
collection all the way through,
potentially, presentation in court.

72
00:03:31.768 --> 00:03:35.857
Or if we never get that far, management of
that information through the life-cycle

73
00:03:35.857 --> 00:03:39.773
while it makes through the investigation,
as I said maybe for senior management

74
00:03:39.773 --> 00:03:43.420
being briefed, whatever it may be,
but that's what chain of custody is.

75
00:03:43.420 --> 00:03:45.049
So we collect evidence.

76
00:03:46.060 --> 00:03:48.410
We ultimately analyze and
store that evidence.

77
00:03:48.410 --> 00:03:50.330
We may or may not present it in court.

78
00:03:50.330 --> 00:03:51.520
We may not get that far.

79
00:03:51.520 --> 00:03:55.140
Or we may simply be briefing somebody
internally, but do understand that, right?

80
00:03:55.140 --> 00:04:00.250
So if we are the security investigator
that has found evidence of wrong doing,

81
00:04:00.250 --> 00:04:03.900
and we've investigated a system,
all that evidence is gathered.

82
00:04:03.900 --> 00:04:06.290
We refer to it as tagging and
bagging it, right?

83
00:04:06.290 --> 00:04:09.520
We're then going to hash
the evidence of its electronics, so

84
00:04:09.520 --> 00:04:12.340
we have an integrity
control associated with it.

85
00:04:12.340 --> 00:04:15.280
So we know the evidence is not
being compromised in any way,

86
00:04:15.280 --> 00:04:16.530
not being modified.

87
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:19.620
We're then gonna have a log,
an evidence log, associated with that,

88
00:04:19.620 --> 00:04:22.040
and we're gonna check
all that evidence in.

89
00:04:22.040 --> 00:04:25.460
And from that point forward,
the evidence custodian, the person that,

90
00:04:25.460 --> 00:04:29.330
essentially, handles that evidence
on site as it is being collected,

91
00:04:29.330 --> 00:04:32.620
gathers that information up,
puts it into separate bags or

92
00:04:32.620 --> 00:04:36.620
uniquely stores that information, whatever
medium may be required to do that.

93
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:39.070
We're talking about a large computer,
we're not gonna, essentially,

94
00:04:39.070 --> 00:04:39.730
bag it, right?

95
00:04:39.730 --> 00:04:43.440
But if we're talking about a USB drive or
something small, we put it in those little

96
00:04:43.440 --> 00:04:48.610
evidence bags like you often see on TV
shows, where they gather up shell casings

97
00:04:48.610 --> 00:04:51.800
or whatever, they drop them into these
little bags or envelopes or whatever.

98
00:04:51.800 --> 00:04:54.600
So we'll do that, or
we'll assign a unique tag and

99
00:04:54.600 --> 00:04:56.560
identifying number to it either way.

100
00:04:56.560 --> 00:05:00.600
And, essentially, store it securely, the
evidence custodian on-site does all that.

101
00:05:00.600 --> 00:05:04.460
And then we transport that evidence
back to a central processing and

102
00:05:04.460 --> 00:05:08.660
facility of some kind, where we can
then safely monitor, maintain it, and

103
00:05:08.660 --> 00:05:11.469
ultimately manage it, use it,
and then we're gonna analyze it.

104

When we analyze it,

00:05:24.290 --> 00:05:28.360
We have to keep an authoritative

00:05:28.360 --> 00:05:31.950

00:05:31.950 --> 00:05:33.640

00:05:33.640 --> 00:05:36.921
From the time it's been gathered,

00:05:36.921 --> 00:05:39.496

00:05:39.496 --> 00:05:42.745
if it's found to no longer be important,

115
00:05:42.745 --> 00:05:47.504
So forensic analysis of compromised system
is really the idea, the art, the science,

00:05:47.504 --> 00:05:52.220

00:05:52.220 --> 00:05:56.231
Information that is going to potentially

00:05:56.231 --> 00:06:00.241

00:06:00.241 --> 00:06:02.380

00:06:02.380 --> 00:06:05.230
So we have to think about

00:06:05.230 --> 00:06:06.830
My computer, for instance, right?

00:06:06.830 --> 00:06:10.940
My laptop or any laptops that Mike and

00:06:10.940 --> 00:06:15.390

00:06:15.390 --> 00:06:17.271

00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:32.300

00:06:57.125 --> 00:07:00.955

00:07:07.425 --> 00:07:10.415

00:07:10.415 --> 00:07:12.100

00:07:14.410 --> 00:07:17.070

00:07:17.070 --> 00:07:19.670

00:07:35.961 --> 00:07:36.946

00:07:36.946 --> 00:07:39.570
Any or all of these information,

00:07:41.130 --> 00:07:44.980

00:07:47.320 --> 00:07:50.392

00:08:22.790 --> 00:08:27.430
So we have to forensically soundly capture

00:08:27.430 --> 00:08:29.010

00:08:51.095 --> 00:08:52.780

00:08:52.780 --> 00:08:55.830

00:08:55.830 --> 00:08:58.720
That's acceptable normally because we

00:08:58.720 --> 00:08:59.410

00:12:23.650 --> 00:12:27.820

00:12:27.820 --> 00:12:32.650
The idea behind this is that a hash
essentially allows us to take any number,

00:12:32.650 --> 00:12:35.200

00:12:35.200 --> 00:12:39.680

00:12:39.680 --> 00:12:42.610

00:12:42.610 --> 00:12:48.363
We run it through a hashing algorithm,
algorithms like MD5, Message-Digest 5 or

257
00:12:48.363 --> 00:12:54.170

or SHA-256, or whatever it may be.

258
00:12:54.170 --> 00:12:58.830
And we then essentially spit out the back
end of that process and integrity

259
00:12:58.830 --> 00:13:03.180
validation or integrity check mechanism,

260
00:13:03.180 --> 00:13:06.630
The hash is not going
to be a representation

261
00:13:06.630 --> 00:13:09.770

262
00:13:09.770 --> 00:13:11.830
All we're doing is trying
to represent the data, so

263
00:13:11.830 --> 00:13:14.750
that way if it changes

00:13:14.750 --> 00:13:16.060
The hash, in other words,

00:13:16.060 --> 00:13:20.430

00:13:20.430 --> 00:13:22.730

00:13:22.730 --> 00:13:29.901
We use SHA-1, we output 160 because

00:13:29.901 --> 00:13:34.035
1 is just short for 160 so

269
00:13:34.035 --> 00:13:37.130
SHA-256 we would output a 256-bit hash.

270
00:13:37.130 --> 00:13:41.380
So the idea is that
the hashing algorithm used,

271
00:13:41.380 --> 00:13:44.950
will dictate the size of the hash
that comes out the back end.

00:13:44.950 --> 00:13:50.490
That hash is an alpha-numeric string,
a letter number combination of 128,

273
00:13:50.490 --> 00:13:54.250

00:13:54.250 --> 00:13:58.010
That string is essentially
an integrity check mechanism.

00:13:58.010 --> 00:14:02.290
Every time we hash that data going

00:14:02.290 --> 00:14:06.200

00:14:06.200 --> 00:14:08.660
In the same order, same number of bytes,

00:14:08.660 --> 00:14:12.700

00:14:12.700 --> 00:14:14.170
If we are able to do that,

00:14:14.170 --> 00:14:17.240
we know that nothing has been

00:14:17.240 --> 00:14:19.910
So we hash all of

00:14:19.910 --> 00:14:22.360

392

393
00:19:33.873 --> 00:19:36.787

00:19:39.087 --> 00:19:42.335

00:19:42.335 --> 00:19:45.737
happening, and what the strengths and

397
00:19:45.737 --> 00:19:46.947
So don't over estimate or

399

400
00:19:54.910 --> 00:19:59.170

405
00:20:11.840 --> 00:20:15.170

00:20:32.660 --> 00:20:35.450

As a security professional who

00:20:50.770 --> 00:20:53.270
to get a feel, for

I go out and I'll research the company.

of investments they make.

And then all I have to do is go ahead and,

00:22:28.330 --> 00:22:32.810
So I've done all my work off-prem

I don't do that, that's not nice, right?

You shouldn't do that.

>> But reverse engineering is very,

When I do audit work, I'll

I can't trust in Michael, though he's

that actually represents

I've gotta validate it.

00:23:16.470 --> 00:23:18.240
So I'm gonna go in and
look at the system and

00:23:39.150 --> 00:23:41.420
So we're gonna look at

480
00:23:41.420 --> 00:23:44.530
We're gonna look at all these

481
00:23:44.530 --> 00:23:47.260
Any good solution that
is implemented properly,

482
00:23:47.260 --> 00:23:51.030
that has a positive ROI associated
with it, has common attributes,

483
00:23:51.030 --> 00:23:54.749
solution attributes, that we talk
about that are very important.

484
00:23:54.749 --> 00:23:56.689
It's gonna have performance available.

485
00:23:56.689 --> 00:24:01.088
We often talk about these being the ITY
attributes, the ITY That's right,

486
00:24:01.088 --> 00:24:03.229
availability capability, right?

487
00:24:03.229 --> 00:24:07.544
Performance is not one of the ITY's but
all the others, availability,

488
00:24:07.544 --> 00:24:11.740
capability, capacity,
scalability, usability, latency.

489
00:24:11.740 --> 00:24:13.490
We're gonna measure all these things.

490
00:24:13.490 --> 00:24:17.140
Maintainability, recoverability,
manageability, these are the all

491
00:24:17.140 --> 00:24:22.270
attributes the good solutions with
positive ROI have associated with them.

492
00:24:22.270 --> 00:24:26.000
And we have to be aware of these things

493
00:24:26.000 --> 00:24:27.610
that we can measure quantitatively and

494
00:24:27.610 --> 00:24:32.320
assign a value to as part of a ROI

00:24:32.320 --> 00:24:37.490
If the ROI on a system is positive but

496
00:24:37.490 --> 00:24:42.540

497
00:24:42.540 --> 00:24:44.940
That it may not make sense

498
00:24:44.940 --> 00:24:47.470
That's something we have to think about,

499
00:24:47.470 --> 00:24:50.730
Maybe it's incredibly tough to
essentially set the system up.

500
00:24:50.730 --> 00:24:53.710
Maybe it's very expensive,
very time consuming, who knows?

501
00:24:53.710 --> 00:24:55.530
That's gonna impact, the ROI and

502
00:24:55.530 --> 00:24:58.360
those two things really have to be
taken into account, ultimately.

503
00:24:58.360 --> 00:25:01.200
So all these solution attributes

504
00:25:01.200 --> 00:25:03.890

00:25:08.430 --> 00:25:12.010

00:25:12.010 --> 00:25:17.730

00:25:17.730 --> 00:25:19.520
You hear it referred to different ways,

00:25:19.520 --> 00:25:23.810
essentially all those terms together

00:25:23.810 --> 00:25:26.930
And what we learn from an experience and

00:25:26.930 --> 00:25:31.270

If we use this as a practical

I, with regards to setting and

All of our time together right?

And shame on us if we don't right?

So we're constantly providing lessons

Cuz we're giving you all these valuable

For you to be able to learn and

That's the ongoing benefit of the ROI,

00:32:30.330 --> 00:32:34.139
If you do these stakes and you do them
regularly and when I say, regularly,

648
00:32:34.139 --> 00:32:35.418
I don't mean every day.

649
00:32:35.418 --> 00:32:37.176
This is not.
I mean, you could do it every day.

650
00:32:37.176 --> 00:32:39.654
Don't get me wrong, but it's not
something you have to do every day,

651
00:32:39.654 --> 00:32:41.256
because you're not under attack every day.

652
00:32:41.256 --> 00:32:43.016
You can take this to the extreme.

653
00:32:43.016 --> 00:32:46.816
You can become that person who runs around
saying, my God, the sky is falling.

654
00:32:46.816 --> 00:32:48.376
But the reality is, it's not falling.

655
00:32:48.376 --> 00:32:50.861
And if it does fall,
chances are good it's gonna kill you and

656
00:32:50.861 --> 00:32:52.096
you're not gonna be around.

657
00:32:52.096 --> 00:32:53.256
So, it doesn't matter.

658
00:32:53.256 --> 00:32:54.174
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

659
00:32:54.174 --> 00:32:55.216
you don't have to get that stressed out.

660
00:32:55.216 --> 00:32:58.336
What you need to do is think about
the fact that every so often.

661
00:32:58.336 --> 00:33:04.176
Once a week, once a month,
once a quarter, twice a year.

662
00:33:04.176 --> 00:33:06.736
I wouldn't do it twice a year, probably
do it a little more frequently than that.

663
00:33:06.736 --> 00:33:10.856
So maybe it's once every couple of weeks,
you should look at that infrastructure.

664
00:33:10.856 --> 00:33:14.849
Somebody who understands the issues and
the concerns when they arise thee should

665
00:33:14.849 --> 00:33:17.560
essentially go out and
dry run that as an average user.

666
00:33:17.560 --> 00:33:20.152
If you do that and
you find out everything is good,

667
00:33:20.152 --> 00:33:23.508
hey, you've validated your
protection systems are in place.

668
00:33:23.508 --> 00:33:26.140
Your users are secure and
we're happy with that.

669
00:33:27.424 --> 00:33:30.309
Just wanna make sure that
we're thinking as CASPS,

670
00:33:30.309 --> 00:33:32.218
as being as proactive as we can be.

671
00:33:32.218 --> 00:33:35.827
I often talk about planning to succeed or
planning to fail and

672
00:33:35.827 --> 00:33:40.380
planning to succeed involves you being
forward thinking, and proactive.

673
00:33:40.380 --> 00:33:42.006
So things like collaboration sites,

674
00:33:42.006 --> 00:33:45.678
we've talked about some of these under the
guise of enterprise content management.

675
00:33:45.678 --> 00:33:48.295
Things such as SharePoint,
things such as WebSphere.

676
00:33:48.295 --> 00:33:52.407
These kind of file sharing and
collaboration platforms that integrate

677
00:33:52.407 --> 00:33:57.134
presents, integrate data, integrate the
ability to see a lot of different stuff

678
00:33:57.134 --> 00:33:59.615
are also great collaboration solutions.

679
00:33:59.615 --> 00:34:03.137
But we have to think about the fact
that they also may provide,

680
00:34:03.137 --> 00:34:04.507
if we're not careful.

681
00:34:04.507 --> 00:34:09.246
The ability for somebody to insecurely
communicate, to insecurely collaborate

682
00:34:09.246 --> 00:34:13.855
and, or to tear down all the great work
we've done from a security standpoint.

683
00:34:13.855 --> 00:34:17.087
Just by one or two clicks of
the mouse without thinking about it.

684
00:34:17.087 --> 00:34:18.887
I'll leave you with this thought
before we wrap up this conversation.

685
00:34:18.887 --> 00:34:23.206
So I've a lot of customers that implement
these kind of systems, ECM systems, but

686
00:34:23.206 --> 00:34:27.032
I have one in particular that has
implemented SharePoint and is looking to

687
00:34:27.032 --> 00:34:30.940
be able to do a variety of really
interesting, really cool things with it.

688
00:34:30.940 --> 00:34:34.285
One of the things they wanna be able to
do is they're gonna integrate Yammer,

689
00:34:34.285 --> 00:34:37.887
which is the social networking aspect of
the platform and they're gonna integrate

690
00:34:37.887 --> 00:34:40.778
OneDrive on the back-end to do storage,
OneDrive for business.

691
00:34:40.778 --> 00:34:44.410
So they're doing all this, it's gonna
be cloud-based, gonna do private cloud.

692
00:34:44.410 --> 00:34:46.348
Really cool concept,
setting up the architecture for them.

693
00:34:46.348 --> 00:34:49.120
It's gonna be a really neat solution.

694
00:34:49.120 --> 00:34:52.398
The challenge we're having right now and
that they're asking me in particular,

695
00:34:52.398 --> 00:34:54.118
to think about and address is governance.

696
00:34:54.118 --> 00:34:56.920
GRC in particular, governance,
risk and compliance.

697
00:34:56.920 --> 00:35:00.880
How do they train their users to be able
to understand the culture of security to

698
00:35:00.880 --> 00:35:02.990
communicate and collaborate securely?

699
00:35:02.990 --> 00:35:07.818
How do they implement government systems
that will force policy, procedure and

700
00:35:07.818 --> 00:35:10.942
process to not only be created,
but to be created and

701
00:35:10.942 --> 00:35:13.570
standardized across their organization?

702
00:35:13.570 --> 00:35:15.560
It's a global company.

703
00:35:15.560 --> 00:35:17.468
So, they've got infrastructure
all over the place.

704
00:35:17.468 --> 00:35:21.177
They've got different lines of business
and they understand that they have to

705
00:35:21.177 --> 00:35:24.603
standardize those approaches to risk
management in order to be able to,

706
00:35:24.603 --> 00:35:26.640
essentially do this the right way.

707
00:35:26.640 --> 00:35:29.248
And so, this is another big
challenge we have as CASPS.

708
00:35:29.248 --> 00:35:33.341
When we're dealing with large
infrastructure, multiple users, different

709
00:35:33.341 --> 00:35:37.496
geographies can we come up with a plan
that, essentially creates standardized

710
00:35:37.496 --> 00:35:41.790
solutions or do we have to essentially
create a series of one-off transactions.

711
00:35:41.790 --> 00:35:44.509
Because if we're managing secure
collaboration as a single

712
00:35:44.509 --> 00:35:47.238
instance event over and over and
over again, I promise you.

713
00:35:47.238 --> 00:35:50.902
It's not gonna be secure and it's not
gonna work out at the end of the day,

714
00:35:50.902 --> 00:35:54.890
and you can't run a network, and run it
securely, and manage it based on luck.

715
00:35:54.890 --> 00:35:57.228
I mean, you can, but
it just doesn't hold out long-term.

716
00:35:57.228 --> 00:35:59.580
If it does,
you should have won the lottery already.

717
00:35:59.580 --> 00:36:00.160
You shouldn't be listening to me.

718
00:36:00.160 --> 00:36:01.965
>> [LAUGH]
>> You should be retired somewhere

719
00:36:01.965 --> 00:36:02.538
on that island.

720
00:36:02.538 --> 00:36:05.803
That Mike was talking about in the
beginning, you should have bought it by

721
00:36:05.803 --> 00:36:09.240
now actually and you should own it and
then you could tell us what we should do.

722
00:36:09.240 --> 00:36:13.210
But the reality is it doesn't work not
long term, it's not a good strategy.

723
00:36:13.210 --> 00:36:17.829
So, what we know we need to do is come
up the ways standardize the implication

724
00:36:17.829 --> 00:36:22.970
solution and create a culture of security
where everybody collaborates securely.

725
00:36:22.970 --> 00:36:25.138
Security awareness is
the order of the day and

726
00:36:25.138 --> 00:36:29.960
this is how we drive secure communication,
and collaboration through the enterprise.

727
00:36:29.960 --> 00:36:30.668
>> Very good, Adam.

728
00:36:30.668 --> 00:36:35.150
Lots of great information, great info,
great examples and we saw a little lab.

729
00:36:35.150 --> 00:36:35.890
We got to setup some IP signals.

730
00:36:35.890 --> 00:36:37.650
>> It was actually all about the island.

731
00:36:37.650 --> 00:36:38.700
If it wasn't for the island,

732
00:36:38.700 --> 00:36:40.850
I couldn't have even thought
about doing a better job that.

733
00:36:40.850 --> 00:36:42.540
>> It did carry the whole episode.

734
00:36:42.540 --> 00:36:44.840
>> It did.
It set the theme for everything.

735
00:36:44.840 --> 00:36:47.140
>> [LAUGH] Well, ladies and gentlemen,
we hope you enjoyed that episode.

736
00:36:47.140 --> 00:36:49.518
We've got more coming your way,
so stay tuned.

737
00:36:49.518 --> 00:36:52.885
Remember, if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

738
00:36:52.885 --> 00:36:55.520
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

739
00:36:55.520 --> 00:36:57.000
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

740
00:36:57.000 --> 00:36:59.678
>> We should get some ukulele
music in the background.

741
00:36:59.678 --> 00:37:02.208
Tiny bubbles, little island theme,
maybe some grass skits.

742
00:37:02.208 --> 00:37:03.013
>> Yeah.

743
00:37:03.013 --> 00:37:06.344
>> I'm gonna go find a hammock and
we'll see you later.

744
00:37:06.344 --> 00:37:08.798
[LAUGH]
