WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.530 --> 00:00:15.968
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.968 --> 00:00:17.518
I'm your host Mike Roderick, and

4
00:00:17.518 --> 00:00:20.970
today we're doing our
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner.

5
00:00:20.970 --> 00:00:23.470
And specifically in this episode
we are going to be continuing on

6
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:27.610
in our thought process of securing
our communications and collaboration.

7
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:32.840
And we have talked a lot about different
ways that we are going to be communicating

8
00:00:32.840 --> 00:00:35.560
within organizations,
between other organizations.

9
00:00:35.560 --> 00:00:38.290
We have got to look at some of
the devices that we might be using.

10
00:00:38.290 --> 00:00:40.330
Especially mobile devices now-a-days.

11
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:43.220
We also want to take a look at some of
the authentication methods that we use

12
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:45.160
that initiate those communications.

13
00:00:45.160 --> 00:00:47.290
So here to help with that,
is Mr. Adam Gordon.

14
00:00:47.290 --> 00:00:48.160
How's it going Adam?

15
00:00:48.160 --> 00:00:48.740
>> Good, good.

16
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:50.682
I'm feeling very mobile this morning.

17
00:00:50.682 --> 00:00:51.405
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

18
00:00:51.405 --> 00:00:54.199
thinking we need some
management of that mobility so

19
00:00:54.199 --> 00:00:58.262
we're going to jump in and continue
talking about secure collaboration and

20
00:00:58.262 --> 00:01:02.131
start talking about the ways in which
we can take our ideas about how we can

21
00:01:02.131 --> 00:01:06.576
communicate securely, how we can manage
that communication process securely and

22
00:01:06.576 --> 00:01:08.650
just broaden that a little bit right.

23
00:01:08.650 --> 00:01:13.520
We've talked a lot about the idea that
we need governance risk and compliance.

24
00:01:13.520 --> 00:01:18.535
Talked about policy procedure process
as being tangible elements of GRC.

25
00:01:18.535 --> 00:01:21.040
We've talked about business
requirements and alignment with that.

26
00:01:21.040 --> 00:01:23.120
Talked about risk awareness.

27
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:27.540
Talked about the need to be able to
anticipate user behavior and plan for

28
00:01:27.540 --> 00:01:29.380
the unexpected and plan to be successful.

29
00:01:29.380 --> 00:01:31.700
When we think about
mobile device management,

30
00:01:31.700 --> 00:01:37.500
we think about traditionally right
something such as this, my old Trustee.

31
00:01:37.500 --> 00:01:38.595
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right.

32
00:01:38.595 --> 00:01:39.187
>> Blackberry, right?

33
00:01:39.187 --> 00:01:39.695
>> Blackberry.

34
00:01:39.695 --> 00:01:40.875
>> So we think about something like this.

35
00:01:40.875 --> 00:01:45.295
We maybe thinking about
a laptop device of some kind.

36
00:01:45.295 --> 00:01:47.335
We maybe thinking about a tablet.

37
00:01:47.335 --> 00:01:50.367
We maybe thinking about
lots of different ways that

38
00:01:50.367 --> 00:01:54.547
people are gonna consume information that
are out beyond the border, logically and

39
00:01:54.547 --> 00:01:57.287
physically, of the policy and

40
00:01:57.287 --> 00:02:02.697
control mechanisms that we put in place to
manage fixed assets, desktops and servers.

41
00:02:02.697 --> 00:02:05.047
I see this happening all the time.

42
00:02:05.047 --> 00:02:06.237
I see it more and more.

43
00:02:06.237 --> 00:02:07.887
It's obviously clearly becoming a trend.

44
00:02:07.887 --> 00:02:09.537
And I don't think it's just Starbucks.

45
00:02:09.537 --> 00:02:11.217
But I think it's in general
anywhere you go and

46
00:02:11.217 --> 00:02:13.940
probably find wireless where
there's a parking lot.

47
00:02:13.940 --> 00:02:15.360
But I see more and more people,

48
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:18.260
I saw it this morning when I was
at Starbucks getting coffee before

49
00:02:18.260 --> 00:02:23.060
we got started, sitting in the parking in
front of Starbucks or in front of areas

50
00:02:23.060 --> 00:02:27.900
that have wireless that's open and they're
in their car working on laptops, right?

51
00:02:27.900 --> 00:02:30.850
I'm sure it's sales people,
I'm sure it's a variety of people.

52
00:02:30.850 --> 00:02:32.300
But I see people sitting there.

53
00:02:32.300 --> 00:02:35.855
I saw two girls this morning sitting in
separate cars on either side of me when I

54
00:02:35.855 --> 00:02:39.610
parked with laptops propped up on
the steering wheel, actually working.

55
00:02:39.610 --> 00:02:43.335
Using clearly, I'm sure, the wireless
coming out from the store front.

56
00:02:43.335 --> 00:02:46.215
And they were actually,
one was on the phone doing something.

57
00:02:46.215 --> 00:02:47.816
The other was heads down.

58
00:02:47.816 --> 00:02:49.453
Thankfully they weren't driving
while they were doing this.

59
00:02:49.453 --> 00:02:51.009
The good thing is they parked.

60
00:02:51.009 --> 00:02:52.448
We like that.

61
00:02:52.448 --> 00:02:54.095
There are a few of those.

62
00:02:54.095 --> 00:02:57.315
But heads down on the laptop
actually doing work,

63
00:02:57.315 --> 00:03:00.905
and I think to myself when
I see this more and more.

64
00:03:00.905 --> 00:03:03.610
Mobile device management and

65
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:08.620
the use of over-the-air technologies
to be able to essentially

66
00:03:08.620 --> 00:03:13.460
communicate back to the corporate entity,
and to access information remotely.

67
00:03:13.460 --> 00:03:19.120
This is not new, we've had telecommuters,
we've had VPN-based mobile access for

68
00:03:19.120 --> 00:03:22.890
secure remote connections back into
a corporate entity for some time.

69
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:27.410
This should not be new by any means,
but taking that to the next level and

70
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:29.850
literally, being able to
sit just about anywhere and

71
00:03:29.850 --> 00:03:32.890
be able to access,
not the corporate network securely.

72
00:03:32.890 --> 00:03:36.290
That's not the part that really
bothers me when I see this.

73
00:03:36.290 --> 00:03:39.051
It's the network that we're on,
the carrier network,

74
00:03:39.051 --> 00:03:42.515
the wireless network that's Starbucks or
a McDonald's or Denny's.

75
00:03:42.515 --> 00:03:44.365
Or, I don't know.
Whoever or whatever it is, right?

76
00:03:44.365 --> 00:03:46.265
Pick any restaurant you go to today.

77
00:03:46.265 --> 00:03:48.305
Most of them probably have wireless,
right?

78
00:03:48.305 --> 00:03:50.015
So it's not just these vendors.

79
00:03:50.015 --> 00:03:52.975
It's any vendor that provides
a wireless communication network.

80
00:03:52.975 --> 00:03:54.778
You're essentially on a guest network,
right?

81
00:03:54.778 --> 00:03:55.996
It's wide open.

82
00:03:55.996 --> 00:03:58.225
You're at a hotel, it's the same thing.

83
00:03:58.225 --> 00:04:01.765
You don't know who's on that network and
you don't know what they're doing.

84
00:04:01.765 --> 00:04:05.900
I was sitting at the hotel last night and
as you know,

85
00:04:05.900 --> 00:04:09.430
I was taking care of the other
thing that I'm here right to do.

86
00:04:09.430 --> 00:04:13.100
And so as a result I had to
do a little network scanning.

87
00:04:13.100 --> 00:04:15.640
And so when I was doing some network
scanning on the wireless network at

88
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:19.570
the hotel, just to see essentially to
create a screen capture something.

89
00:04:19.570 --> 00:04:22.190
So I could document something for
somebody.

90
00:04:22.190 --> 00:04:25.580
I just ran Angry IP Scanner
just to see what was out there.

91
00:04:25.580 --> 00:04:28.530
Figured out the subnet that
they had me on wirelessly and

92
00:04:28.530 --> 00:04:30.688
it ran and it went almost all
the way through and there's nothing.

93
00:04:30.688 --> 00:04:33.010
I think well I can't be the only
person on the wireless network.

94
00:04:33.010 --> 00:04:33.850
That's kind of odd.

95
00:04:33.850 --> 00:04:34.720
And then I finish this up and

96
00:04:34.720 --> 00:04:39.850
all of a sudden I see about 20 devices pop
in and again, it's common sense stuff.

97
00:04:39.850 --> 00:04:43.430
But I see, not just IP addresses,
but a lot of them are names.

98
00:04:43.430 --> 00:04:45.220
So I see Jenny's iPad.

99
00:04:45.220 --> 00:04:48.390
I see Sam's tablet.

100
00:04:48.390 --> 00:04:52.450
And again I don't know who Jenny is and
I don't care right?

101
00:04:52.450 --> 00:04:53.300
This is what I do for

102
00:04:53.300 --> 00:04:57.990
a living but just my point is, when I see
that I'm thinking to myself, number one,

103
00:04:57.990 --> 00:05:02.390
if I really wanted to find out who she
was, how hard would it be right to start

104
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:07.010
asking questions downstairs and figure
out who Jenny is and what room she's in.

105
00:05:07.010 --> 00:05:10.880
I mean we give away so much information
today when we connect on these

106
00:05:10.880 --> 00:05:14.940
public networks without thinking about it,
and this is what mobile device management

107
00:05:14.940 --> 00:05:17.760
to me is really all about
as a security professional.

108
00:05:17.760 --> 00:05:22.620
Are we as CASPS safeguarding,
securing, and providing guidance

109
00:05:22.620 --> 00:05:27.790
to our users that allows them to
operate securely when we're not around?

110
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:31.850
Are we implementing policies that
mandate that we don't use machine names

111
00:05:31.850 --> 00:05:33.350
that give away our identity?

112
00:05:33.350 --> 00:05:36.617
We use anonymous IP addresses
right that can be NAT'd,

113
00:05:36.617 --> 00:05:40.246
that can essentially just mean
nothing in the outside world.

114
00:05:40.246 --> 00:05:44.230
Are we making sure that everybody
has a firewall installed and

115
00:05:44.230 --> 00:05:48.606
running on their device that is
configured to provide protection?

116
00:05:48.606 --> 00:05:52.920
Are we ensuring, again through policy,
through process, through procedure,

117
00:05:52.920 --> 00:05:56.482
are we ensuring that the user
understands how to connect securely,

118
00:05:56.482 --> 00:05:59.470
even though they're using
an insecure network?

119
00:05:59.470 --> 00:06:01.630
Because when I right-click and
Angry IP Scanner and

120
00:06:01.630 --> 00:06:05.740
I connect to some of these devices,
I can get into them.

121
00:06:05.740 --> 00:06:07.230
That's the scary part, right.

122
00:06:07.230 --> 00:06:09.190
I don't want to see what
you're doing on your iPad but

123
00:06:09.190 --> 00:06:10.820
I can connect to it with no trouble.

124
00:06:10.820 --> 00:06:14.870
So the problem becomes that you may
be just going about your business,

125
00:06:14.870 --> 00:06:17.790
looking at Netflix or
whatever you do, right.

126
00:06:17.790 --> 00:06:20.150
And I'm there right along with
you without your knowledge,

127
00:06:20.150 --> 00:06:21.590
taking a look at what you're looking at.

128
00:06:21.590 --> 00:06:23.730
You're shopping,
I can go buy something for myself.

129
00:06:23.730 --> 00:06:25.930
I can get your credit card information,
right?

00:05:04.110 --> 00:05:08.630

00:05:12.330 --> 00:05:13.160

00:05:13.160 --> 00:05:14.910
What you have,

00:05:27.610 --> 00:05:29.840

110
00:05:29.840 --> 00:05:35.095
But we also may provide with that,

114
00:05:45.515 --> 00:05:48.485
However we do that, ultimately
what's gonna happen is we're gonna

115

pass those credentials onto the radius

116
00:05:53.265 --> 00:05:56.742
The radius server takes that,

117
00:05:56.742 --> 00:05:59.289

118
00:05:59.289 --> 00:06:03.160

120
00:06:04.070 --> 00:06:07.330
If not, hey, let's get them out of here,

121
00:06:07.330 --> 00:06:10.670

the authorization stage, if the answer to

122
00:06:10.670 --> 00:06:15.770

123
00:06:15.770 --> 00:06:19.350
We're essentially gonna assign

124
00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:21.970
that request inbound will

125
00:06:21.970 --> 00:06:25.695
And then the radius server will
essentially go back to the external client

126
00:06:25.695 --> 00:06:30.094
and say okay, you're allowed in, and this
is what essentially you're able to go do.

127
00:06:30.094 --> 00:06:31.970
But then the radius server

128
00:06:31.970 --> 00:06:35.580
It does what's called triple A, so
we just covered two of the As, right?

129
00:06:35.580 --> 00:06:38.390
We did the authentication and

130
00:06:38.390 --> 00:06:41.160
The third A is audit, or essentially,

131
00:06:41.160 --> 00:06:46.650

all the transactions that take place so

132
00:06:46.650 --> 00:06:49.448

133
00:06:49.448 --> 00:06:52.240
So we're gonna provide what's
known as triple A capability

134
00:06:52.240 --> 00:06:54.010
when we use a radius solution.

135
00:06:54.010 --> 00:06:57.910
The last part is equal
importance to the other two, but

136
00:06:57.910 --> 00:07:02.270
it's actually more important when we are
dealing with looking at connections and

137
00:07:02.270 --> 00:07:05.900

138
00:07:05.900 --> 00:07:08.910

logged the transactional data

00:07:08.910 --> 00:07:10.970

00:07:10.970 --> 00:07:12.660

Under what credential or

144
00:07:19.980 --> 00:07:23.230
We keep track of a lot of information,

145
00:07:23.230 --> 00:07:26.340
So this is essentially a log
of all inbound connectivity

146
00:07:26.340 --> 00:07:27.820

confidentiality mechanisms involved
with a technology like RADIUS.

634
00:32:26.510 --> 00:32:29.870
Password authentication protocol
as known as PAP was in there.

635
00:32:29.870 --> 00:32:32.890
This essentially sends you RADIUS and
passwords in the clear.

636
00:32:32.890 --> 00:32:35.460
It's real old school, very old technology.

637
00:32:35.460 --> 00:32:37.080
Not really used much anymore.

638
00:32:37.080 --> 00:32:39.140
This protocol is very insecure.

639
00:32:39.140 --> 00:32:41.690
It does still exists as
an option in most systems, but

640
00:32:41.690 --> 00:32:43.180
should really never be chosen.

641
00:32:43.180 --> 00:32:46.390
It's much like CalNet, it's there just
because nobody's finally decided to get

642
00:32:46.390 --> 00:32:50.020
around to getting rid of it and just
sticking it in the get done column and

643
00:32:50.020 --> 00:32:51.220
deleting it totally.

644
00:32:51.220 --> 00:32:54.100
So it still exists,
providers shouldn't really use it.

645
00:32:54.100 --> 00:32:57.050
That's password authentication
protocol was an option there.

646
00:32:57.050 --> 00:33:00.160
Challenge handshake authentication
protocol, what's known as CHAP,

647
00:33:00.160 --> 00:33:03.970
not to be confused with Microsoft's
proprietary implementation of CHAP.

648
00:33:03.970 --> 00:33:09.940
We'll just call it MS chap and or MS chap
v2, but chap is the industry standard or

649
00:33:09.940 --> 00:33:13.320
generic version that Microsoft
eventually plays off of and

650
00:33:13.320 --> 00:33:15.342
implements for their own ends.

651
00:33:15.342 --> 00:33:20.150
This is an authentication
protocol that encrypts

652
00:33:20.150 --> 00:33:23.800
the the authentication traffic, so the
username and the password is encrypted.

653
00:33:23.800 --> 00:33:27.090
We send essentially a hash of
the information back and forth

654
00:33:27.090 --> 00:33:31.320
to represent it and we compare the hash
essentially to understand what's going on.

655
00:33:31.320 --> 00:33:32.720
So we wanna make sure we're aware of that.

656
00:33:32.720 --> 00:33:37.640
We often use MD5 the hashing algorithm
we spoke about which will produce a,

657
00:33:37.640 --> 00:33:39.280
anybody, anybody out there?

658
00:33:39.280 --> 00:33:40.350
Flash a number up on the screen.

659
00:33:40.350 --> 00:33:42.470
How big is the hash string for MD5?

660
00:33:42.470 --> 00:33:46.780
I know Mike's dying to say it's gonna be,
are you gonna do it in finger code there?

661
00:33:46.780 --> 00:33:48.184
>> I'm trying to give them the secret so
they can answer you.

662
00:33:48.184 --> 00:33:49.984
[LAUGH]
>> Can you do 128 with just fingers,

663
00:33:49.984 --> 00:33:50.722
without toes?

664
00:33:50.722 --> 00:33:52.432
I don't know, right.
>> Let's see, one, two, eight.

665
00:33:52.432 --> 00:33:55.412
>> There we go, so
128 bits, right for MD5.

666
00:33:55.412 --> 00:33:59.058
So we'll see that, so please make sure
that that is at least something you're

667
00:33:59.058 --> 00:34:01.118
aware of when you associate MV5 with chat.

668
00:34:01.118 --> 00:34:03.671
But also understand that MV5 today,

669
00:34:03.671 --> 00:34:09.590
is not necessarily considered to be the
most secure hashing algorithm we can use.

670
00:34:09.590 --> 00:34:12.206
Not because we're worried
about confidentiality, but

671
00:34:12.206 --> 00:34:14.558
because it is going to
provide a much smaller hash.

672
00:34:14.558 --> 00:34:18.511
And we may want larger hash outputs
because we want to be able to provide

673
00:34:18.511 --> 00:34:20.528
a higher level of integrity check.

674
00:34:20.528 --> 00:34:22.576
A higher level of the authenticity there.

675
00:34:22.576 --> 00:34:26.520
So maybe shy 160,
shy 256 whatever it may be.

676
00:34:26.520 --> 00:34:27.800
So just be aware of that.

677
00:34:27.800 --> 00:34:30.910
Extensible authentication protocol
what we talked about is EAP or

678
00:34:30.910 --> 00:34:33.050
Microsoft's implementation of it.

679
00:34:33.050 --> 00:34:38.010
Also Cisco's implementation of it because
Cisco, Microsoft and RS they partnered

680
00:34:38.010 --> 00:34:42.980
with a lot of other companies to
essentially provide a alternate to EAP,

681
00:34:42.980 --> 00:34:46.850
which is known as PEAP, protected
extensible authentication protocol.

682
00:34:46.850 --> 00:34:48.460
They all implement that jointly.

683
00:34:48.460 --> 00:34:51.370
And then Cisco went out and created
their own because it wasn't good enough

684
00:34:51.370 --> 00:34:54.201
to partner, they had to have their
own cuz that's how they are.

685
00:34:54.201 --> 00:34:54.838
>> [LAUGH] Of course.

686
00:34:54.838 --> 00:34:56.465
>> And as a result,
they created something known as LEAP.

687
00:34:56.465 --> 00:34:59.875
Which is lightweight extensible
authentication protocol, right.

688
00:34:59.875 --> 00:35:02.335
I'm waiting for
LEAP part two, which will be.

689
00:35:02.335 --> 00:35:04.447
[LAUGH] We have all
these different options.

690
00:35:04.447 --> 00:35:05.020
>> Or PREAP.

691
00:35:05.020 --> 00:35:07.930
>> Or CREAP, right, or
something like that.

692
00:35:07.930 --> 00:35:10.930
So EAP, we have PEAP, the protected
extensible authentication protocol,

693
00:35:10.930 --> 00:35:13.680
also LEAP, lightweight extensible
authentication protocol.

694
00:35:13.680 --> 00:35:16.520
These are all going to be used,
you saw them in RADIUS.

695
00:35:16.520 --> 00:35:19.610
We've seen them in different
implementations we look at.

696
00:35:19.610 --> 00:35:25.310
We saw some of them in IPsec,
we saw EAP and protected EAP as an option

697
00:35:25.310 --> 00:35:30.840
with IPsec specifically, because Microsoft
does implement both EAP and protected EAP.

698
00:35:30.840 --> 00:35:34.940
So just be aware of the fact that these
are going to allow us to again, provide

699
00:35:34.940 --> 00:35:39.480
user credentials and to do so in a secure
way as part of a RADIUS implementation.

700
00:35:39.480 --> 00:35:41.510
So we just wanna make sure
we're aware of those.

701
00:35:41.510 --> 00:35:44.470
Also, quickly just wanna talk about
some other options that RADIUS

702
00:35:44.470 --> 00:35:46.162
has morphed into over time.

703
00:35:46.162 --> 00:35:48.540
RADIUS as I said is kinda
older school technology.

704
00:35:48.540 --> 00:35:52.410
We still use it and we still
generically use the concept of RADIUS

705
00:35:52.410 --> 00:35:56.040
although RADIUS itself is really
just a acronym for technology.

706
00:35:56.040 --> 00:35:58.690
It also happens to be a brand
name in some cases right?

707
00:35:58.690 --> 00:35:59.820
But generically it's an idea.

708
00:36:00.900 --> 00:36:02.970
There are newer implementations of RADIUS.

709
00:36:02.970 --> 00:36:04.780
Some have been more popular than others.

710
00:36:04.780 --> 00:36:08.990
One of the key issues of RADIUS was that
it was not necessarily going to provide

711
00:36:08.990 --> 00:36:12.030
some of the most secure
elements that we need.

712
00:36:12.030 --> 00:36:15.800
So for instance if we were to implement
RADIUS using PAP, the username and

713
00:36:15.800 --> 00:36:18.770
password authentication challenges
would be sent in the clear.

714
00:36:18.770 --> 00:36:21.000
And that's unacceptable
by today's standards.

715
00:36:21.000 --> 00:36:24.790
So we may look at something like Diameter,
which is a newer implementation for

716
00:36:24.790 --> 00:36:25.550
RADIUS.

717
00:36:25.550 --> 00:36:26.840
It is more secure.

718
00:36:26.840 --> 00:36:28.873
It has a failover mechanism so

719
00:36:28.873 --> 00:36:33.928
that way it uses TCP based solutions
that allow us to provide redundancy.

720
00:36:33.928 --> 00:36:37.590
So that way, if RADIUS stops working,
essentially you can't get in.

721
00:36:37.590 --> 00:36:41.414
With the Diameter solution we
essentially can use TCP or UDP's so

722
00:36:41.414 --> 00:36:46.018
we can create connection oriented or
connectionless transmissions of data.

723
00:36:46.018 --> 00:36:49.049
And as a result we can validate that
the data is actually achieving its end

724
00:36:49.049 --> 00:36:50.850
result and
getting to where it needs to be.

725
00:36:50.850 --> 00:36:55.380
It can also provide failover tolerance so
we can stack these systems up essentially

726
00:36:55.380 --> 00:36:59.520
and create a highly available Cluster
if you will to be able to implement So

727
00:36:59.520 --> 00:37:00.760
we have different options there.

728
00:37:00.760 --> 00:37:02.730
Diameter never became really popular.

729
00:37:02.730 --> 00:37:04.540
It was European centric.

730
00:37:04.540 --> 00:37:07.840
Updates your RADIUS and was never
really widely deployed or implemented.

731
00:37:07.840 --> 00:37:11.235
It was more of a theoretical
construct than anything else.

732
00:37:11.235 --> 00:37:15.635
We have NPS, Network Policy Server, as I
said, that's Microsoft's implementation of

733
00:37:15.635 --> 00:37:19.455
RADIUS, along with NAP, which is
the network access protection solution.

734
00:37:19.455 --> 00:37:23.005
Which uses RADIUS in combination with NPS,
to essentially evaluate.

735
00:37:23.005 --> 00:37:27.890
And then we also have TACACS, and TACACS+,
which are additional implementations

736
00:37:27.890 --> 00:37:32.498
of RADIUS, that have been updated over
time to achieve additional results, or

737
00:37:32.498 --> 00:37:36.868
deal with additional concerns, and
validate additional, technology.

738
00:37:36.868 --> 00:37:40.200
Essentially gaps that were in
the technology implementation with RADIUS.

739
00:37:40.200 --> 00:37:42.760
You may see RADIUS, in other words,
in one or more forms.

740
00:37:42.760 --> 00:37:44.690
You just want to understand
that RADIUS itself,

741
00:37:44.690 --> 00:37:49.060
generically, is really this
this idea of how we can do AAA.

742
00:37:49.060 --> 00:37:51.000
We may implement it as RADIUS, or

743
00:37:51.000 --> 00:37:53.380
we may implement it as one of
the more updated versions.

744
00:37:53.380 --> 00:37:57.000
It really still is essentially RADIUS,
it's just newer versions of RADIUS,

745
00:37:57.000 --> 00:38:00.920
which is what these Diameter Tacx,
Tacx+ concepts represent, but

746
00:38:00.920 --> 00:38:04.650
at the end of the day they're still
basically implementing a RADIUS solution.

747
00:38:04.650 --> 00:38:06.140
And that's what we want to
at least think about or

748
00:38:06.140 --> 00:38:08.600
take away from the conversation, right.

749
00:38:08.600 --> 00:38:09.680
And I did mention LDAP and

750
00:38:09.680 --> 00:38:12.320
we talked about the LDAP protocol,
we've talked a lot about it.

751
00:38:12.320 --> 00:38:17.200
We mentioned that it's an X.500 standard,
where it's certificates are X.509,

752
00:38:17.200 --> 00:38:19.830
LDAP is an X.500 implementation.

753
00:38:19.830 --> 00:38:21.470
Meaning that the formal standard for

754
00:38:21.470 --> 00:38:25.330
LDAP is the X.500 standard for
directory services.

755
00:38:25.330 --> 00:38:29.470
Whereas email, often confused with X.500,
people get this confused,

756
00:38:29.470 --> 00:38:31.490
think, email is X.500.

757
00:38:31.490 --> 00:38:36.916
No, LDAP is X.500,
whereas the email standard is X.?

758
00:38:36.916 --> 00:38:39.940
>> I'm not sure.

759
00:38:39.940 --> 00:38:41.103
>> X., X.?
>> X.4.

760
00:38:41.103 --> 00:38:42.068
>> X.4?

761
00:38:42.068 --> 00:38:43.460
>> O.

762
00:38:43.460 --> 00:38:44.230
>> Which is?
>> 400.

763
00:38:44.230 --> 00:38:46.570
>> There we go, look at that, X.400.

764
00:38:46.570 --> 00:38:49.917
As I said, people often get confused,
right, and don't know the difference.

765
00:38:49.917 --> 00:38:53.543
So it's X.400 for email,
X.500 for LDAP, and

766
00:38:53.543 --> 00:38:57.886
X.509, in this case version 3,
for digital certificates.

767
00:38:57.886 --> 00:39:01.600
Again, as a CASp candidate, you wanna be
familiar with these different standards,

768
00:39:01.600 --> 00:39:03.810
and associate them with
the appropriate technologies.

769
00:39:03.810 --> 00:39:07.080
the lightweight directory access protocol
which I believe we have to make sure we do

770
00:39:07.080 --> 00:39:10.170
to actually define the acronym
as we talk about it.

771
00:39:10.170 --> 00:39:11.560
And we also have secure LDAP..

772
00:39:11.560 --> 00:39:15.888
A lot of people don't understand
there's something called LDAP S.

773
00:39:15.888 --> 00:39:19.798
Which is a more secure implementation of
the generic LDAP version that we often

774
00:39:19.798 --> 00:39:24.140
talk about and think, is generically
the directory service we use regardless.

775
00:39:24.140 --> 00:39:28.700
That implements TLS and or SSL encryption
that transmit traffic back and

776
00:39:28.700 --> 00:39:32.520
forth so usually we have a secure
version of most of these protocols and

777
00:39:32.520 --> 00:39:33.470
these implementations.

778
00:39:33.470 --> 00:39:37.070
We just want to be thinking about that and
be aware of that as well.

779
00:39:37.070 --> 00:39:40.554
And of course Microsoft implements their
LDAP solution as the Microsoft active

780
00:39:40.554 --> 00:39:43.690
directory, the ADDS or
active director directory service.

781
00:39:43.690 --> 00:39:46.312
We talked about OpenLDAP
which is the non-proprietary,

782
00:39:46.312 --> 00:39:49.250
non-Microsoft specific
version of LDAP that

783
00:39:49.250 --> 00:39:52.800
essentially could be used by anybody
on any platform for any reason.

784

>> All right, very good, Adam.

785

A lot of great information there

786

the authorization process, and a few

787
00:40:00.560 --> 00:40:04.890

authentication authorization.

788
00:40:04.890 --> 00:40:06.990
And then as well as
the auditing/accounting and

00:40:06.990 --> 00:40:10.210
we would look at radius and

790
00:40:10.210 --> 00:40:11.490
So thanks for that, Adam, appreciate it.

791
00:40:11.490 --> 00:40:14.220
I hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

Remember, if you wanna sit in

Sounding off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

39
00:01:59.678 --> 00:02:03.810
What we wanna do is take a look at the
steps involved in the Kerberos process.

40
00:02:03.810 --> 00:02:07.148
Usually seven steps, more or less,

00:02:07.148 --> 00:02:09.880

So, in step one from the client there,

00:02:41.910 --> 00:02:46.790

00:02:46.790 --> 00:02:51.820

00:02:51.820 --> 00:02:54.750

00:02:54.750 --> 00:02:57.760
The request in other words is
made through the LDAP server.

56
00:02:57.760 --> 00:03:01.680
But then in step three, if you will,
the authentication server

57
00:03:01.680 --> 00:03:06.300

what's known as the TGS right down there.

58
00:03:06.300 --> 00:03:10.710
And attempts to essentially make
the request on behalf of the user.

59
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:15.610
And attempts to get a ticket granting
ticket issued to the client,

60
00:03:15.610 --> 00:03:19.390
so the second step is that
the client makes the request and

61
00:03:19.390 --> 00:03:22.470

So they got a whole bunch

00:27:19.625 --> 00:27:21.595

And so if you buy the Park Hopper,

00:27:21.595 --> 00:27:25.465

511
00:27:25.465 --> 00:27:28.755
You're trusted, right, through
federation in all these different parks.

512
00:27:28.755 --> 00:27:32.695
Cuz you could also just buy a park pass

513
00:27:32.695 --> 00:27:34.145

00:27:34.145 --> 00:27:38.135
Essentially Disney has their own open ID
authentication system with their pass

00:27:38.135 --> 00:27:39.715
framework running behind the scenes.

516
00:27:39.715 --> 00:27:42.145
You buy the right kind of pass and
they federate you and

00:27:42.145 --> 00:27:43.610
allow you into any of the parks.

00:27:43.610 --> 00:27:46.520
If you buy the wrong pass,
essentially a one park,

00:27:46.520 --> 00:27:49.520
one pass kinda thing,
you're limited only to that park.

520
00:27:49.520 --> 00:27:51.410
And then of course they just
simply charge you more money,

521
00:27:51.410 --> 00:27:54.220
and they're happy to then federate
you wherever you wanna go.

522
00:27:54.220 --> 00:27:56.040
For money, Adam,
we'll let you go anywhere you'd like.

523
00:27:56.040 --> 00:27:57.165
It's not a Problem, right?

524
00:27:57.165 --> 00:28:00.945
We also have Shibboleth,
which is another federated ID method.

525
00:28:00.945 --> 00:28:01.995
It's based on XAML.

526
00:28:01.995 --> 00:28:04.765
It's one of the additional
ones that we often will see.

527
00:28:04.765 --> 00:28:06.325
It's very big in the academic space,

528
00:28:06.325 --> 00:28:08.905
universities will use
it a lot as a provider.

529
00:28:09.995 --> 00:28:14.205
Open source, public service
organizations that are, like NGOs and

530
00:28:14.205 --> 00:28:16.835
things like that tend to use it

531
00:28:16.835 --> 00:28:19.980
So it is essentially on being or

532
00:28:19.980 --> 00:28:23.830
being able to retrieve your information
from a Shibboleth enabled website.

533
00:28:23.830 --> 00:28:26.620
And then once we have that information,

534
00:28:26.620 --> 00:28:29.700
XAML is essentially used to
authenticate behind the scenes.

535
00:28:29.700 --> 00:28:32.530
So you're logging into a common front end

536
00:28:32.530 --> 00:28:36.780
XAML's used to proxy your request on the
back end and send that information back.

537
00:28:36.780 --> 00:28:39.564
We also may see where are you from,
what's known as WAYF,

538
00:28:39.564 --> 00:28:45.110
W-A-Y-F is the acronym,
where are you from, is what it spells out.

539
00:28:45.110 --> 00:28:50.050
It's an SSL implementation that
essentially asks users to tell us hey,

540
00:28:50.050 --> 00:28:52.620
where are you from,
what institution are you associated with?

541
00:28:52.620 --> 00:28:54.020
In large organizations,

542
00:28:54.020 --> 00:28:57.490
again think maybe universities
with different colleges, right?

543
00:28:57.490 --> 00:28:59.210
Or think something like Harvard or Yale,

544
00:28:59.210 --> 00:29:03.050
one of these big, huge schools that
have different colleges and institutions

545
00:29:03.050 --> 00:29:07.140
associated with them that may log you in
and authenticate you as a student, but

546
00:29:07.140 --> 00:29:09.400
you may be associated with
the School of Engineering or

547
00:29:09.400 --> 00:29:13.200
the School of Business or School of Public
Policy or School of Medicine or whatever.

548
00:29:13.200 --> 00:29:16.960
And you may have different access to
different resources based on essentially

549
00:29:16.960 --> 00:29:20.550
what school and what organization or
institution you're associated with.

550
00:29:20.550 --> 00:29:25.940
So where are you from is a method with SSO
that essentially allows us to silo you,

551
00:29:25.940 --> 00:29:30.070
right if you think about it logically,
Inside of those different containers.

552
00:29:30.070 --> 00:29:32.530
It's just another method that's used.

553
00:29:32.530 --> 00:29:35.450
We ask you where are you from,
you validate with some sort of

554
00:29:35.450 --> 00:29:39.550
not just user name and password, but
typically some sort of association, right,

555
00:29:39.550 --> 00:29:43.910
so you have an institution id that's
associated specifically with your user id.

556
00:29:43.910 --> 00:29:47.420
You log in to essentially tell us where
you're from and then we essentially

557
00:29:47.420 --> 00:29:50.330
are able to provision you as a result
of that and give you access.

558
00:29:50.330 --> 00:29:54.850
So where are you from is yet another
federation architecture that may be used

559
00:29:54.850 --> 00:29:57.840
where different companies are trusting
each other and based on are different

560
00:29:57.840 --> 00:30:01.580
entities within the same institution or
essentially able to silo you

561
00:30:01.580 --> 00:30:05.470
through federation and because of that
we essentially figure out where you are.

562
00:30:05.470 --> 00:30:08.360
Where you're coming from and what
you're entitled to as a result of that.

563
00:30:08.360 --> 00:30:11.440
So these are just different ways
we can approach federation and

564
00:30:11.440 --> 00:30:12.500
think about federation.

565
00:30:12.500 --> 00:30:16.980
And obviously the value add here for
the casp is to understand how to integrate

566
00:30:16.980 --> 00:30:21.460
identity management across
the organization, across the enterprise

567
00:30:21.460 --> 00:30:25.330

568
00:30:25.330 --> 00:30:29.410
or what we know and think about as the

569
00:30:29.410 --> 00:30:32.970
But more importantly, specifically
address the business requirements and

570
00:30:32.970 --> 00:30:36.390
a line to support them that
individual organizations may have.

571
00:30:36.390 --> 00:30:39.680
Some organizations may wanna federate,
others may not.

572
00:30:39.680 --> 00:30:42.120
And implementing a federation
solution when we have no need for

573
00:30:42.120 --> 00:30:46.150
one is needlessly complex and
very, very problematic to manage.

574
00:30:46.150 --> 00:30:48.930
But many organizations, I think it's
fair to say almost all of them without

575
00:30:48.930 --> 00:30:53.000
exception today, want SSO capabilities
whether they federate or not.

576
00:30:53.000 --> 00:30:56.060
Remember SSO is a subset of federation.

577
00:30:56.060 --> 00:31:01.100
You don't have to use SSO in order to
be able to do federation, you need SSO,

578
00:31:01.100 --> 00:31:06.270
but you don't have to use SSO with,
with or without a federation solution.

579
00:31:06.270 --> 00:31:10.040
You just decide you wanna use single
sign on, and you implement it.

580
00:31:10.040 --> 00:31:11.780
But you may not be federated,
in other words.

581
00:31:11.780 --> 00:31:13.840
So they can exist separately
from one another.

582
00:31:14.930 --> 00:31:17.110
All federated solutions use SSO.

583
00:31:17.110 --> 00:31:19.220
But not all SSO solutions
require federation.

584
00:31:19.220 --> 00:31:19.840
That's my point,

Trevor you said earlier.

599

>> Mm-hm.
>> Right so all these different ones.

600
00:32:04.550 --> 00:32:07.680
And we may have to pick and choose when

601
00:32:07.680 --> 00:32:09.520
So a lot of things for us to think about.

602
00:32:09.520 --> 00:32:12.220
A lot of things for
us to potentially sink our teeth into.

603
00:32:12.220 --> 00:32:15.360
Most people that do this, that do this
well and really understand this particular

604
00:32:15.360 --> 00:32:18.910
area of security, specialize in
identity and access management.

605
00:32:18.910 --> 00:32:22.080

This is one of the things that got
us into a lot of trouble with home

560
00:27:41.720 --> 00:27:43.870
based internet connections
that are always on.

561
00:27:43.870 --> 00:27:47.190
Early on as we started to roll this
concept out with cable modems, for

562
00:27:47.190 --> 00:27:49.390
instance, right over the last decade or
so.

563
00:27:49.390 --> 00:27:52.281
Because now we are essentially
hooking up computers at home,

564
00:27:52.281 --> 00:27:54.067
leaving the internet on all the time.

565
00:27:54.067 --> 00:27:57.786
And as a result, someone essentially could
hack in when you weren't there if you

566
00:27:57.786 --> 00:28:00.754
don't have a firewall or
proper protection mechanisms set up.

567
00:28:00.754 --> 00:28:05.934
Whereas in the corporate world,
with always on permanent virtual circuits,

568
00:28:05.934 --> 00:28:11.150
things like T1 lines or OC,
optical carrier lines, whatever it may be.

569
00:28:11.150 --> 00:28:14.750
The idea was that we have firewalls,
we have monitoring systems,

570
00:28:14.750 --> 00:28:17.490
we're constantly looking
at that inbound connection.

571
00:28:17.490 --> 00:28:20.280
And as a result, we're not as,
although we are concerned, but

572
00:28:20.280 --> 00:28:22.990
we're not as concerned about
the always on capabilities.

573
00:28:22.990 --> 00:28:24.630
We want them to be on demand.

574
00:28:24.630 --> 00:28:27.630
So permanent virtual circuits
are essentially provisioned to be on all

575
00:28:27.630 --> 00:28:29.430
the time, they're dedicated to you.

576
00:28:29.430 --> 00:28:32.610
Switch virtual circuits essentially
are on-demand circuits that

577
00:28:32.610 --> 00:28:36.810
are built on the fly and then torn down
after you essentially transit them so

578
00:28:36.810 --> 00:28:38.740
that the path is never gonna be the same.

579
00:28:38.740 --> 00:28:42.240
It's always gonna randomly change
based on ISP availability, and

580
00:28:42.240 --> 00:28:46.700
based on whether they're using frame or
ATM, or whatever the underlying

581
00:28:46.700 --> 00:28:49.370
carrier architecture,
it's MPLS, whatever it may be.

582
00:28:49.370 --> 00:28:53.140
Those networks are designed to essentially
be dynamic and resilient, and you'll

583
00:28:53.140 --> 00:28:57.630
constantly be changing the way you move
from A to B to C, in a switched solution.

584
00:28:57.630 --> 00:29:00.920
That is not going to be permanent, but
rather is essentially built on demand.

585
00:29:00.920 --> 00:29:05.490
So, virtual circuits also help us to
understand how to deal with data flow, and

586
00:29:05.490 --> 00:29:07.010
data flow security issues.

587
00:29:07.010 --> 00:29:10.070
But we have to be thinking about all
the different states that data exists in,

588
00:29:10.070 --> 00:29:12.720
to address these concerns
across the enterprise.

589
00:29:12.720 --> 00:29:15.290
It's very very important for
us to be thinking about these things.

590
00:29:15.290 --> 00:29:19.260
So when we're considering the guidelines
that we really have to, kind of,

591
00:29:19.260 --> 00:29:22.270
in our mind, have, for
implementing standards in the enterprise.

592
00:29:22.270 --> 00:29:24.150
These are some of the concerns.

593
00:29:24.150 --> 00:29:28.040
These are some of the things that
as security professionals, as CSPs,

594
00:29:28.040 --> 00:29:29.770
we want to have at the top of our list.

595
00:29:29.770 --> 00:29:32.250
And ultimately be talking
about on the C level.

596
00:29:32.250 --> 00:29:34.580
Making sure we're talking
with senior executives.

597
00:29:34.580 --> 00:29:37.700
Making sure we're dealing with
the strategies that have to be laid out,

598
00:29:37.700 --> 00:29:39.400
requirements that have to be gathered.

599
00:29:39.400 --> 00:29:42.920
And the thought processes that then
have to be implemented through policy,

600
00:29:42.920 --> 00:29:45.786
process and
procedure to support those over time.

601

are you ready for your acronym?

602

You know that one?

604

>> S-R-T-P, SRTP, S-R-T-P.

605

>> [LAUGH] I know,
this is an obscure one, It really is.

607

>> Secure real time protocol.

609

>> Secure real time protocol.

610

All right,
that's gonna be our acronym for the day.

611

>> You've hit all the good ones.

>> I hit all the good ones, that's true.

Shame on me I took all the easy ones.

614

>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so secure real

615
00:30:13.950 --> 00:30:14.665
time protocol.

616
00:30:14.665 --> 00:30:19.692
SRTP, acronym for the day in ITPro.TV,
today is SRTP day.

617

>> [LAUGH]
>> Awesome, all right, very good.

618

>> All right, Adam, thanks for all that

619

doing this secure enterprise architecture.

620

I know we've got more to cover but
we are out of time, unfortunately, for

this particular episode so
we'll go ahead and call it here.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.367 --> 00:00:15.295
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.295 --> 00:00:16.856
I'm your host, MIke Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.856 --> 00:00:20.269
Today we're doing our
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner.

5
00:00:20.269 --> 00:00:21.757
In this particular episode,

6
00:00:21.757 --> 00:00:25.691
we're gonna continue our conversation
on secure enterprise architecture.

7
00:00:25.691 --> 00:00:29.690
What it takes to start tying all
these different pieces together, and

8
00:00:29.690 --> 00:00:31.360
as our networks change and

9
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:35.130
our enterprise evolves, we've got
a lot of different moving parts there.

10
00:00:35.130 --> 00:00:38.650
So here to help us with all of that is Mr.
Adam Gordon, how's it going Adam?

11
00:00:38.650 --> 00:00:39.648
>> Good, good, very good.

12
00:00:39.648 --> 00:00:43.135
So we're gonna talk a little bit more,
as Mike said, about this whole concept.

13
00:00:43.135 --> 00:00:45.810
We're actually gonna focus in a little
bit on how we select technical

14
00:00:45.810 --> 00:00:46.647
deployment models.

15
00:00:46.647 --> 00:00:52.382
Specifically what do we do with regards to
how we bring the cloud, virtualization.

16
00:00:52.382 --> 00:00:56.201
Some of these new technologies that we
have seen and continue to see evolving and

17
00:00:56.201 --> 00:00:57.854
emerging in the marketplace, and

18
00:00:57.854 --> 00:01:01.330
certainly inside the enterprise
over the last several years.

19
00:01:01.330 --> 00:01:02.610
How do we bring them to bear?

20
00:01:02.610 --> 00:01:04.620
How do we integrate them if you will?

21
00:01:04.620 --> 00:01:08.030
We have to really understand what they
are, what they represent, how they work,

22
00:01:08.030 --> 00:01:11.140
in order to make good informed decisions
about whether we can consume them, and

23
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:12.820
if so, under what conditions?

24
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:16.190
So, wanna make sure we think about how
to select technical deployment models

25
00:01:16.190 --> 00:01:18.770
by starting with a baseline.

26
00:01:18.770 --> 00:01:22.150
A good understanding of,
in this case specifically, the cloud.

27
00:01:22.150 --> 00:01:25.970
What the cloud deployment models are,
our options there, we'll go through those.

28
00:01:25.970 --> 00:01:29.880
What the cloud service models are, again
our options there, we'll go through those.

29
00:01:29.880 --> 00:01:31.108
Let's start with the deployment models.

30
00:01:31.108 --> 00:01:33.449
Essentially deployment
model's a framework for

31
00:01:33.449 --> 00:01:36.913
how particular systems can be put
into play in the organization, right?

32
00:01:36.913 --> 00:01:41.705
We talk about a deployment model,
we essentially are talking about the box

33
00:01:41.705 --> 00:01:46.666
that we're gonna build essentially,
to be able to frame the conversation.

34
00:01:46.666 --> 00:01:50.912
About how this organization's system
is gonna look, how it's gonna operate,

35
00:01:50.912 --> 00:01:53.480
what it will do,
things of that nature, right?

36
00:01:53.480 --> 00:01:54.850
So we're gonna think about that.

37
00:01:54.850 --> 00:01:58.600
So, what we're gonna do
is talk just a little bit

38
00:01:58.600 --> 00:02:01.420
about the cloud deployment models,
you can see them, thank you very much.

39
00:02:01.420 --> 00:02:05.580
You can see them on the screen, up there's
the cloud and virtualization hosting

40
00:02:05.580 --> 00:02:09.470
options, essentially, or really what
the cloud deployment models represent.

41
00:02:09.470 --> 00:02:13.066
There are four established,
agreed upon cloud deployment models,

42
00:02:13.066 --> 00:02:15.362
public, private, hybrid and community.

43
00:02:15.362 --> 00:02:16.616
You'll see them listed there.

44
00:02:16.616 --> 00:02:19.820
We wanna quickly define them for you,
but also show you where they come from.

45
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:22.730
We'll do that in just a minute, but
let's start with the definition.

46
00:02:22.730 --> 00:02:27.300
So, a public cloud is going to
be a cloud that essentially

47
00:02:27.300 --> 00:02:29.690
is open to anybody that
wants to consume it.

48
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:34.504
It's available from multiple places,
traditionally, and allows us to access

49
00:02:34.504 --> 00:02:39.260
information that is stored there without
having to authenticate most likely.

50
00:02:39.260 --> 00:02:42.562
The concept of cloud computing
is kind of interesting.

51
00:02:42.562 --> 00:02:44.780
Let's step back and
talk historically for just a minute.

52
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:47.500
Old school versus new school, right.

53
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:51.520
So when we think about public cloud today,
and we hear the marketing hype and

54
00:02:51.520 --> 00:02:56.170
the discussion track around cloud now
kind of morphing into the Internet of

55
00:02:56.170 --> 00:03:00.230
Things and convergence, kind of
the newest way of thinking about this.

56
00:03:00.230 --> 00:03:03.194
What we really are talking about
is concepts that have been around,

57
00:03:03.194 --> 00:03:04.500
in some cases, for decades.

58
00:03:04.500 --> 00:03:07.093
And the public cloud is really
just the rebranding and

59
00:03:07.093 --> 00:03:11.320
the reimagining of the World Wide Web,
and more specifically, the Internet.

60
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:14.094
The largest public cloud in
the world that we have, and

61
00:03:14.094 --> 00:03:17.231
that concept of a network that's
been freely available, and

62
00:03:17.231 --> 00:03:21.412
has been accessible to many people if not
all people, but certainly many people.

63
00:03:21.412 --> 00:03:24.531
As long as you have a computer,
and essentially,

64
00:03:24.531 --> 00:03:28.530
an on ramp, that you can get
connected to the network to use.

65
00:03:28.530 --> 00:03:30.900
The Internet is the original public cloud.

66
00:03:30.900 --> 00:03:33.470
And so when we think about public cloud,
we're really thinking about the Internet

67
00:03:33.470 --> 00:03:36.580
or the World Wide Web as one example,
probably the largest example.

68
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:39.353
Not the only one, but
certainly a very, very important one.

69
00:03:39.353 --> 00:03:40.810
When we think about private cloud,

70
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:43.310
we're thinking about
essentially the same concept.

71
00:03:43.310 --> 00:03:48.080
But now you have to be a member of
a certain group or have some sort of

72
00:03:48.080 --> 00:03:51.140
a credential of some kind and
a reason to be there to authenticate,

73
00:03:51.140 --> 00:03:54.680
to see the content that is
provided to you by a vendor,

74
00:03:54.680 --> 00:03:58.790
by a company, whatever is, or
whoever is behind the private cloud.

75
00:03:58.790 --> 00:04:02.030
Essentially, we are building
a private network.

76
00:04:02.030 --> 00:04:05.887
And we would think of this as an intranet,
an internal private network.

77
00:04:05.887 --> 00:04:09.186
That would be old school way of
thinking about private cloud,

78
00:04:09.186 --> 00:04:13.387
whereas the Internet is the old school
way of thinking about the public cloud.

79
00:04:13.387 --> 00:04:17.747
So we have public cloud equals
essentially Internet, private cloud would

80
00:04:17.747 --> 00:04:22.400
essentially have equaled the intranet,
and then we would have a hybrid cloud.

81
00:04:22.400 --> 00:04:25.246
A hybrid cloud is essentially
combining public and

82
00:04:25.246 --> 00:04:27.233
private cloud elements together,

83
00:04:27.233 --> 00:04:31.960
allowing us to have essentially both
elements in a single cloud environment.

84
00:04:31.960 --> 00:04:35.826
A lot of companies will wanna have
information available publicly that any

85
00:04:35.826 --> 00:04:38.537
customers, or
anybody from anywhere can consume.

86
00:04:38.537 --> 00:04:42.865
But then also have private elements of
information that are available only to

87
00:04:42.865 --> 00:04:47.350
their members, or their employees, or
their customers or whatever it may be.

88
00:04:47.350 --> 00:04:51.344
So imagine for
instance that you go to Google.

89
00:04:51.344 --> 00:04:54.129
Imagine that you go and
we've done this in prior episodes,

90
00:04:54.129 --> 00:04:56.256
showed you the Google authentication page.

91
00:04:56.256 --> 00:05:00.578
And discussed how OAuth and the steps of
OAuth are used at a site like to Google to

92
00:05:00.578 --> 00:05:04.508
essentially create tokens and
walk you through the authentication and

93
00:05:04.508 --> 00:05:07.018
the federation process
with single sign on.

94
00:05:07.018 --> 00:05:09.820
We've been through a lot of
this in other episodes, right?

95
00:05:09.820 --> 00:05:13.080
Not gonna redo that whole conversation
here, but just imagine for

96
00:05:13.080 --> 00:05:18.650
a minute going to the main Google web page
and essentially being at that log on page.

97
00:05:18.650 --> 00:05:21.350
You're seeing publicly
available information, but

98
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:23.980
then when you log in you're
being shown private information,

99
00:05:23.980 --> 00:05:26.720
essentially information about you,
your account, etc.

100
00:05:26.720 --> 00:05:29.130
You're seeing a hybrid cloud
where you have both elements.

101
00:05:29.130 --> 00:05:32.873
Go to any of the banking sites that you
may use, or a bank's website that you may

102
00:05:32.873 --> 00:05:36.190
be a customer from, whatever bank
that may be anywhere in the world.

103
00:05:36.190 --> 00:05:40.411
The public facing side of that cloud is
gonna be the information the bank has

104
00:05:40.411 --> 00:05:44.297
on the main page, mortgage rates
in the United States for instance,

105
00:05:44.297 --> 00:05:47.584
credit card rates,
if they have credit cards they issue.

106
00:05:47.584 --> 00:05:51.662
Probably information about
the services the bank offers,

107
00:05:51.662 --> 00:05:56.730
private lending, second loans on homes,
all that kind of stuff.

108
00:05:56.730 --> 00:05:59.400
And then if you're a customer,
you can log in somewhere,

109
00:05:59.400 --> 00:06:03.650
usually in a secure page, and you can
essentially access account information.

110
00:06:03.650 --> 00:06:07.200
Information behind that secure log on is

111
00:06:07.200 --> 00:06:09.820
essentially the private
side of that cloud.

112
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:12.470
These are examples of what
hybrid clouds would look like.

113
00:06:12.470 --> 00:06:15.090
We may also think about them
from an IT perspective.

114
00:06:15.090 --> 00:06:19.648
We may have a private cloud that is being
used by the IT function of the business to

115
00:06:19.648 --> 00:06:23.335
essentially do asset management,
to do identity management.

116
00:06:23.335 --> 00:06:27.597
Everything to do, everything or anything
from enterprise content management to

117
00:06:27.597 --> 00:06:30.680
email, all that stuff can
be done in a private cloud.

118
00:06:30.680 --> 00:06:32.960
We may also have a public
facing portion of that cloud,

119
00:06:32.960 --> 00:06:35.840
and we may be producing
hybrid cloud solutions.

120
00:06:35.840 --> 00:06:38.100
So there's lots of different
ways to view this.

121
00:06:38.100 --> 00:06:41.041
And then community cloud is one a lot
of people don't often talk about,

122
00:06:41.041 --> 00:06:42.770
most people don't even realize exists.

123
00:06:42.770 --> 00:06:45.061
It's one of those kind of less well known,

124
00:06:45.061 --> 00:06:47.880
less well understood
cloud deployment models.

125
00:06:47.880 --> 00:06:52.650
But the community cloud is essentially
a subset of the private cloud.

126
00:06:52.650 --> 00:06:56.950
Private cloud overall represents
simply the entire organization, and

127
00:06:56.950 --> 00:06:59.970
all the members of that
organization be given access to

128
00:06:59.970 --> 00:07:02.950
whatever information the company
wants to keep confidential.

129
00:07:02.950 --> 00:07:05.500
The community cloud is
typically a subset of that.

130
00:07:05.500 --> 00:07:09.590
Specific interest groups within the
private community, or within the private

131
00:07:09.590 --> 00:07:13.830
cloud, may have their own separate areas
in the private cloud unique to them.

132
00:07:13.830 --> 00:07:19.212
So for instance maybe HR, maybe sales and
marketing, maybe IT, would all have their

133
00:07:19.212 --> 00:07:24.329
own sub areas within the private cloud
that are unique to their interest groups.

134
00:07:24.329 --> 00:07:28.747
The people that are part of HR may go into
a separate secure area of the private

135
00:07:28.747 --> 00:07:33.480
cloud that's an additional secured area,
off from the main private cloud.

136
00:07:33.480 --> 00:07:38.960
That they have to log into to look at
employee data, maybe employee reviews,

137
00:07:38.960 --> 00:07:41.710
maybe HR specific information.

138
00:07:41.710 --> 00:07:43.626
Your personnel file, in effect, right?

139
00:07:43.626 --> 00:07:49.110
The stuff about you, that may be stored in
an ERP system, let's say hypothetically.

140
00:07:49.110 --> 00:07:53.652
And that ERP system may be only open
to certain members of the private cloud

141

00:01:30.740 --> 00:01:34.980

00:01:50.790 --> 00:01:55.110
The capability to essentially put data

00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:59.280
interact with it through the processing

37
00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:02.430
Those physical resources

38
00:02:02.430 --> 00:02:06.920
They essentially are divided up and made

00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:10.600

00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:14.600

00:02:44.080 --> 00:02:45.920

00:02:45.920 --> 00:02:49.720

00:02:49.720 --> 00:02:53.920

One box one role is what we would often

00:03:05.420 --> 00:03:09.120
it's one box multiple roles or

00:03:09.120 --> 00:03:13.494
And so we may see consolidation

Running multiple instances, in other

chair and I kick my shoes off and I relax,

76
00:04:10.100 --> 00:04:14.000
I want to be able to kind of be stress
free, right, as I'm sure most of you do.

00:04:14.000 --> 00:04:18.130

00:04:19.350 --> 00:04:23.010
That's what work's for, right, that's not

00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:25.910
So we don't want to really know,

00:04:25.910 --> 00:04:27.510
We want to have it hidden from us.

00:04:27.510 --> 00:04:30.434

00:04:30.434 --> 00:04:31.123

00:04:31.123 --> 00:04:33.049
I don't want to know about all that stuff,

00:04:33.049 --> 00:04:36.060
I just want to know that ultimately

00:04:36.060 --> 00:04:40.200

00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:44.056
That's our responsibility, let us go out

00:04:44.056 --> 00:04:46.840

have these things called budgets, right?

00:06:03.685 --> 00:06:04.940
That we have to worry about and

Virtual machines,

00:15:30.231 --> 00:15:33.315

00:47:19.930 --> 00:47:22.282

00:47:22.282 --> 00:47:25.570

00:47:25.570 --> 00:47:28.560
Because they don't
necessarily end with a yes or

00:27:51.160 --> 00:27:54.220
Type one, type two, so,
great information, thanks for that, Adam.

590
00:27:54.220 --> 00:27:56.170
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

591
00:27:56.170 --> 00:27:58.770
Remember, if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

592
00:27:58.770 --> 00:28:02.130
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

593
00:28:02.130 --> 00:28:03.805
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

594
00:28:05.090 --> 00:28:05.685
>> That would be me.

595
00:28:05.685 --> 00:28:07.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm sorry, I was virtualizing and

596
00:28:07.970 --> 00:28:08.862
I was somewhere else.

597
00:28:08.862 --> 00:28:09.951
I'm in the cloud!

598
00:28:09.951 --> 00:28:11.840
Here I am, I'm Adam.

599
00:28:11.840 --> 00:28:13.690
Nice to meet you, take care.

600
00:28:13.690 --> 00:28:14.761
>> We'll see you next time.

601
00:28:14.761 --> 00:28:16.061
>> Take care, everybody.

602

episodes.title: Enterprise Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.064 --> 00:00:10.064
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.387 --> 00:00:15.888
Hello welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.888 --> 00:00:16.990
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.990 --> 00:00:20.450
Today we're doing our
CompTia Advanced Security Practitioner.

5
00:00:20.450 --> 00:00:21.973
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:21.973 --> 00:00:24.500
we're going to be taking
a look at Enterprise Storage.

7
00:00:24.500 --> 00:00:26.740
Now storage is obviously very important.

8
00:00:26.740 --> 00:00:29.890
It seems like today's
enterprises generate more and

9
00:00:29.890 --> 00:00:32.430
more data that we've got
to store than ever before.

10
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:35.130
So we've got to make sure that
we have a place to store it.

11
00:00:35.130 --> 00:00:39.980
And that we're providing things
like redundancy, high availability,

12
00:00:39.980 --> 00:00:43.360
performance necessary
to get to that storage.

13
00:00:43.360 --> 00:00:46.420
If we store it somewhere and
we can't get to it when we need it and

14
00:00:46.420 --> 00:00:48.740
the performance isn't there,
it doesn't do us a lot of good.

15
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:53.700
So we've mentioned a few different types
of storage that we can use at enterprise,

16
00:00:53.700 --> 00:01:00.260
SANs, NAS, direct attached storage, we're
gonna talk about those again, kinda rehash

17
00:01:00.260 --> 00:01:03.960
some of those as well as bringing in a few
new types that we haven't talked about.

18
00:01:03.960 --> 00:01:08.210
So here to help us keep all of this
straight is the one only Adam Gordon.

19
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:09.070
How's it going, Adam?

20
00:01:09.070 --> 00:01:09.610
>> Good, good.

21
00:01:09.610 --> 00:01:12.700
You caught me playing around
with my storage container.

22
00:01:12.700 --> 00:01:14.910
Look, I've got a visual aid here again.

23
00:01:14.910 --> 00:01:19.460
Here's my storage container, we're
gonna put all of Mike's data in there.

24
00:01:19.460 --> 00:01:22.272
Along with all the other stuff that
he talks about on a regular basis.

25
00:01:22.272 --> 00:01:24.391
You wanna contribute?
>> It looks suspiciously similar.

26
00:01:24.391 --> 00:01:24.937
>> It is!

27
00:01:24.937 --> 00:01:26.735
It's a dual use technology, by the way.

28
00:01:26.735 --> 00:01:28.782
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because it's also the hypervisor, and

29
00:01:28.782 --> 00:01:32.025
I, did you know hypervisor spelled
backwards is storage container?

30
00:01:32.025 --> 00:01:33.394
[LAUGH]
>> Did I share with you that

31
00:01:33.394 --> 00:01:34.620
whole desert and stress thing?

32
00:01:34.620 --> 00:01:36.880
I think I told you about that
in one of the episodes, right?

33
00:01:36.880 --> 00:01:37.500
>> Yep.
>> So yes,

34
00:01:37.500 --> 00:01:40.110
hypervisor spelled backwards is
storage container, but only when

35
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:44.290
you're standing on your head every other
Tuesday in a leap year, just so you know.

36
00:01:44.290 --> 00:01:46.040
Anyway, we're gonna talk about storage,

37
00:01:46.040 --> 00:01:48.300
storage containers,
how we deal with storage.

38
00:01:48.300 --> 00:01:52.150
Mike made a really great point,
which is shocking, never happens.

39
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:55.260
But he made a really good point
when we were starting which is that

40
00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:59.790
enterprises and
when you said this I was thinking,

41
00:01:59.790 --> 00:02:01.350
it's a really good point that
we want to talk about and

42
00:02:01.350 --> 00:02:05.010
bring through as a thread kind of
a commonality in our conversations here.

43
00:02:05.010 --> 00:02:09.950
Enterprises are producing so much data and
so much stuff, data in many forms,

44
00:02:09.950 --> 00:02:13.760
written as well as electronic
certainly today and continue to.

45
00:02:13.760 --> 00:02:17.030
And when you think about how
expensive storage was years ago,

46
00:02:17.030 --> 00:02:18.100
compared to what it is today.

47
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:20.880
And we had this conversation in one of
the earlier episodes where we talked about

48
00:02:20.880 --> 00:02:24.562
cell phones and the onboard
storage capacity, the SD card, and

49
00:02:24.562 --> 00:02:29.350
having a 64 gig or now as I share
with you, a 256 gig chip that can

50
00:02:29.350 --> 00:02:34.150
start to be deployed, we start thinking
about what we're paying for storage today.

51
00:02:34.150 --> 00:02:37.270
And it really is true,
space abhors a vacuum as they say.

52
00:02:37.270 --> 00:02:42.730
So data grows to essentially fill
the storage capacity that we throw at it.

53
00:02:42.730 --> 00:02:45.010
We don't create data out of necessity.

54
00:02:45.010 --> 00:02:48.920
We create it because if we didn't
the universe would essentially

55
00:02:48.920 --> 00:02:52.270
self destruct and implode, because
there would be too much free space and

56
00:02:52.270 --> 00:02:53.710
not enough stuff to put in it.

57
00:02:53.710 --> 00:02:58.710
So we just seemingly without any rhyme or
reason are continuing to create data,

58
00:02:58.710 --> 00:03:00.850
most of which is erroneous and
garbage by the way.

59
00:03:00.850 --> 00:03:04.520
It means absolutely nothing,
but, we still create it.

60
00:03:04.520 --> 00:03:08.336
And as a result for the CASP we have to
figure out how to ultimately secure it and

61
00:03:08.336 --> 00:03:11.976
how to focus on what the importance of
it is, because if we understand what

62
00:03:11.976 --> 00:03:15.710
the importance of data is, we could
decide whether it's worth securing.

63
00:03:15.710 --> 00:03:17.940
So this is the first thing
we wanna think about.

64
00:03:17.940 --> 00:03:19.440
How do we secure data?

65
00:03:19.440 --> 00:03:23.380
We step back and we start by understanding
the importance of data for classification.

66
00:03:23.380 --> 00:03:26.620
And if we don't have a good classification
scheme, and we don't really truly

67
00:03:26.620 --> 00:03:31.550
understand the nature of data, then we
can't really talk intelligently about

68
00:03:31.550 --> 00:03:35.200
whether or not it's important to secure
it and therefore how we should secure it.

69
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:36.850
So, what again I'm kinda getting at, and

70
00:03:36.850 --> 00:03:40.370
we talked about this in the last episode,
is this idea of root cause.

71
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:41.080
And why?

72
00:03:41.080 --> 00:03:45.480
If we understand why data is
important through classification,

73
00:03:45.480 --> 00:03:48.740
we can then make some decisions about
whether or not we're gonna secure it, and

74
00:03:48.740 --> 00:03:50.280
if so, under what conditions.

75
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:55.570
Where most of my customers, where most
of my students, where I fear many of you

76
00:03:55.570 --> 00:03:59.420
may be stuck, is the fact that
you don't really understand, and

77
00:03:59.420 --> 00:04:04.700
therefore appreciate the need for data
classification to drive data security.

78
00:04:04.700 --> 00:04:07.480
And we often see it backwards,
let's secure the data and

79
00:04:07.480 --> 00:04:10.350
then yeah we should classify it
when we're done securing it.

80
00:04:10.350 --> 00:04:13.870
Well no, you gotta classify it in order
to figure out whether you should even be

81
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:15.660
considering securing it.

82
00:04:15.660 --> 00:04:20.640
So, for instance, I'm holding up or I will
be holding up in just a moment this page

83
00:04:20.640 --> 00:04:24.680
of seemingly randomly,
garbaged white space, but

84
00:04:24.680 --> 00:04:30.010
if this was a steganography solution,
there would actually be data.

85
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:34.649
But you can't see it,
I'm not Surratt, but I'm close.

86
00:04:34.649 --> 00:04:36.480
>> [LAUGH] Adam Copperfield.

87
00:04:36.480 --> 00:04:37.675
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

88
00:04:37.675 --> 00:04:40.805
But when we're talking about data, and I
know you can't see the data on the screen,

89
00:04:40.805 --> 00:04:42.725
and quite honestly what's
on the page is irrelevant.

90
00:04:42.725 --> 00:04:45.245
This is just the outline for some of
the notes that we're going through and

91
00:04:45.245 --> 00:04:47.047
talking about with you,
it's not really important.

92
00:04:47.047 --> 00:04:50.257
What is important is understanding
that what is on this paper

93
00:04:50.257 --> 00:04:52.227
may actually be very critical data.

94
00:04:52.227 --> 00:04:53.937
But the problem is we don't really know.

95
00:04:53.937 --> 00:04:57.927
And unless I have a classification
scheme that helps me to figure this out,

96
00:04:57.927 --> 00:05:01.527
it may be very difficult for
myself, for Mike, for any of you,

97
00:05:01.527 --> 00:05:05.407
to understand whether we should waste
time securing this piece of paper.

98
00:05:05.407 --> 00:05:08.687
Or we should simply just leave it out and
hope that if somebody comes along they

99
00:05:08.687 --> 00:05:11.010
don't take it, and if they do,
we don't really care.

100
00:05:11.010 --> 00:05:15.080
So classification becomes an incredibly,
incredibly important driver for

101
00:05:15.080 --> 00:05:18.160
us with regards to identifying
storage types and protocols.

102
00:05:18.160 --> 00:05:20.910
Because unless we have
a compelling business reason and

103
00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:23.800
a framework to attach to that,
there's really no good way for

104
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:27.590
us to understand whether the decisions
we're making are the right ones or not.

105
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:30.930
How do we know essentially,
we don't really know.

106
00:05:30.930 --> 00:05:34.020
And if we're operating blindly,
we may make very good decisions, but

107
00:05:34.020 --> 00:05:36.430
we're not gonna do so consistently,
and that's one of the struggles,

108
00:05:36.430 --> 00:05:37.730
potentially, that we have.

109
00:05:37.730 --> 00:05:41.760
So we have to think about classification
first, ultimately as the driver,

110
00:05:41.760 --> 00:05:44.790
to allow us to then understand how to
jump in and start securing storage.

111
00:05:44.790 --> 00:05:48.970
So with that thought process out there,
kinda with that framework if you will

112
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:52.150
laid out before us let's talk about
how we identify storage types and

113
00:05:52.150 --> 00:05:54.310
protocols that may be appropriate for
a little bit.

114
00:05:54.310 --> 00:05:55.530
So when we think about storage,

115
00:05:55.530 --> 00:05:57.530
Mike mentioned again some
real interesting stuff.

116
00:05:57.530 --> 00:06:00.590
He talked about NAS solutions,
networked attached storage,

117
00:06:00.590 --> 00:06:04.990
he talked about SAN solutions,
storage attached network devices,

118
00:06:04.990 --> 00:06:09.245
or networks rather, he talked about DAS,
direct attached storage solutions.

119
00:06:09.245 --> 00:06:12.550
We've spoken about these as
well in other episodes, but

120
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:14.940
what he didn't mention
was virtual storage.

121
00:06:14.940 --> 00:06:20.120
We have, these days, VSAN or Virtual san,
essentially software defining the storage

122
00:06:20.120 --> 00:06:24.900
parameters so that way we can take storage
that physically does exist somewhere,

123
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:27.990
because storage has to be physical for
us to use it.

124
00:06:27.990 --> 00:06:32.830
So somewhere there is a physical backend
for the storage of a virtual san and

125
00:06:32.830 --> 00:06:38.710
we essentially then allow consumers and
the virtual world to use that storage.

126
00:06:38.710 --> 00:06:41.440
But we're extracting it, much like we're
extracting everything else through

127
00:06:41.440 --> 00:06:44.850
the hypervisor or
through whatever the kernel may be or

128
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:49.530
whatever that function may be that
the vendor refers to their hypervisor as.

129
00:06:49.530 --> 00:06:53.680
We're abstracting it so that it appears
to be something that is accessible to

130
00:06:53.680 --> 00:06:57.020
everybody when in fact it's uniquely
defined for us even though there

131
00:06:57.020 --> 00:07:00.520
are many other people that may be using
it behind the scenes from a common pool.

132
00:07:00.520 --> 00:07:04.344
So virtual storage is very popular today,
and we're seeing it with virtual SAN

133
00:07:04.344 --> 00:07:08.230
technology, again, on most of the major
vendor platforms, so be aware of that.

134
00:07:08.230 --> 00:07:11.470
But there are security implications like
there are with everything that we do for

135
00:07:11.470 --> 00:07:12.590
virtual storage.

136
00:07:12.590 --> 00:07:15.680
And I've talked about some of these
things in many, many of our discussions.

137
00:07:15.680 --> 00:07:18.940
I've talked about unauthorized
access to storage back ends,

138
00:07:18.940 --> 00:07:22.810
I've talked about multipathing, which is a
good thing from a redundancy perspective,

139
00:07:22.810 --> 00:07:27.500
but if isolation through LUN masking and
zoning is not accomplished correctly,

140
00:07:27.500 --> 00:07:30.970
multipathing can essentially
open up large slots

141
00:07:30.970 --> 00:07:35.600
of secure resources to bad actors,
cuz they can be exposed unnecessarily.

142
00:07:35.600 --> 00:07:38.068
So we have to worry about that,
we have to worry about VM escape,

143
00:07:38.068 --> 00:07:40.604
we talked about that in our prior
discussion on virtualization.

144
00:07:40.604 --> 00:07:43.626
We have to worry about data remnants,
data being left behind,

145
00:07:43.626 --> 00:07:47.050
storage being repurposed and
essentially now being made available and

146
00:07:47.050 --> 00:07:50.360
all of a sudden look there's last
year's financials for company A,

147
00:07:50.360 --> 00:07:53.523
when I'm now company B, and
that's not obviously a good thing.

148
00:07:53.523 --> 00:07:55.510
So we have to worry about
all these concerns,

149
00:07:55.510 --> 00:07:59.017
we have to worry about cloud storage, and
we talked extensively about Cloud and

150
00:07:59.017 --> 00:08:01.450
Cloud technologies some for
earlier conversations.

151
00:08:01.450 --> 00:08:04.450
I dont think there's much we
haven't talked about actually.

152
00:08:04.450 --> 00:08:06.690
Do we have an acronym of the day?

153
00:08:06.690 --> 00:08:07.340
>> We do.

154
00:08:07.340 --> 00:08:08.760
>> What is that?
>> Yeah we talked about, and

155
00:08:08.760 --> 00:08:10.670
I'll just throw it at you and
see what you think.

156
00:08:10.670 --> 00:08:13.690
Let's do WIPS and,
what would the other one be?

157
00:08:13.690 --> 00:08:15.505
>> You better be careful how
you frame the next one here.

158
00:08:15.505 --> 00:08:16.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> WIPS, okay.

159
00:08:16.360 --> 00:08:19.210
So I'm waiting for
the whole chain thing to pop up.

160
00:08:19.210 --> 00:08:21.020
>> WIDS, we'll go WIDS.

161
00:08:21.020 --> 00:08:21.680
>> Even better.

162
00:08:21.680 --> 00:08:23.480
All right, so WIPS and WIDS, right?

163
00:08:23.480 --> 00:08:28.350
Okay, so we have HIDS and HIPS,
we had NIDS and NIPS, and

164
00:08:28.350 --> 00:08:30.120
now we have WIPS and WIDS.

165
00:08:30.120 --> 00:08:32.640
That is just like wow, okay.

166
00:08:32.640 --> 00:08:35.320
You and I gotta coordinate,
before we go back on camera next time.

167
00:08:35.320 --> 00:08:40.110
That is just an unacceptable level
of garbage, so WIPS and WIDS right?

168
00:08:40.110 --> 00:08:45.000
So Wireless IP or
Wireless Intrusion Prevention Systems,

169
00:08:45.000 --> 00:08:49.490
WIDS, Wireless IDS or
Wireless Intrusion Detection Systems.

170
00:08:49.490 --> 00:08:51.848
Boys and girls, acronyms,
plural of the day.

171
00:08:51.848 --> 00:08:53.495
>> Mm-hm.
>> Good job overachieving there,

172
00:08:53.495 --> 00:08:53.995
very, very good.

173
00:08:53.995 --> 00:08:54.605
>> Thank you very much.

174
00:08:54.605 --> 00:08:56.865
>> All right, so
we have our acronyms of the day.

175
00:08:56.865 --> 00:09:00.405
That takes care of today and I guess
we're banking that for a future day.

176
00:09:00.405 --> 00:09:00.945
>> That's right.

177
00:09:00.945 --> 00:09:01.785
>> All right, good.

178
00:09:01.785 --> 00:09:04.735
So we've talked about all these
technologies, we've talked a lot about

179
00:09:04.735 --> 00:09:08.382
Cloud in prior episodes but we haven't
talked about Cloud storage, per se.

180
00:09:08.382 --> 00:09:10.222
I mean we did when we
talked about Cloud but

181
00:09:10.222 --> 00:09:12.792
we haven't talked about it in
the context of this conversation.

182
00:09:12.792 --> 00:09:16.942
We need storage and we know that in the
Cloud we still have a need for storage.

183
00:09:16.942 --> 00:09:20.482
Which one of the three service
models that we've talked about,

184
00:09:20.482 --> 00:09:21.862
the established service models.

185
00:09:21.862 --> 00:09:24.472
There are three that we've agreed on and,
according to NIST,

186
00:09:24.472 --> 00:09:25.960
are the acceptable ones.

187
00:09:25.960 --> 00:09:27.010
We've said there are many others.

188
00:09:27.010 --> 00:09:29.000
We may or
may not agree on those definitions, but

189
00:09:29.000 --> 00:09:32.980
if you remember, there is SaaS,
software as a service, there is PaaS,

190
00:09:32.980 --> 00:09:36.920
platform as a service, there is IaaS,
infrastructure as a service.

191
00:09:36.920 --> 00:09:39.565
So those are the three we've defined and
have talked about.

192
00:09:39.565 --> 00:09:44.295
Of those three, which one or
which ones require Cloud storage?

193
00:09:45.415 --> 00:09:47.375
>> Well, I'm gonna think all three.

194
00:09:47.375 --> 00:09:49.330
>> And you would be thinking correctly,
young sir.

195
00:09:49.330 --> 00:09:51.525
>> [LAUGH]
>> So all three require Cloud storage.

196
00:09:51.525 --> 00:09:53.301
And again,
think about the logic of this, right.

197
00:09:53.301 --> 00:09:57.630
Anything we consume as a service is
gonna be hosted by the Cloud provider.

198
00:09:57.630 --> 00:10:01.580
Even if it's infrastructure as a service,
we're still using the storage network that

199
00:10:01.580 --> 00:10:05.330
the Cloud provider is giving us
access to to provision our data.

200
00:10:05.330 --> 00:10:08.010
When it's past platform as a service

201
00:10:08.010 --> 00:10:10.940
we're using the storage network
the Cloud provider is giving us, but

202
00:10:10.940 --> 00:10:14.220
they're provisioning a large portion
of the infrastructure for us.

203
00:10:14.220 --> 00:10:17.810
When we're using SaaS the one thing
the Cloud provider says to us is hey,

204
00:10:17.810 --> 00:10:18.550
gimme your data.

205
00:10:18.550 --> 00:10:20.390
I'm gonna go put it somewhere and
store it for you.

206
00:10:20.390 --> 00:10:25.260
And all you gotta do is use this really
cool web API front end to open it up, and

207
00:10:25.260 --> 00:10:25.860
access it.

208
00:10:25.860 --> 00:10:29.550
And yeah, maybe you wanna create some
users on occasion, and administer those,

209
00:10:29.550 --> 00:10:30.980
so we'll give you rights to do that.

210
00:10:30.980 --> 00:10:33.760
But all that other stuff that's all us,
we're taking care of that.

211
00:10:33.760 --> 00:10:36.430
All three of the Cloud service
models that we've talked about,

212
00:10:36.430 --> 00:10:37.830
all require Cloud storage.
