00:20:56.375 --> 00:20:57.275
You could buy them for

441
00:20:57.275 --> 00:21:01.253
a few hundred dollars depending on the
kind of system you want all the way up to

442
00:21:01.253 --> 00:21:05.655
$50,000 for high-end net app devices,
things like that that are very high end.

443
00:21:05.655 --> 00:21:07.866
Very, very complex NAS devices.

444
00:21:07.866 --> 00:21:10.187
But NAS is a pretty common
thought process today.

445
00:21:10.187 --> 00:21:13.816
Most people in small and
medium-sized networks are not gonna have

446
00:21:13.816 --> 00:21:17.441
the ability and the money to deploy a SAN,
a storage area network,

447
00:21:17.441 --> 00:21:21.754
which usually starts out at 50 to
$100,000 and above, depending.

448
00:21:21.754 --> 00:21:24.692
And you can have multimillion
dollar SAN systems out there.

449
00:21:24.692 --> 00:21:28.768
But the average SAN is gonna
be at least 50 to $100,000 for

450
00:21:28.768 --> 00:21:30.860
a reasonable brand today.

451
00:21:30.860 --> 00:21:33.410
Most businesses can't
afford that kind of money,

452
00:21:33.410 --> 00:21:35.370
it's just a very expensive solution.

453
00:21:35.370 --> 00:21:38.880
It's very high-performing, there's a lot
of value in that, but the reality is,

454
00:21:38.880 --> 00:21:41.290
you're spending a lot of money
to get access to that storage.

455
00:21:41.290 --> 00:21:44.360
So a lot of smaller customers
of mine are using NAS devices.

456
00:21:44.360 --> 00:21:48.520
They're just about as good as long as your
performance expectations are in line.

457
00:21:48.520 --> 00:21:51.250
You can do very well with NAS
devices in virtualized environments.

458
00:21:51.250 --> 00:21:53.100
They're really not very
difficult to use at all.

459
00:21:53.100 --> 00:21:56.790
But like anything else we do have to
think about security implications.

460
00:21:56.790 --> 00:22:00.560
User permissions, again your
access control keeps coming back.

461
00:22:00.560 --> 00:22:03.800
Security permissions in general, or
rather security concerns in general

462
00:22:03.800 --> 00:22:07.520
whether physical or virtual revolve
around these same thought processes.

463
00:22:07.520 --> 00:22:08.240
Physical security.

464
00:22:08.240 --> 00:22:12.380
Can somebody get to the NAS box or devices
that are racked or wherever they are.

465
00:22:12.380 --> 00:22:13.370
Can they walk out with them literally?

466
00:22:13.370 --> 00:22:17.003
They may not be much bigger,
literally, some of these NAST devices.

467
00:22:17.003 --> 00:22:20.790
I'm just gonna borrow two
representations here.

468
00:22:20.790 --> 00:22:25.730
A lot of these NAST devices are not
much bigger than this stack right here,

469
00:22:25.730 --> 00:22:29.150
and then just imagine this out
about two inches as a square box.

470
00:22:29.150 --> 00:22:30.060
They're not much bigger.

471
00:22:30.060 --> 00:22:33.410
They're maybe four by four, maybe
four by eight or something like that.

472
00:22:33.410 --> 00:22:34.660
They're not very big, so

473
00:22:34.660 --> 00:22:39.380
it's the size of a small speaker, one of
those home personal stereo speaker things.

474
00:22:39.380 --> 00:22:40.120
They're not very big.

475
00:22:40.120 --> 00:22:42.100
You could walk out with
one under your arm and

476
00:22:42.100 --> 00:22:44.940
most people probably wouldn't know what it
is if they're not paying attention to you.

477
00:22:44.940 --> 00:22:47.130
So if somebody can get
into the data center or

478
00:22:47.130 --> 00:22:49.740
get into the wiring closet,
whereever these things are stored.

479
00:22:49.740 --> 00:22:51.350
I've seen them stored on people's desks,

480
00:22:51.350 --> 00:22:55.715
I mean just holding up books,
all sorts of crazy stuff right?

481
00:22:55.715 --> 00:22:58.070
But if they're just plugged in with
a network cable and a power cord,

482
00:22:58.070 --> 00:22:58.810
that's really all you need.

483
00:22:58.810 --> 00:23:00.790
You don't need much more than that right?

484
00:23:00.790 --> 00:23:03.310
So somebody can just walk off with it,
if they can gain access to it.

485
00:23:03.310 --> 00:23:04.513
That could be an issue.
They can also,

486
00:23:04.513 --> 00:23:06.633
they do have USB ports
typically on the back.

487
00:23:06.633 --> 00:23:10.582
You may be able to upload data into
the device if you can gain physical

488
00:23:10.582 --> 00:23:11.428
access to it.

489
00:23:11.428 --> 00:23:14.372
So somebody may be able to
upload malware or bad files,

490
00:23:14.372 --> 00:23:18.220
things like that to the device as well,
infecting the entire network.

491
00:23:18.220 --> 00:23:21.630
Yeah, if you think about the fact that
everybody comes to drink at one point,

492
00:23:21.630 --> 00:23:24.620
right, and you infect that place,
everybody that drinks,

493
00:23:24.620 --> 00:23:27.190
everybody that accesses the data is
essentially going to get infected.

494
00:23:27.190 --> 00:23:31.200
If I can infect the NAS,
I can touch everybody in the network.

495
00:23:31.200 --> 00:23:32.910
So I don't have to go after
each individual machine.

496
00:23:32.910 --> 00:23:34.780
I can essentially attack you right there.

497
00:23:34.780 --> 00:23:38.232
So if I can gain physical access to
the network that may really be a very big

498
00:23:38.232 --> 00:23:39.318
complication for me.

499
00:23:39.318 --> 00:23:40.851
So I have to think about that.

500
00:23:40.851 --> 00:23:41.873
Maintenance.

501
00:23:41.873 --> 00:23:45.188
Right, I mean these boxes
are fairly straight forward, but

502
00:23:45.188 --> 00:23:48.828
you know when was the last time you
took a NAS device off the shelf and

503
00:23:48.828 --> 00:23:51.210
opened it up and did a little job on it?

504
00:23:51.210 --> 00:23:53.160
I mean we're having
trouble fixing a timer.

505
00:23:53.160 --> 00:23:56.370
We're not gonna be able to fix a NAS
device that easily, so you know these

506
00:23:56.370 --> 00:24:00.450
things are really kind of built in such
a way that you don't tend to open them up.

507
00:24:00.450 --> 00:24:02.120
You can.
I mean you can swap out hard drives.

508
00:24:02.120 --> 00:24:03.030
I'm not suggesting you couldn't,

509
00:24:03.030 --> 00:24:05.940
but you know the average person can't do
a lot of maintenance on these things.

510
00:24:05.940 --> 00:24:08.770
So we may have to get a professional
to come in and do some work on them.

511
00:24:08.770 --> 00:24:10.770
Especially the higher end ones, right?

512
00:24:10.770 --> 00:24:12.220
The $50,000 net app device?

513
00:24:12.220 --> 00:24:13.590
You're not opening that thing up yourself.

514
00:24:13.590 --> 00:24:14.870
I mean, you could.

515
00:24:14.870 --> 00:24:16.110
But you're voiding your warranty.

516
00:24:16.110 --> 00:24:16.970
So you're not gonna do that.

517
00:24:16.970 --> 00:24:18.160
So you're gonna have to get support.

518
00:24:18.160 --> 00:24:20.400
So there's gonna be additional expense and
concern.

519
00:24:20.400 --> 00:24:23.600
What if that person that comes
in swaps out that hard drive and

520
00:24:23.600 --> 00:24:27.140
doesn't even give it to you to destroy or
dispose of securely, and walks out

521
00:24:27.140 --> 00:24:30.920
the door with data on your hard drive and
gives you a brand new hard drive?

522
00:24:30.920 --> 00:24:32.990
This can happen,
it happens all the time, right?

523
00:24:32.990 --> 00:24:35.850
So we gotta think about this,
same thing with sand devices by the way.

524
00:24:35.850 --> 00:24:40.120
Storage area networks, same idea, at the
end of the day there's a very large rack

525
00:24:40.120 --> 00:24:43.415
of hard drives sitting in cabinets
that back-end these things

526
00:24:43.415 --> 00:24:46.595
because we have to get to that
physical storage layer at some point.

527
00:24:46.595 --> 00:24:49.725
Just like wireless systems
ultimately end up dead-ending

528
00:24:49.725 --> 00:24:51.855
in wireless connections back to our stack.

529
00:24:51.855 --> 00:24:54.575
There's no such thing as a true
wireless solution end-to-end.

530
00:24:54.575 --> 00:24:56.175
Because somewhere you gotta plug in.

531
00:24:56.175 --> 00:24:59.225
Somewhere you've got to hit the rest
of the network that's wired up.

532
00:24:59.225 --> 00:25:00.155
At least today anyway.

533
00:25:00.155 --> 00:25:02.720
That may change in the future but
for today that's the way it is.

534
00:25:02.720 --> 00:25:07.640
So these virtualized environments, these
storage solutions, they're abstracted but

535
00:25:07.640 --> 00:25:11.760
ultimately, there's a row of hard disks
sitting somewhere in cabinets spinning

536
00:25:11.760 --> 00:25:13.330
that you've gotta access.

537
00:25:13.330 --> 00:25:16.650
That is potentially an issue cuz
that's the point of access that

538
00:25:16.650 --> 00:25:19.860
we have to be concerned with is CASP
because that's where a bad actor is

539
00:25:19.860 --> 00:25:23.640
gonna try to get to ultimately or at least
in theory where we may be most vulnerable.

540
00:25:23.640 --> 00:25:27.050
Because again, physical security may
not be the thing we're focusing on.

541
00:25:27.050 --> 00:25:34.090
We've got our zones and our masking going
on, right, so our virtual security.

542
00:25:34.090 --> 00:25:35.906
But we left the door wide
open essentially, right?

543
00:25:35.906 --> 00:25:37.770
>> [LAUGH]
>> To the wiring closet, or storage room,

544
00:25:37.770 --> 00:25:39.610
or whatever and somebody walked in.

545
00:25:39.610 --> 00:25:42.770
And for all that great logical security
they just pulled the thing right off

546
00:25:42.770 --> 00:25:44.950
the network stack, walked out with it, and

547
00:25:44.950 --> 00:25:47.895
left us a little smiley face note
that said thank you very much, right?

548
00:25:47.895 --> 00:25:49.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> That could be a problem, right?

549
00:25:49.320 --> 00:25:51.160
>> Yes.
>> So remember, whether it's virtual or

550
00:25:51.160 --> 00:25:54.360
not, right, we've talked about the fact
that all these things potentially have to

551
00:25:54.360 --> 00:25:55.310
be treated the same way.

552
00:25:56.338 --> 00:25:59.220
>> All right Adam great look
at enterprise storage and

553
00:25:59.220 --> 00:26:00.590
a lot of different options there.

554
00:26:00.590 --> 00:26:03.290
Which one we choose really
depends on what our needs are.

555
00:26:03.290 --> 00:26:06.540
Again, we go back to the whole
why question I think, there.

556
00:26:06.540 --> 00:26:08.500
>> Root cause,
the whole why question absolutely.

557
00:26:08.500 --> 00:26:09.530
>> Which one we choose.

558
00:26:09.530 --> 00:26:10.328
Thanks for that Adam.

559
00:26:10.328 --> 00:26:12.313
Appreciate it and
hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

560
00:26:12.313 --> 00:26:15.229
Remember, if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

561
00:26:15.229 --> 00:26:17.712
just shoot us an email
here at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

562
00:26:17.712 --> 00:26:19.941
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

563
00:26:19.941 --> 00:26:21.797
>> I'm sorry, I was reading the whole,

564
00:26:21.797 --> 00:26:25.209
how many feet of lime in the toilet
planner comments on the chat.

565
00:26:25.209 --> 00:26:26.880
>> Yeah, yeah.

566
00:26:26.880 --> 00:26:30.492
>> I'm befuddled by the whole toilet
recycling phenomenon going on.

567
00:26:30.492 --> 00:26:32.233
>> We'll see you next time.

568
00:26:32.233 --> 00:26:33.879
>> Take care everybody.

569
00:26:33.879 --> 00:26:39.250

1

2

Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.612 --> 00:00:16.842
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.842 --> 00:00:19.943
Today we're doing
a ComtTIA Advanced Security Practitioner.

5
00:00:19.943 --> 00:00:21.702
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:21.702 --> 00:00:25.320
we're gonna be continuing our
conversation on enterprise storage.

7
00:00:25.320 --> 00:00:28.080
We've already had a pretty lengthy
conversation on lot of the different

8
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:31.320
types of storage that we can expect
to find and have to deal with and

9
00:00:31.320 --> 00:00:34.670
have to secure an enterprise environment
but we didn't get to all of them.

10
00:00:34.670 --> 00:00:38.340
So, we're back again for round two and
here with us is Mr. Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:38.340 --> 00:00:39.230
How's it going, Adam?

12
00:00:39.230 --> 00:00:39.920
>> Good, good.

13
00:00:39.920 --> 00:00:43.280
You know, I'm feeling very torn as we
begin our second conversation with

14
00:00:43.280 --> 00:00:44.210
regards to storage.

15
00:00:44.210 --> 00:00:47.475
I'm torn about the difference
between SCSI and iSCSI.

16
00:00:47.475 --> 00:00:49.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> I get asked about this all the time and

17
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:52.420
people don't realize that
there is a difference.

18
00:00:52.420 --> 00:00:56.670
And indeed they are essentially the same
technology, the same storage protocol, but

19
00:00:56.670 --> 00:00:57.900
treated differently.

20
00:00:57.900 --> 00:01:00.280
Anybody know out there what
the difference is between SCSI and

21
00:01:00.280 --> 00:01:02.220
iSCSI in terms of storage methods?

22
00:01:02.220 --> 00:01:04.458
>> Tick, tock, tick, tock, tick, tock.

23
00:01:04.458 --> 00:01:05.714
>> By the way, no pressure, but

24
00:01:05.714 --> 00:01:09.060
I'm not gonna continue talking
[LAUGH] until you figure this out.

25
00:01:09.060 --> 00:01:10.660
I thought I'd throw that out there for
you.

26
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:12.460
It's about setting the right expectations.

27
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:14.350
That's what I've learned
with raising kids,

28
00:01:14.350 --> 00:01:16.050
about having the right
expectation going in.

29
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:18.460
So that everybody understands what
they have to do to be successful.

30
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:22.530
So since nobody's answered, we're going to
put up the gone fishing sign, and Mike and

31
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:23.345
I will be back in a while.

32
00:01:23.345 --> 00:01:25.310
[LAUGH] I'm only kidding.

33
00:01:25.310 --> 00:01:26.595
We're not going anywhere.

34
00:01:26.595 --> 00:01:28.720
So, what is the difference
between SCSI and iSCSI.

35
00:01:28.720 --> 00:01:32.430
I get asked this a great deal,
especially when I'm doing visualization

36
00:01:32.430 --> 00:01:34.860
classes where I discuss
virtualization with clients.

37
00:01:34.860 --> 00:01:39.330
Because you know a lot of people know
iSCSI or SCSI, but they don't often think

38
00:01:39.330 --> 00:01:41.970
of the two as being synonymous in the
sense that they come from the same place.

39
00:01:41.970 --> 00:01:43.620
They essentially are the same thing.

40
00:01:43.620 --> 00:01:46.380
It's a question of how we
access the technology.

41
00:01:46.380 --> 00:01:50.560
SCSI hard drives, or SCSI solutions,
are essentially internal to a machine.

42
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:51.770
You use a SCSI hard drive.

43
00:01:51.770 --> 00:01:54.040
Many of us have probably,
if you've been doing this long enough,

44
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:55.870
have seen them in servers over the years.

45
00:01:55.870 --> 00:01:59.280
I used to have them in my
desktop computers at one point.

46
00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:02.270
You'd have an Adaptec SCSI card,

47
00:02:02.270 --> 00:02:06.230
and you'd have the SCSI daisy
chain set up with all the drives.

48
00:02:06.230 --> 00:02:08.640
At the time that was bitchin
cool technology, right?

49
00:02:08.640 --> 00:02:09.690
>> It was, yes.

50
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:13.810
>> That was the really,
really cool kids that had that stuff.

51
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:16.410
The normal kids had just I go E drives,
yeah.

52
00:02:16.410 --> 00:02:18.280
>> E drives.
[LAUGH] >> Because they weren't as cool.

53
00:02:18.280 --> 00:02:21.040
They couldn't afford
the really good iSCSI drives.

54
00:02:21.040 --> 00:02:23.455
Right?

55
00:02:23.455 --> 00:02:24.254
Or SCSI drives rather.

56
00:02:24.254 --> 00:02:25.242
So we would have the SCSI drives.

57
00:02:25.242 --> 00:02:28.996
We'd daisy chain those with the cables and
you would have the Adaptec card or

58
00:02:28.996 --> 00:02:30.680
whatever it was, the SCSI card.

59
00:02:30.680 --> 00:02:31.420
I keep saying iSCSI.

60
00:02:31.420 --> 00:02:32.970
You would have the SCSI
card you would put in,

61
00:02:32.970 --> 00:02:35.490
and you would have that, but
it was all internal hard drives.

62
00:02:35.490 --> 00:02:39.980
iSCSI is the use of the SCSI protocol to
connect to SCSI storage over the internet,

63
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:41.431
hence the lower-case i.

64
00:02:41.431 --> 00:02:43.810
iSCSI, internet-based SCSI.

65
00:02:43.810 --> 00:02:47.070
So people often don't realize that
essentially we're just talking about

66
00:02:47.070 --> 00:02:49.830
an updated version of those old SCSI
drives you used to use in your machines.

67
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:54.780
So there's a little geek factoid for you,
if you're gonna do a geek trivia later.

68
00:02:54.780 --> 00:02:58.255
And if you do and you win,
I get 10% of everything.

69
00:02:58.255 --> 00:02:59.480
>> 10%?
That's pretty good.

70
00:02:59.480 --> 00:03:03.205
>> I'm a reasonable, benevolent dictator
but I want 10% of everything that you get,

71
00:03:03.205 --> 00:03:05.200
[LAUGH] if you win in
Geek Trivia later on.

72
00:03:05.200 --> 00:03:07.360
So iSCSI is a storage protocol.

73
00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:10.130
It is a very common one, probably the most
common one we use today as a matter of

74
00:03:10.130 --> 00:03:12.190
fact, with regards to storage.

75
00:03:12.190 --> 00:03:14.890
Specifically in cloud environments,
in virtual environments.

76
00:03:14.890 --> 00:03:17.170
Almost anything you do is
gonna be driven by iSCSI.

77
00:03:17.170 --> 00:03:22.040
It's the, I don't know, the HP print
driver of the storage world these days,

78
00:03:22.040 --> 00:03:25.140
because it does everything,
and essentially is everywhere.

79
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:29.755
So iSCSI is internet SCSI, or internet
Small Small computer system interface.

80
00:03:29.755 --> 00:03:32.595
If you really wanna know
what iSCSI stands for.

81
00:03:32.595 --> 00:03:36.605
But it's a protocol essentially that
allows us to link to storage base networks

82
00:03:36.605 --> 00:03:41.345
that are driving or being used by SCSI
systems essentially to provide storage.

83
00:03:41.345 --> 00:03:45.635
iSCSI architecture, like all of
the storage architectures we use

84
00:03:45.635 --> 00:03:49.835
that are network based, is gonna be made
up of two very critical moving parts.

85
00:03:49.835 --> 00:03:53.840
We have what are known as HBAs,
host bus adapters,

86
00:03:53.840 --> 00:03:55.990
they're commonly referred
to as initiators.

87
00:03:55.990 --> 00:03:58.980
And they will be used on the host,
in other words,

88
00:03:58.980 --> 00:04:04.380
on the endpoint site that we are accessing
storage from to be able to go ahead and

89
00:04:04.380 --> 00:04:08.540
we are going to be able to access
the storage network through the initiator.

90
00:04:08.540 --> 00:04:11.760
And then we have what is
called a storage processor, or

91
00:04:11.760 --> 00:04:14.620
is sometimes referred to as a target,
on the other side.

92
00:04:14.620 --> 00:04:18.520
Depends on the language and
terminology in the documentation you read.

93
00:04:18.520 --> 00:04:23.800
But generically, the HBA is the storage
processor that is on the host.

94
00:04:23.800 --> 00:04:27.542
And the storage processor generically
the SP is simply the target,

95
00:04:27.542 --> 00:04:32.030
the place you wanna go to the access
storage of the far side of the network.

96
00:04:32.030 --> 00:04:33.900
So we have initiator and targets,

97
00:04:33.900 --> 00:04:38.015
we also assist that commonly referred
to them as HBAs and storage processors.

98

off-site and

the building and

00:28:54.820 --> 00:28:58.360

00:28:58.360 --> 00:29:00.780

00:29:09.070 --> 00:29:13.910

00:29:13.910 --> 00:29:15.450

00:29:15.450 --> 00:29:16.080

the tapes are in the same place.

00:29:18.050 --> 00:29:18.970

678
00:29:18.970 --> 00:29:20.400
So we've gotta figure

679
00:29:20.400 --> 00:29:22.230
We obviously have to encrypt our storage,

00:29:22.230 --> 00:29:25.100

681
00:29:25.100 --> 00:29:27.000
Full disk encryption, whatever we do.

682

Tapes were encrypted.

00:29:27.980 --> 00:29:28.620

00:29:35.420 --> 00:29:36.600

00:29:36.600 --> 00:29:38.930

696
00:29:55.290 --> 00:29:58.560

that there is a lot of things that

698
00:30:02.030 --> 00:30:03.840
And while he was doing

703

704
00:30:18.570 --> 00:30:20.550
So he was kinda making it up as he goes.

705
00:30:20.550 --> 00:30:22.580
And again, kudos to him.

706

He understood the importance of separating
the back-up tapes from the data source.

707
00:30:26.230 --> 00:30:30.380
But the crazy way he went
about it was just, one for

708
00:30:30.380 --> 00:30:31.885

709
00:30:31.885 --> 00:30:35.850
So want to make sure we understand the
limitations for operational environment.

710
00:30:35.850 --> 00:30:39.180
When it comes to storage, these are a lot

711
00:30:39.180 --> 00:30:40.620
There are many others, certainly.

712
00:30:40.620 --> 00:30:42.330
And remember, networking and

00:30:51.130 --> 00:30:52.590

00:30:52.590 --> 00:30:55.573

00:30:57.140 --> 00:31:00.242

00:31:00.242 --> 00:31:04.106
We've gotta figure out how to navigate

00:31:08.306 --> 00:31:11.050
good judgment, best practices,
so that way we all more or

less wind up in the same

00:31:13.246 --> 00:31:15.700
And we try to maximize the security

52
00:02:53.410 --> 00:02:56.650
So while unified threat management

54
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:04.200

00:46:27.895 --> 00:46:29.748
there's gonna be several of them.

967
00:46:29.748 --> 00:46:30.909
You're only gonna see a couple of them.

968
00:46:30.909 --> 00:46:34.265
There's a few others you don't see that
will kill you if you try to get past

969
00:46:34.265 --> 00:46:35.415
the guys that you do see.

970
00:46:35.415 --> 00:46:37.250
And they take this stuff very seriously.

971
00:46:37.250 --> 00:46:38.830
This is physical security.

972
00:46:38.830 --> 00:46:42.300
There's equally serious logical security
that has to take place as well.

973
00:46:42.300 --> 00:46:46.710
That's where the CASP comes in, because
it's really our job to be the equivalent

974
00:46:46.710 --> 00:46:49.540
of that guy standing there in the body
armor with the machine gun so

975
00:46:49.540 --> 00:46:51.130
that we're ready to shoot
the bad guys when they show up.

976
00:46:51.130 --> 00:46:51.650
Show up.

977
00:46:51.650 --> 00:46:54.564
And so, we have to figure out how to
do this as we look at this over-arching

978
00:46:54.564 --> 00:46:56.820
thought process of enterprise
security architecture.

979
00:46:56.820 --> 00:47:00.550
Essentially, all the complicated stuff
that comes together in one place.

980
00:47:00.550 --> 00:47:01.420
>> Very good, Adam.

981
00:47:01.420 --> 00:47:05.320
I tell you what, that was a comprehensive
look at comprehensive And social security,

982
00:47:05.320 --> 00:47:08.680
right, tying it all together,
bring all the pieces in place so

983
00:47:08.680 --> 00:47:12.100
that we can have that complete
solution that we need.

984
00:47:12.100 --> 00:47:13.910
So thank you for that,
that was a great one.

985
00:47:13.910 --> 00:47:17.030
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching,
remember if you wanna attend one

986
00:47:17.030 --> 00:47:21.570
of Adam's classes live shoot us
an email here at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

987
00:47:21.570 --> 00:47:23.880
Signing off for now I'm Mike Rodrick.

988
00:47:23.880 --> 00:47:24.900
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

989
00:47:24.900 --> 00:47:25.930
>> And we'll see you next time.

990
00:47:25.930 --> 00:47:28.581
>> Comprehensively so.

991

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.417 --> 00:00:15.575
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.575 --> 00:00:17.168
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:17.168 --> 00:00:21.034
Today we're doing our
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner.

5
00:00:21.034 --> 00:00:25.251
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at application security.

6
00:00:25.251 --> 00:00:27.970
A lot of things involved, a lot of
different things we have to worry about

7
00:00:27.970 --> 00:00:31.760
with these applications, on top of all
the other stuff we've already discussed.

8
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:36.145
Securing the network, securing the host,
application is not secured, well,

9
00:00:36.145 --> 00:00:38.035
the rest of it really doesn't
do us a whole lot of good.

10
00:00:38.035 --> 00:00:40.125
So here to help us with
that is Mister Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:40.125 --> 00:00:41.335
How's it going Adam?

12
00:00:41.335 --> 00:00:43.505
>> Good.
Other system like application not secured,

13
00:00:43.505 --> 00:00:44.965
call Ghostbusters.

14
00:00:44.965 --> 00:00:45.864
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

15
00:00:45.864 --> 00:00:46.764
>> Adam and there's something.

16
00:00:46.764 --> 00:00:48.365
>> I leave the movie references to you.

17
00:00:48.365 --> 00:00:51.965
>> I just gonna say I'm the master
of the name movie reference.

18
00:00:51.965 --> 00:00:55.365
So, when we think about identifying
general application vulnerability, so

19
00:00:55.365 --> 00:00:57.470
let's start talking about
application security.

20
00:00:57.470 --> 00:00:58.980
We really should start
at the framework level.

21
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:01.730
We often talk about frameworks and
something like an SOA,

22
00:01:01.730 --> 00:01:03.170
a Service Oriented Architecture,

23
00:01:03.170 --> 00:01:06.750
as a framework for instance,
would be a good way to think broadly,

24
00:01:06.750 --> 00:01:11.060
right, about applications, about the way
we service them, and apply them, and

25
00:01:11.060 --> 00:01:14.620
ultimately consume them and
provide them in the organization.

26
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:17.170
Whether we're using protocols and

27
00:01:17.170 --> 00:01:21.951
framework architecture elements
such as SOAP, or XML, or

28
00:01:25.580 --> 00:01:30.990
we've mentioned of these programmatic
framework items in prior discussions.

29
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:33.300
Security assertion markup language.

30
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:35.690
XML is an extensible mark up language,
numerically.

31
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:39.830
And we implement that, from a security
standpoint with various takes.

32
00:01:39.830 --> 00:01:42.960
These kind of things are gonna provide
anchor points and references for

33
00:01:42.960 --> 00:01:46.246
us as we begin to start thinking about
general application vulnerabilities.

34
00:01:46.246 --> 00:01:51.690
An idea that for
the casp yields tremendous

35
00:01:51.690 --> 00:01:55.230
value with regards to application
vulnerabilities is thinking about APIs,

36
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:59.350
the programmatic interfaces that
applications used in call and

37
00:01:59.350 --> 00:02:01.480
ultimately to access and
interact with data.

38
00:02:01.480 --> 00:02:02.650
Are they secure?

39
00:02:02.650 --> 00:02:03.850
Are they tested?

40
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:05.260
Are they validated?

41
00:02:05.260 --> 00:02:08.340
Do we know, in other words, what
the application and the code is doing?

42
00:02:08.340 --> 00:02:12.090
If so, great, if not, then should we
be allowing the application to run.

43
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:15.490
This is the thought process we
have to start engaging around and

44
00:02:15.490 --> 00:02:17.330
start from, kinda up this level.

45
00:02:17.330 --> 00:02:21.380
And then we have to work into some of
the more detail-oriented discussions.

46
00:02:21.380 --> 00:02:25.250
For instance, do we have insecure
direct object references?

47
00:02:25.250 --> 00:02:29.840
A direct object reference is essentially
a reference, or the way in which

48
00:02:29.840 --> 00:02:33.600
a programmatic call is made to call
an object and interact with it.

49
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:34.780
How do we deal with that?

50
00:02:34.780 --> 00:02:35.910
Are we calling it by name?

51
00:02:35.910 --> 00:02:38.410
Are we proxing for it in some way?

52
00:02:38.410 --> 00:02:41.640
Do we call for
it with a dedicated reference?

53
00:02:41.640 --> 00:02:44.460
Do we call for it with something
that's dynamically generated?

54
00:02:44.460 --> 00:02:48.200
Is it the actual name of the system
object that the application uses?

55
00:02:48.200 --> 00:02:50.870
If an attacker's able to
manipulate that perimeter and

56
00:02:50.870 --> 00:02:54.328
directly references an object as a result,
that can lead to compromise.

57
00:02:54.328 --> 00:02:58.834
So, a lot of times you'll see
application programmers purposely,

58
00:02:58.834 --> 00:03:01.560
well I shouldn't say purposely,
but without realizing what

59
00:03:01.560 --> 00:03:05.700
they're doing most likely I'm guessing,
hard code references into their code.

60
00:03:05.700 --> 00:03:08.850
Essentially they program in this
is always going to be this.

61
00:03:08.850 --> 00:03:10.460
Or this at this path.

62
00:03:10.460 --> 00:03:12.840
Or this credential is used this way.

63
00:03:12.840 --> 00:03:14.060
Or this equals that.

64
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:15.730
There's various ways you could do this.

65
00:03:15.730 --> 00:03:20.010
But if we hard code an execution path and
we know that certain files will be

66
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:24.170
found in that directory and a hacker gets
to take a look at that underlying code,

67
00:03:24.170 --> 00:03:28.250
decompiles the application and sees that,
they now know a very valuable piece of

68
00:03:28.250 --> 00:03:31.460
information with regards
to our environment.

69
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:35.900
And if they now can use a directory
traversal attack to walk through

70
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:40.040
a server to get to that directory and find
those files, they have a very valuable way

71
00:03:40.040 --> 00:03:43.740
of attacking and getting in and
gaining advantage in our systems.

72
00:03:43.740 --> 00:03:48.150
And so direct object references that
are insecure can be a big problem.

73
00:03:48.150 --> 00:03:50.500
We have to be thinking about this and
really understand this.

74
00:03:50.500 --> 00:03:52.780
It's also how we error and
exception handle.

75
00:03:52.780 --> 00:03:54.470
What happens when something goes wrong?

76
00:03:54.470 --> 00:03:58.290
Do we pop up, you ever see one of those
pages right that pops up from a database,

77
00:03:58.290 --> 00:04:01.220
you get the yellow bar we can see
the yellow at the top as a hacker

78
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:04.900
work citings we know we got an error
page that's gonna be ill defined and as

79
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:07.825
a result of that we're gonna get a bunch
of data that we're not supposed to see.

80
00:04:07.825 --> 00:04:10.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> When we get a white generic page,

81
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:15.010
error 404, page not found, or something
like that, error 403, don't know what

82
00:04:15.010 --> 00:04:16.580
the hell you're talking about
>> [LAUGH]

83
00:04:16.580 --> 00:04:17.900
>> You know, whatever it is, but

84
00:04:17.900 --> 00:04:22.460
if we see that yellow bar that we've got
the back slash or the forward slash for

85
00:04:22.460 --> 00:04:23.790
the directory indicator
>> Mm-hm.

86
00:04:23.790 --> 00:04:26.920
>> We gotta bunch of error exception code
>> That's bad.

87
00:04:26.920 --> 00:04:29.850
Because that's essentially an internal
error that should never see

88
00:04:29.850 --> 00:04:30.870
the light of day.

89
00:04:30.870 --> 00:04:35.120
That because of a bad programming
decision, somebody essentially did a loop

90
00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:38.320
of some kind and
said when we have this error, do this.

91
00:04:38.320 --> 00:04:41.310
And they showed the page
instead of breaking out, and

92
00:04:41.310 --> 00:04:45.390
running some sort of additional process or
whatever may be the case.

93
00:04:45.390 --> 00:04:47.310
We're not using good
programming techniques.

94
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:50.150
For instance, in that case we should
be doing something like a try catch

95
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:51.050
construct.

96
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:54.270
Which essentially would
allow us to try some code,

97
00:04:54.270 --> 00:04:57.510
see if there's an error,
if there is catch it and

98
00:04:57.510 --> 00:05:01.380
then specify what we should do on exit
essentially when the error occurs.

99
00:05:01.380 --> 00:05:05.140
We may be able to silently ignore,
continue on in other words.

100
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:07.310
We may have a hard stop
because it's a fatal error.

101
00:05:07.310 --> 00:05:10.130
There's a lot of ways we handle that,
but the point is we have

102
00:05:10.130 --> 00:05:13.190
error control mechanisms that we
should deploy and should implement and

103
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:16.710
we're not doing so, so error and
exception handling is a big deal.

104
00:05:16.710 --> 00:05:19.760
If we're not doing this the right way,
we're going to get that server in,

105
00:05:19.760 --> 00:05:22.280
you know whatever application,
yellow bar and

106
00:05:22.280 --> 00:05:24.090
we're going to get all
sorts of great stuff.

107
00:05:24.090 --> 00:05:26.820
So try cache statements and
constructs may be very valuable

108
00:05:26.820 --> 00:05:30.440
to help us here things like Java,
C#, Python, they all support,

109
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:34.630
all these languages support them and
we should be thinking about them.

110
00:05:34.630 --> 00:05:37.880
When we consider code to be protected,
we consider it to be vetted and

111
00:05:37.880 --> 00:05:40.470
we consider it to be code that
is gonna behave a certain way.

112
00:05:40.470 --> 00:05:41.900
If the code is unprotected or

113
00:05:41.900 --> 00:05:45.400
it's not vetted in some way then
we've got all these concerns.

114
00:05:45.400 --> 00:05:49.110
We have privilege escalation.

115
00:05:49.110 --> 00:05:50.224
I'm hanging out with you too much.

116
00:05:50.224 --> 00:05:51.370
>> [LAUGH] Yes you are.

117
00:05:51.370 --> 00:05:52.550
>> Privilege escalation.

118
00:05:52.550 --> 00:05:53.340
Right.
This occurs.

119
00:05:53.340 --> 00:05:54.980
We talked about this before.

120
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:59.660
This is when you log on as one user with
probably minimal footprint in the system

121
00:05:59.660 --> 00:06:03.360
and somehow you gain access through
the use of an elevated credential

122
00:06:03.360 --> 00:06:05.710
to become an administrator or
something of that nature.

123
00:06:05.710 --> 00:06:09.720
Now, generically, you have your privilege
escalation when it comes to code.

124
00:06:09.720 --> 00:06:14.340
An application escalation is the same,
but it's not a user that's logging on and

125
00:06:14.340 --> 00:06:15.230
doing something.

126
00:06:15.230 --> 00:06:20.590
It's a service or an application or a call
of some kind that is executing above its

127
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:25.320
intended level, and as a result gets
access to more system credentials or

128
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:28.300
more system capabilities then it should.

129
00:06:28.300 --> 00:06:30.400
This is what privilege
escalation really is all about.

130
00:06:31.520 --> 00:06:34.390
So want to make sure that we know
that there are two distinct types

131
00:06:34.390 --> 00:06:37.510
of privilege escalation that
the casp should be familiar with.

132
00:06:37.510 --> 00:06:38.730
Do we have any idea what they are sir?

133
00:06:39.730 --> 00:06:42.830
>> Two types,
I'll say horizontal and vertical.

134
00:06:42.830 --> 00:06:43.905
>> Very good, horizontal and.

135
00:06:43.905 --> 00:06:45.202
Awesome.
>> I've been listening.

136
00:06:45.202 --> 00:06:46.920
[LAUGH]
>> I thought I was going to catch him.

137
00:06:46.920 --> 00:06:47.980
That was good.

138
00:06:47.980 --> 00:06:50.890
Most people by the way, and
all kidding aside, cuz Mike and

139
00:06:50.890 --> 00:06:54.145
I kid around a great deal about a lot of
things, but I'm serious about this one.

140
00:06:54.145 --> 00:06:57.375
That's actually really
good catch on Mike's part.

141
00:06:57.375 --> 00:06:59.585
No pun intended with the horizontal and
vertical thing.

142
00:06:59.585 --> 00:07:02.695
Most people I talk to and most students
I discuss this with don't know

143
00:07:02.695 --> 00:07:04.687
that there are two types and
specifically know what those types are.

144
00:07:04.687 --> 00:07:07.807
So the fact that Mike was able to
pull those out immediately is great,

145
00:07:07.807 --> 00:07:08.617
really, really good.

146
00:07:08.617 --> 00:07:09.557
So a little hint for you,

147
00:07:09.557 --> 00:07:13.527
if you wanna be a CASP, you should do
the same thing fast, very important.

148
00:07:13.527 --> 00:07:16.697
Vertical privilege escalation, sometimes
just called generically privilege

149
00:07:16.697 --> 00:07:19.997
escalation, or horizontal privilege
escalation, two types, right?

150
00:07:19.997 --> 00:07:21.517
Essentially what are we
talking about here?

151
00:07:21.517 --> 00:07:25.617
If a user performs a function that they're
not normally assigned to in their role or

152
00:07:25.617 --> 00:07:27.707
somehow are not explicitly
permitted to do,

153
00:07:27.707 --> 00:07:29.500
that's a vertical privilege escalation.

154
00:07:29.500 --> 00:07:30.880
They're moving up essentially, right?

155
00:07:30.880 --> 00:07:32.300
They're going above their level.

156
00:07:32.300 --> 00:07:36.170
We call that essentially, well not
essentially, but what we would refer to

157
00:07:36.170 --> 00:07:41.380
that as in generic parlance is, they
are above their station in life, right?

158
00:07:41.380 --> 00:07:43.830
They're not where they should be-
>> Above that pay grade.

159
00:07:43.830 --> 00:07:45.540
>> Above that pay grade,
right, that's what we call it.

160
00:07:45.540 --> 00:07:47.479
So that's vertical privilege escalation.

161
00:07:47.479 --> 00:07:51.600
Horizontal privilege escalation, kind of
think about the logic of going this way if

162
00:07:51.600 --> 00:07:54.851
we're thinking about horizontal,
occurs when a user accesses or

163
00:07:54.851 --> 00:07:58.816
modifies resources that they're not
entitled to at the same level they're at.

164
00:07:58.816 --> 00:07:59.458
So in other words.

165
00:07:59.458 --> 00:08:01.945
They don't use a more advanced credential.

166
00:08:01.945 --> 00:08:02.634
I'm user X.

167
00:08:02.634 --> 00:08:03.992
I don't have rights to anything.

168
00:08:03.992 --> 00:08:08.160
Let me pretend to be user Y that's
a full admin to gain access.

169
00:08:08.160 --> 00:08:10.350
That's a vertical privilege escalation.

170
00:08:10.350 --> 00:08:13.550
I'm user X and I have rights to
these systems at this level.

171
00:08:13.550 --> 00:08:16.985
Let me see if at this level I can
see if I can get other systems even

172
00:08:16.985 --> 00:08:18.450
though I'm not supposed to see them.

173
00:08:18.450 --> 00:08:20.440
That's a horizontal privilege escalation.

174
00:08:20.440 --> 00:08:22.020
I don't pretend to be anybody else.

175
00:08:22.020 --> 00:08:25.920
I use my own credential but I essentially
try to then get into other systems.

176
00:08:25.920 --> 00:08:27.250
That's horizontally escalating.

177
00:08:27.250 --> 00:08:30.460
I wanna make sure we just understand
the difference between the two.

178
00:08:30.460 --> 00:08:34.620
Both can be problematic clearly, but
they are gonna operate and occur for

179
00:08:34.620 --> 00:08:35.780
different reasons.

180
00:08:35.780 --> 00:08:39.250
Of the two, while both can be damaging,
vertical privilege escalation

181
00:08:39.250 --> 00:08:42.540
is the more problematic of the two
because we have an advanced or

182
00:08:42.540 --> 00:08:46.070
a higher level credential that has been
compromised as a result of the escalation.

183
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:49.150
And that can lead to all sorts of
other unintended consequences.

184
00:08:49.150 --> 00:08:52.420
Or a term that we used and defined in

185
00:08:52.420 --> 00:08:56.460
prior discussions around cryptography will
be referred to as the avalanche effect.

186
00:08:56.460 --> 00:08:58.020
Not the avalanche effect per se, but

187
00:08:58.020 --> 00:09:01.820
the butterfly effect that I kind of
likened it to which is a change or

188
00:09:01.820 --> 00:09:06.100
a problem in one area, ripples out and
causes tremendous disruption in others.

189
00:09:06.100 --> 00:09:09.320
If that advanced or
high level credential gets compromised,

190
00:09:09.320 --> 00:09:10.890
think about all the other
things it's tied to.

191
00:09:10.890 --> 00:09:14.710
And think about potentially all the
problems that that escalation can cause

192
00:09:14.710 --> 00:09:17.760
if it goes unchecked or unrecognized for
a period of time, right?

193
00:09:17.760 --> 00:09:19.100
That can be a very big issue.

194
00:09:19.100 --> 00:09:20.930
So what about improper
storage of sensitive data?

195
00:09:20.930 --> 00:09:23.430
We've been going on and
on about this for some time.

196
00:09:23.430 --> 00:09:26.050
Data at rest,
data in transit, data in use.

197
00:09:26.050 --> 00:09:28.570
Real simple, encrypt everything, right?

198
00:09:28.570 --> 00:09:29.820
Leave nothing to chance.

199
00:09:29.820 --> 00:09:32.710
We won't improperly store
data if we're encrypting data

200
00:09:32.710 --> 00:09:33.820
across the entire life cycle.

201
00:09:33.820 --> 00:09:36.600
It will be very hard for
anybody to gain advantage there.

202
00:09:36.600 --> 00:09:40.640
But having said that, what about data
that is actively in use in memory, and

203
00:09:40.640 --> 00:09:42.550
are we able to protect that all the time?

204
00:09:42.550 --> 00:09:46.710
We have this issue, this concern, not
with the data and memory being protected,

205
00:09:46.710 --> 00:09:49.200

553
00:24:59.990 --> 00:25:02.210
the ways we hear about this and
think about this.

554
00:25:02.210 --> 00:25:02.970
It may work, it may not.

555
00:25:02.970 --> 00:25:05.250
The problem is you're
kind of standing back and

556
00:25:05.250 --> 00:25:07.990
hoping nobody notices you may not
be the most effective strategy.

557
00:25:09.272 --> 00:25:13.410
I maybe able to outrun you but you may
not be able to outrun everybody else.

558
00:25:13.410 --> 00:25:16.310
And so they often say as long as
I'm faster than you I have nothing

559
00:25:16.310 --> 00:25:17.380
to worry about, right?

560
00:25:17.380 --> 00:25:20.970
But if you're the last person standing,
somebody is going to notice you, right?

561
00:25:20.970 --> 00:25:22.770
So security through obscurity may or

562
00:25:22.770 --> 00:25:27.002
may not make sense depending on how many
other things are going on at the time.

563
00:25:27.002 --> 00:25:29.670
So while we can talk about
hiding in plain site.

564
00:25:29.670 --> 00:25:32.646
While we can talk about the fact that we
may just be able to just keep our head

565
00:25:32.646 --> 00:25:34.187
down and hope that nobody bothers us.

566
00:25:34.187 --> 00:25:35.986
At some point that may not be enough.

567
00:25:35.986 --> 00:25:40.370
And as a CASP we should not rely on
security through obscurity exclusively.

568
00:25:40.370 --> 00:25:42.990
We really should rely on
security through good design.

569
00:25:42.990 --> 00:25:44.780
Building security in from every stand.

570
00:25:45.860 --> 00:25:47.110
Every vantage point or

571
00:25:47.110 --> 00:25:51.090
every standard that we can check off, that
we can hit in the development life cycle

572
00:25:51.090 --> 00:25:53.960
at every phase is gonna be a much
better approach for us over time.

573
00:25:53.960 --> 00:25:56.340
So I wanna be thinking
about these kind of things.

574
00:25:56.340 --> 00:26:00.380
The idea of input validation as we've
discussed extensively is very valuable.

575
00:26:00.380 --> 00:26:03.490
One of the other areas that we touched
on with that list of web application

576
00:26:03.490 --> 00:26:06.790
vulnerabilities was
the idea of sandboxing.

577
00:26:06.790 --> 00:26:10.670
Generically, broadly, sandboxing,
specifically, we think about application,

578
00:26:10.670 --> 00:26:12.120
application sandboxing.

579
00:26:12.120 --> 00:26:14.680
The idea of being able to isolate code and

580
00:26:14.680 --> 00:26:18.710
validate it before we allow it to
interact is the idea of using a sandbox.

581
00:26:18.710 --> 00:26:22.770
And sandboxing is the idea of being
able to essentially virtually execute or

582
00:26:22.770 --> 00:26:26.640
virtually isolate applications or
a system for testing purposes or

583
00:26:26.640 --> 00:26:30.730
whatever where we segregate that
information from the rest of the system.

584
00:26:30.730 --> 00:26:34.260
We look at it, examine it,
isolate it, execute it.

585
00:26:34.260 --> 00:26:35.840
But we don't let it touch anything else so

586
00:26:35.840 --> 00:26:39.340
that if there's something bad,
it doesn't infect all the other systems.

587
00:26:39.340 --> 00:26:41.600
Now we've been doing this
in malware research for

588
00:26:41.600 --> 00:26:44.880
years by using virtual instances lately

589
00:26:44.880 --> 00:26:48.030
to be able to run a virtual machine to
infect with malware and look at it.

590
00:26:48.030 --> 00:26:50.654
But before we virtualize
we did this with hosts,

591
00:26:50.654 --> 00:26:54.942
all we would do essentially was create
a dedicated host, infect it, isolate it

592
00:26:54.942 --> 00:26:59.110
physically from other hosts on the
network, and then see what would happen.

593
00:26:59.110 --> 00:27:01.690
So sandboxing has been around for
sometime.

594
00:27:01.690 --> 00:27:04.350
The fact that we can use
virtualization technology today to

595
00:27:04.350 --> 00:27:07.440
make it easier to do is really just and
advent in technology.

596
00:27:07.440 --> 00:27:09.550
It's an advantage but it's no different.

597
00:27:09.550 --> 00:27:13.250
Executing an application virtually
inside a sandbox simply allows us to

598
00:27:13.250 --> 00:27:16.450
isolate that application or
isolate anything going on within it.

599
00:27:16.450 --> 00:27:18.180
So I do a lot of this kind of work, and

600
00:27:18.180 --> 00:27:20.310
I'm constantly infecting
my system with malware and

601
00:27:20.310 --> 00:27:23.640
different things to examine it, work on
it, document it, do whatever I may do.

602
00:27:23.640 --> 00:27:27.770
Look at it for customers, figure out
what's wrong, and I run virtual machines,

603
00:27:27.770 --> 00:27:31.440
and I isolate them by simply unhooking
their networking capabilities so

604
00:27:31.440 --> 00:27:34.060
that they can't get out of
the system into the host.

605
00:27:34.060 --> 00:27:37.740
And as a result of that,
unless I do something really stupid or

606
00:27:37.740 --> 00:27:39.550
I'm just not paying
attention to the details,

607
00:27:39.550 --> 00:27:41.690
that malware should not
be able to escape the VM.

608
00:27:41.690 --> 00:27:42.920
There's no way to get out.

609
00:27:42.920 --> 00:27:48.050
Now it could use a VM escape concept where
it may be able to jump the memory divide,

610
00:27:48.050 --> 00:27:52.050
and essentially move out of that memory
buffer if it's really nasty malware and

611
00:27:52.050 --> 00:27:53.610
has some advanced capabilities.

612
00:27:53.610 --> 00:27:57.970
So there are additional steps we can take
to do things to effectively sandbox and

613
00:27:57.970 --> 00:27:59.265
isolate even more.

614
00:27:59.265 --> 00:28:01.580
Java is very famous for

615
00:28:01.580 --> 00:28:06.165
the fact that it uses a memory isolation
sandbox to execute application code.

616
00:28:06.165 --> 00:28:10.250
That's at least been the selling point for
many years of Java and Java security.

617
00:28:10.250 --> 00:28:12.260
May work well, may not,
it depends on who you talk to,

618
00:28:12.260 --> 00:28:15.490
there's a lot of votability with Java,
so it's not as good as it could be.

619
00:28:15.490 --> 00:28:18.020
But one of the things it
is actually fairly robust

620
00:28:18.020 --> 00:28:20.670
is the memory isolation that
takes place with the sandboxing.

621
00:28:20.670 --> 00:28:22.630
So we just want to have
a sense of sandboxing,

622
00:28:22.630 --> 00:28:24.860
have a sense of understanding
what that may be.

623
00:28:24.860 --> 00:28:28.010
There are many application security
frameworks that exist out there,

624
00:28:28.010 --> 00:28:29.885
that we want to be aware of as well.

625
00:28:29.885 --> 00:28:33.000
SDLCs as I mentioned,
software development life cycles, and

626
00:28:33.000 --> 00:28:35.920
secure software development
life cycles do exist.

627
00:28:35.920 --> 00:28:37.290
Microsoft has an SDLC.

628
00:28:37.290 --> 00:28:41.970
There are many, a software development
life cycle framework in SDL framework.

629
00:28:41.970 --> 00:28:44.020
There are many of them out there.

630
00:28:44.020 --> 00:28:48.660
We've talked about not just
secure development lifecycles but

631
00:28:48.660 --> 00:28:52.880
we've also talked about things that are
more broad from a security standpoint with

632
00:28:52.880 --> 00:28:56.060
regards to frameworks and
enterprise security architectures.

633
00:28:56.060 --> 00:28:59.250
But secure development lifecycles
are really important for

634
00:28:59.250 --> 00:29:01.810
application developers to be aware of and
to think about.

635
00:29:01.810 --> 00:29:03.630
We should be using vetted code and

636
00:29:03.630 --> 00:29:06.160
standard libraries that are secure and
are vetted.

637
00:29:06.160 --> 00:29:09.080
And we should stay away from
insecure code libraries.

638
00:29:09.080 --> 00:29:12.390
There are certain functions in the C
library for instance that are considered

639
00:29:12.390 --> 00:29:15.710
to be secure and certain ones
that are known to be insecure.

640
00:29:15.710 --> 00:29:18.360
As a good programmer if you work in C or
C+,

641
00:29:18.360 --> 00:29:22.330
you would hopefully know the difference
and not use the insecure solution.

642
00:29:22.330 --> 00:29:26.461
So for instance str-cat, str-copy,

643
00:29:26.461 --> 00:29:31.078
sprintf, vsprintf, b-copy, scanf, and

644
00:29:31.078 --> 00:29:37.300
gets are all considered
insecure C library functions.

645
00:29:37.300 --> 00:29:39.620
As a programmer,
you would hopefully know these.

646
00:29:39.620 --> 00:29:43.580
Secure alternatives exist for those,
and so you can use a lot of them,

647
00:29:43.580 --> 00:29:47.510
just have an underscore s at the end for
secure, so you can just essentially use

648
00:29:47.510 --> 00:29:53.110
the same insecure name and call
the secure library doing underscore S,

649
00:29:53.110 --> 00:29:56.520
but you would hopefully be aware of
that as an application programmer.

650
00:29:56.520 --> 00:29:59.290
Now as a cast,
are you gonna know all that?

651
00:29:59.290 --> 00:30:01.780
Unless you write code for
a living you probably won't, but

652
00:30:01.780 --> 00:30:04.480
you should be aware of the fact
that there are both secure and

653
00:30:04.480 --> 00:30:08.660
insecure versions of code that may
exist in a program addict language.

654
00:30:08.660 --> 00:30:12.170
And we have to be able to differentiate or
rely on experts, people that do

655
00:30:12.170 --> 00:30:16.230
application programming to understand
that, and to use secure coding standards.

656
00:30:16.230 --> 00:30:19.470
That is gonna be very important,
we do have to know, in other words so

657
00:30:19.470 --> 00:30:20.940
we can rely on that behavior.

658
00:30:20.940 --> 00:30:24.720
Because that's how we securely implement,
things like WS Security,

659
00:30:24.720 --> 00:30:27.080
WS Web Services Security, right?

660
00:30:27.080 --> 00:30:31.370
So WS Security is an extension of SOAP,
the Simple Object Access Protocol.

661
00:30:31.370 --> 00:30:34.810
We've talked about SOAP in some of
our prior conversations around secure

662
00:30:34.810 --> 00:30:38.550
frameworks and secure protocols that
could be used within those frameworks.

663
00:30:38.550 --> 00:30:41.600
We've talked about,
again I've already mentioned before, XML,

664
00:30:41.600 --> 00:30:46.270
XACML, the Extensible Access Control
Markup Language, things like that.

665
00:30:46.270 --> 00:30:48.528
We talked about soap in
that regard as well.

666
00:30:48.528 --> 00:30:50.550
WS-Security is essentially an extension.

667
00:30:50.550 --> 00:30:56.270
It's essentially an extension to the SOAP
protocol, or to SOAP generically.

668
00:30:56.270 --> 00:30:58.250
SOAP enforces or

669
00:30:58.250 --> 00:31:02.855
can be used to enforce with WS security,
confidentiality and integrity protections.

670
00:31:02.855 --> 00:31:06.805
And so knowing that we should
something like WS-Security with SOAP,

671
00:31:06.805 --> 00:31:09.475
is again a good choice from
a programmatic stand point.

672
00:31:09.475 --> 00:31:12.935
One that an application developer that
understands secure coding standards

673
00:31:12.935 --> 00:31:14.615
would hopefully know how to do.

674
00:31:14.615 --> 00:31:18.685
You as in a CASP may not know that but
you have to rely on the people that do.

675
00:31:18.685 --> 00:31:21.655
What you should know, is that you know,
or if you don't know,

676
00:31:21.655 --> 00:31:25.440
you should be able to go out and figure
out that you have to rely on those people,

677
00:31:25.440 --> 00:31:26.448
as opposed to trying to do it yourself.

678
00:31:26.448 --> 00:31:29.170
You don't wanna sit down and
write insecure code just for

679
00:31:29.170 --> 00:31:30.354
the sake of saying you did something.

680
00:31:30.354 --> 00:31:33.730
You wanna have somebody who knows how
to program properly vet that code and

681
00:31:33.730 --> 00:31:35.110
make sure it is legitimate.

682
00:31:35.110 --> 00:31:38.010
We have also talked about DAM,
Database Activity Monitoring,

683
00:31:38.010 --> 00:31:38.750
in a prior discussion.

684
00:31:38.750 --> 00:31:42.510
We've also talked about WAFs,
Web Application Firewalls, right?

685
00:31:42.510 --> 00:31:44.810
And the ideas behind
these are very important.

686
00:31:44.810 --> 00:31:46.500
We've discussed them in prior episodes.

687
00:31:46.500 --> 00:31:50.560
They allow us to keep track of activity,
and to understand how to pay attention

688
00:31:50.560 --> 00:31:54.830
to the warning signs that insecure code
may bring to a system and flag them and

689
00:31:54.830 --> 00:31:57.950
prevent them from occurring, and
prevent those exploits from occurring.

690
00:31:57.950 --> 00:32:00.590
So you wanna take advantage of that,
and understand that knowledge.

691
00:32:00.590 --> 00:32:03.450
And the difference, we've talked
about this with all of the exploits

692
00:32:03.450 --> 00:32:04.910
that we talked about on the OS bliss.

693
00:32:04.910 --> 00:32:09.660
The client side processing versus server
side processing conversation where a code

694
00:32:09.660 --> 00:32:13.620
is trusted, where a code comes from, where
a code executes, is really an issue and

695
00:32:13.620 --> 00:32:14.850
a concern for us.

696
00:32:14.850 --> 00:32:17.320
And depending on where the code is,
where it originates from,

697
00:32:17.320 --> 00:32:19.390
where it comes from,
whether it's trusted or

698
00:32:19.390 --> 00:32:22.680
not, can greatly impact our
ability to have a secure solution.

699
00:32:22.680 --> 00:32:23.924
>> Very good, all right, again.

700
00:32:23.924 --> 00:32:26.910
Adam, a lot of great information
there about web attacks,

701
00:32:26.910 --> 00:32:29.760
web vulnerabilities I guess
that we have to be aware of.

702
00:32:29.760 --> 00:32:33.690
So that we can secure them, prevent those
types of things from affecting our system.

703
00:32:33.690 --> 00:32:37.060
So thank you for that, I hope everybody
out there enjoyed watching this one.

704
00:32:37.060 --> 00:32:40.900
And remember if you want to attend

00:15:57.196 --> 00:16:00.894

00:16:00.894 --> 00:16:03.563

And control what is within
the sphere of influence you have.

981
00:43:18.150 --> 00:43:21.540
And then the things that you can't,
this is risk management 101, right?

982
00:43:21.540 --> 00:43:23.930
Accept, mitigate, avoid transfer.

983
00:43:23.930 --> 00:43:26.910
Accept certain risks, but
do your best to mitigate them.

984
00:43:26.910 --> 00:43:28.590
Put up the cameras to watch people, right?

985
00:43:28.590 --> 00:43:31.190
Even though you may not be able to
do background checks on everybody,

986
00:43:31.190 --> 00:43:32.160
that kind of stuff.

987
00:43:32.160 --> 00:43:33.770
Lock certain areas, and
say, you know what?

988
00:43:33.770 --> 00:43:37.550
I don't care, I appreciate you coming and
cleaning, nobody goes in the server room.

989
00:43:37.550 --> 00:43:38.640
We'll take care of cleaning that.

990
00:43:38.640 --> 00:43:41.130
Don't worry about that,
cleaning crew, you don't go in there.

991
00:43:41.130 --> 00:43:43.630
We don't want you in there no matter what,
under any circumstances.

992
00:43:43.630 --> 00:43:45.620
Control what you can control.

993
00:43:45.620 --> 00:43:47.330
This is important, right?

994
00:43:47.330 --> 00:43:49.775
Make sure we understand that
things that are problematic,

995
00:43:49.775 --> 00:43:51.640
can come back to haunt us in other words.

996
00:43:51.640 --> 00:43:53.840
Very, very important for us.

997
00:43:53.840 --> 00:43:54.490
>> Very good Adam.

998
00:43:54.490 --> 00:43:56.905
Great looking at doing
security assessments,

999
00:43:56.905 --> 00:43:59.630
allot of the tools associated with and
techniques.

1000
00:43:59.630 --> 00:44:03.560
And, of course some great stories that
we've come to expect from Mr Adam Gordon.

1001
00:44:03.560 --> 00:44:07.190
We thank you for that, we hope
everybody out there enjoyed watching.

1002

Remember, if you want to attend

1003

shoot us an email here

Signing off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner.

And specifically in this episode,

we're gonna be continuing our
conversation on security assessment.

7
00:00:25.147 --> 00:00:28.330
We're gonna be focusing in on some

00:00:28.330 --> 00:00:31.803
some of the attack frameworks that we

9
00:00:31.803 --> 00:00:34.385
And here to help us with all

10
00:00:34.385 --> 00:00:35.305
How's it going Adam?

11
00:00:35.305 --> 00:00:36.975
Good, good, good, very good.

12
00:00:36.975 --> 00:00:38.285
Outstanding as a matter of fact.

13
00:00:38.285 --> 00:00:39.552
>> Couldn't be better if I tried.

14
00:00:39.552 --> 00:00:42.003
I'm lying of course, but
that's okay, you don't know that.

15
00:00:42.003 --> 00:00:42.755
Everything is well.

16
00:00:42.755 --> 00:00:45.465
So let's continue talking
about security assessments.

17
00:00:45.465 --> 00:00:47.805
So, we've been talking a lot about the,

18
00:00:47.805 --> 00:00:51.695
if we think of it as the methods that
we use to achieve security assessment.

19
00:00:51.695 --> 00:00:53.045
Wanna talk a little bit more about that,

20
00:00:53.045 --> 00:00:54.870
but really focus more
on some of the tools.

21
00:00:54.870 --> 00:00:58.033
We'll talk about vulnerability
assessments, talk about pen testing.

22
00:00:58.033 --> 00:01:01.460
Vulnerability scanners are very important,
I demonstrated one for you.

23
00:01:01.460 --> 00:01:03.880
We used the zap tool and
took a look at that.

24
00:01:03.880 --> 00:01:05.830
Port scanners are very important.

25
00:01:05.830 --> 00:01:08.390
A port scanner is essentially a device
that allows us to go out and look for

26
00:01:08.390 --> 00:01:12.190
open ports as we engage in
fingerprinting of the operating system.

27
00:01:12.190 --> 00:01:15.890
So we wanna make sure we're taking a look
at those and understand what they may be.

28
00:01:15.890 --> 00:01:19.190
I think I mentioned at some point
in one of the other episodes that I

29
00:01:19.190 --> 00:01:21.680
was at the hotel and
I used Angry IP Scanner.

30
00:01:21.680 --> 00:01:24.710
I think I told that story
about finding Lisa's iPad and

31
00:01:24.710 --> 00:01:26.040
all that other stuff, right?

32
00:01:26.040 --> 00:01:27.660
So we can do that kind of stuff.

33
00:01:27.660 --> 00:01:30.980
Nmaps, another real popular one
you may use, or may be aware of.

34
00:01:30.980 --> 00:01:34.602
We can run Nmap or
the Windows Port WinMap on Windows, Linux,

35
00:01:34.602 --> 00:01:38.584
etcetera with different port
scanning techniques that we can use.

36
00:01:38.584 --> 00:01:43.071
A TCP full connection scan,
a TCP SYN scan,

37
00:01:43.071 --> 00:01:48.176
a FIN scan, a Xmas scan,
a NULL scan, UDP scans.

38
00:01:48.176 --> 00:01:51.372
There's lots of different scans we
can choose depending on the type of

39
00:01:51.372 --> 00:01:52.950
tool that we're engaging.

40
00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:55.550
And the idea is that we're
essentially playing off of

41
00:01:55.550 --> 00:01:58.360
the TCP flags that are set
in the data header.

42
00:01:58.360 --> 00:02:02.000
As a result of that,
we can then turn on certain flags,

43
00:02:02.000 --> 00:02:05.910
or disable certain flags,
looking for behavior that is gonna

44
00:02:05.910 --> 00:02:09.680
indicate the kind of operating system that
may be on the other side of that machine.

45
00:02:09.680 --> 00:02:12.470
And as a result of that,
we can then profile the machine.

46
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:14.790
So when we do an Xmas scan
we light up everything.

47
00:02:14.790 --> 00:02:18.540
All the flags are set on and
we see what kind of responses we get back.

48
00:02:18.540 --> 00:02:20.530
When we do a NULL scan, it's the opposite.

49
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:21.864
We turn off all the flags and

50
00:02:21.864 --> 00:02:24.534
we essentially are looking
to see what the behaviors.

51
00:02:24.534 --> 00:02:26.756
We should get a reset flag, a reset pack,

52
00:02:26.756 --> 00:02:29.177
an RST packet response
when we do a NULL scan.

53
00:02:29.177 --> 00:02:32.323
If we do, we know certain things,
then we don't we know certain things.

54
00:02:32.323 --> 00:02:37.395
And so we're looking to essentially
manipulate all the different kinds

55
00:02:37.395 --> 00:02:43.190
of scanning solutions or techniques and
variances on them that we are aware of.

56
00:02:43.190 --> 00:02:46.500
Based on the knowledge of how
TCP networking is implemented.

57
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:49.200
And specifically,
these flags are designed to work.

58
00:02:49.200 --> 00:02:52.820
And so the knowledgeable attacker, and
the knowledgeable security defender,

59
00:02:52.820 --> 00:02:57.680
may go back and look at the older RFCs,
specifically RFC 793.

60
00:02:57.680 --> 00:02:58.231
Can you do me a favor Mike?

61
00:02:58.231 --> 00:03:03.689
Can you just quickly while we're talking,
can you Google RFC 793?

62
00:03:03.689 --> 00:03:05.674
Mm-hm.

63
00:03:05.674 --> 00:03:07.067
And we'll take a look.

64
00:03:07.067 --> 00:03:10.776
You should be able to get it up in
the RFC registration database, and

65
00:03:10.776 --> 00:03:12.150
we should be able to see.

66
00:03:12.150 --> 00:03:13.070
Tell me when you have it up.

67
00:03:13.070 --> 00:03:15.770
We'll be able to just quickly jump
to your machine and take a look.

68
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:17.450
>> You have it?
So can we go to Mike's machine real quick?

69
00:03:17.450 --> 00:03:18.410
Thank you very much.

70
00:03:18.410 --> 00:03:20.825
This is almost like I don't even
have to say it, it just happens.

71
00:03:20.825 --> 00:03:21.454
[LAUGH].

72
00:03:21.454 --> 00:03:22.960
Awesome, awesome.

73
00:03:22.960 --> 00:03:25.892
I love that.
All right, so you can see RFC 793 there,

74
00:03:25.892 --> 00:03:26.570
I believe.

75
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:27.705
I assume that's the right one, right?

76
00:03:27.705 --> 00:03:28.910
Got it up there, right?

77
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:32.350
So that's the TCP,
the Transmission Control Protocol RFC.

78
00:03:32.350 --> 00:03:34.880
Now, if you are really
wanting to go deep and

79
00:03:34.880 --> 00:03:38.920
dark into how all this works,
you will read this RFC.

80
00:03:38.920 --> 00:03:43.470
This details out for you the TCP, the
Transmission Control Protocol structure.

81
00:03:43.470 --> 00:03:46.720
All the flags that I was talking about,
the RST, the reset flag.

82
00:03:46.720 --> 00:03:48.720
The SYN, the synchronized flag.

83
00:03:48.720 --> 00:03:53.456
The ACK, the acknowledge for
the three-way handshake, SYN, SYN-ACK,

84
00:03:53.456 --> 00:03:54.938
ACK, the PSH, right?

85
00:03:54.938 --> 00:04:00.485
The RST, ACK, SYN, PSH, URG, urgent,
all the different flags that are there,

86
00:04:00.485 --> 00:04:03.433
and you will be able to
understand each one.

87
00:04:03.433 --> 00:04:09.430
Read the specified responses that should
be occurring and the behavior we expect.

88
00:04:09.430 --> 00:04:13.460
That knowledge is gonna be invaluable
to you when you're doing port scanning

89
00:04:13.460 --> 00:04:16.710
because you're then gonna understand
how to profile machines as a result.

90
00:04:16.710 --> 00:04:19.209
So, as a CASP,
you would wanna be aware of port scanning.

91
00:04:19.209 --> 00:04:22.808
You would wanna be aware of the different
kinds of port scans that exist,

92
00:04:22.808 --> 00:04:24.289
as we've just talked about.

93
00:04:24.289 --> 00:04:28.500
I wouldn't suggest you definitely go read
the RFC, but if you wanna become that much

94
00:04:28.500 --> 00:04:32.135
more knowledgeable, go take a look
at it and see what's going on there.

95
00:04:32.135 --> 00:04:33.475
You obviously can drill in.

96
00:04:33.475 --> 00:04:35.275
We have protocol analyzers.

97
00:04:35.275 --> 00:04:38.220
Protocol analyzers essentially
do the same thing.

98
00:04:38.220 --> 00:04:40.640
But they do the same thing
on the protocol site.

99
00:04:40.640 --> 00:04:42.848
Since we're on your machine,
real quick before we jump away.

100
00:04:42.848 --> 00:04:44.140
>> All right [LAUGH].
>> Or we could jump away, and

101
00:04:44.140 --> 00:04:44.850
then we could go back.

102
00:04:44.850 --> 00:04:46.750
That would work equally as well.

103
00:04:46.750 --> 00:04:49.790
>> Just to settle in for you,
don't pay attention to him.

104
00:04:49.790 --> 00:04:51.340
Only pay attention to me.

105
00:04:51.340 --> 00:04:54.130
I'm the one who should be telling
you which machines to go to.

106
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:56.670
Not the guy waving at you
from behind the scenes.

107
00:04:56.670 --> 00:04:57.940
All right, just kidding.

108
00:04:57.940 --> 00:05:01.390
So here let's quickly, since we're
here all ready let's do one thing.

109
00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:02.890
Google Nmap for me.

110
00:05:02.890 --> 00:05:05.630
Let's just show the nice people out
there how they can find Nmap or

111
00:05:05.630 --> 00:05:08.690
WinMap the port for
it since we're talking about scanners.

112
00:05:08.690 --> 00:05:11.863
And so when they go out and
they take a look they can download, right,

113
00:05:11.863 --> 00:05:12.756
from what is that?

114
00:05:12.756 --> 00:05:13.697
>> nmap.org.

115
00:05:13.697 --> 00:05:14.932
>> Or nmap.org.

116
00:05:14.932 --> 00:05:17.360
And then go out and download Nmap,
great port scanner.

117
00:05:17.360 --> 00:05:18.190
Go ahead and

118
00:05:18.190 --> 00:05:22.875
Google protocol analyzers as well and
you'll probably find a bunch, I'm sure.

119
00:05:22.875 --> 00:05:26.390
So, essentially decodes and
analyzes network traffic for us.

120
00:05:26.390 --> 00:05:27.910
I have a favorite,
there's a bunch out there.

121
00:05:27.910 --> 00:05:31.890
You'll probably find Wireshark or Ethereal
depending on how old school you are.

122
00:05:31.890 --> 00:05:33.960
There's also one from Network Chemistry.

123
00:05:33.960 --> 00:05:37.250
Go ahead and Google Network Chemistry.

124
00:05:37.250 --> 00:05:38.244
Two words.

125
00:05:38.244 --> 00:05:42.430
And network chemistry analyzer or protocol
analyzer network chemistry, either way.

126
00:05:42.430 --> 00:05:45.520
But they make one of the best
ones on the market, it is free.

127
00:05:45.520 --> 00:05:48.030
And it's one of the most
powerful ones I've ever used.

128
00:05:48.030 --> 00:05:49.330
And it does everything.

129
00:05:49.330 --> 00:05:52.364
You may have to actually do
network chemistry analyzer, or

130
00:05:52.364 --> 00:05:55.648
network chemistry protocol analyzer
I think is how you find it.

131
00:05:55.648 --> 00:06:00.504
And if you find the URL we should just
post it up in the chat room for everybody,

132
00:06:00.504 --> 00:06:04.718
or rather up on the shownotes,
cuz this is also a really great one.

133
00:06:04.718 --> 00:06:07.481
>> Let's see, I got SolarWinds.

134
00:06:07.481 --> 00:06:09.397
I don't see anything from.

135
00:06:09.397 --> 00:06:10.217
>> Nothing from Network Chemistry?

136
00:06:10.217 --> 00:06:12.120
We'll look for it offline and
I'll tell you where it is.

137
00:06:12.120 --> 00:06:15.110
It may not be listed under that name, it
may have been bought up, who knows what.

138
00:06:15.110 --> 00:06:17.060
It's been awhile since I looked for
it the last time.

139
00:06:17.060 --> 00:06:22.971
But things like NetStumbler, Editcap,
as I said, Wireshark used to be Ethereal.

140
00:06:22.971 --> 00:06:26.641
Microsoft actually rebranded and
came out recently with an updated version,

141
00:06:26.641 --> 00:06:27.395
a Net Monitor.

142
00:06:27.395 --> 00:06:28.380
Mm-hm.
They came out with a new one

143
00:06:28.380 --> 00:06:29.252
which is kind of cool.

144
00:06:29.252 --> 00:06:33.592
WinDump, tcpdump, Cane and Abel, these are
all examples of protocol analyzers that

145
00:06:33.592 --> 00:06:36.920
would be valuable and
potetially could all be useful for you.

146
00:06:36.920 --> 00:06:39.429
Your protocol analyzer,
essentially are network sniffers,

147
00:06:39.429 --> 00:06:42.020
they allow us to look at
traffic going back and forth.

148
00:06:42.020 --> 00:06:45.650
Network enumerators gather
information on not just protocols,

149
00:06:45.650 --> 00:06:49.985
not just on packet information but
users, groups, services.

150
00:06:49.985 --> 00:06:52.115
All without authenticating to a device.

151
00:06:52.115 --> 00:06:56.385
We essentially use protocols that are
open, that may not require authentication.

152
00:06:56.385 --> 00:07:00.995
Things like ICMP, things like SNMP, and
we go out and we probe and we discover.

153
00:07:00.995 --> 00:07:05.727
So, solutions like WhatsUp Gold, if you
remember that, it's an oldie but a goodie.

154
00:07:05.727 --> 00:07:08.022
SolarWinds has a mapping
tool that you can use.

155
00:07:08.022 --> 00:07:10.572
NetworkView, Network map.

156
00:07:10.572 --> 00:07:12.882
These are all tools that
can be used to go out and

157
00:07:12.882 --> 00:07:16.890
essentially enumerate all the hosts and
the network and find out about them.

158
00:07:16.890 --> 00:07:21.059
So another example of things that
may be done on that Zenmap, or

159
00:07:21.059 --> 00:07:23.350
Zenmap which is the windows port.

160
00:07:23.350 --> 00:07:23.960
Windows port?

161
00:07:23.960 --> 00:07:26.524
Will be Zenmap that you can use as well.

162
00:07:26.524 --> 00:07:28.690
It's Nmap essentially,
but the windows port for

163
00:07:28.690 --> 00:07:32.140
that that you can use to do all that
will be helpful in this regard.

164
00:07:32.140 --> 00:07:33.920
What about Password Crackers, right?

165
00:07:33.920 --> 00:07:36.740
Password crackers are tools
that will allow us to recover

166
00:07:36.740 --> 00:07:39.010
passwords from data stored on computers.

167
00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:43.140
So we can take information, typically
hashes that represent the password and

168
00:07:43.140 --> 00:07:44.600
we can run them through a program.

169
00:07:44.600 --> 00:07:48.450
We talked about this in the cryptography
conversation, one of the earlier episodes.

170
00:07:48.450 --> 00:07:51.290
Looking at rainbow tables,
looking at the value of salting and

171
00:07:51.290 --> 00:07:53.020
looking at the way in
which we may do that.

172
00:07:53.020 --> 00:07:57.550
So tools like pwdump,
pwdump 2, John the Ripper.

173
00:07:57.550 --> 00:08:02.110
LOphtCrack, Lopht spelled L-O-P-H-T,
which is no longer a company,

174
00:08:02.110 --> 00:08:05.090
it was bought up years ago and
their products are no longer made, but

175
00:08:05.090 --> 00:08:07.310
LOphtHeavy Industries was
the name of the company.

176
00:08:07.310 --> 00:08:10.820
But LOphtCrack, one of the best password
cracking programs on the market for years.

177
00:08:10.820 --> 00:08:12.870
You could probably still find
it if you Google for it.

178
00:08:12.870 --> 00:08:15.500
I think the last version
was Version 5 out there and

179
00:08:15.500 --> 00:08:17.370
you can probably still find
it if you take a look.

180
00:08:18.510 --> 00:08:20.640
Floats around our hacking
classes all the time.

181
00:08:20.640 --> 00:08:22.444
Cuz people are always
bringing that up and,

182
00:08:22.444 --> 00:08:24.360
hey look what the school
thing is that I found.

183
00:08:24.360 --> 00:08:26.780
Well yeah,
we've known about that for 15 years.

184
00:08:26.780 --> 00:08:28.540
Not so cool, but I appreciate that.

185
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:30.070
But things like Kali Linux, right?

186
00:08:30.070 --> 00:08:33.798
So, secure implementations of Linux,
lot of the really cool hacking and

187
00:08:33.798 --> 00:08:34.710
security tools.

188
00:08:34.710 --> 00:08:35.330
Did I say hacking?

189
00:08:35.330 --> 00:08:36.260
I'm sorry, I didn't say hacking.

190
00:08:36.260 --> 00:08:39.200
Cuz this is a security class,
we don't talk about hacking here.

191
00:08:39.200 --> 00:08:42.230
All the good defense tools,
shame on me for saying that.

192
00:08:42.230 --> 00:08:43.610
All the good tools typically,

193
00:08:43.610 --> 00:08:46.780
a lot of them anyway,
come from Linux distributions initially.

194
00:08:46.780 --> 00:08:49.510
So Kali is one of the ones that
you often will hear about.

195
00:08:49.510 --> 00:08:54.545
K-I, K-A, you know how to spell Kali,
yeah, he'll spell it for you.

196
00:08:54.545 --> 00:08:55.400
>> K-A-L-I.

197
00:08:55.400 --> 00:08:57.328
>> There you go, that's the one, right?

198
00:08:57.328 --> 00:09:00.066
Kali Linux, there's Nipox,
there's secure Linux,

199
00:09:00.066 --> 00:09:04.030
there's all these different ones that
are used for forensic examination.

200
00:09:04.030 --> 00:09:06.710
But also for
security platform assessments.

201
00:09:06.710 --> 00:09:08.240
